TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 10 sitting days after today, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 19 and made under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a short statement about the Committee's concern with this instrument.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —These regulations were made consequent upon the passing of the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1991, which implemented recommendations in Professor Peter Baume's report on the future of drug evaluation in Australia. The Committee's concerns relate, firstly, to discretions conferred upon a public official with no apparent right of external review of their merits, even though they appear to be of considerable commercial importance. In addition, public officials are not required to make a decision in respect of certain matters until 12 months have elapsed. Also, the Committee is concerned about possible limits on compensation for members of the public who suffer loss because public officials do not comply with legislative requirements. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement of the matters raised by the Committee with the Minister.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: THERAPEUTIC GOODS REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT)
STATUTORY RULES 1992 NO.19

The Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 is intended to establish and maintain a national system of controls relating to the quality, safety, efficiency and availability of therapeutic goods used in Australia or exported from Australia. The Therapeutic Goods Amendment Act 1991 amended that principal Act to give effect to recommendations made by Professor Peter Baume's Report on the Future of Drug Evaluation in Australia, with the present Regulations made as a consequence of those amendments.

Two regulations confer important discretions on the Secretary with no indication whether they are subject to external independent review of their merits. In this context the principal Therapeutic Goods Regulations provide generally satisfactory review procedures, some of which were included to implement earlier undertakings given to the Committee.

Also, the Regulations provide for public officials to complete certain processes only within 175 and 255 working days. While this is some protection for the public, those periods appear to be some nine calendar months and one calendar year respectively. The Committee wishes to ensure that these periods are not excessive and are in accordance with Professor Baume's Report.

In addition, there may be a breach of the personal liberties of members of the public affected by the Regulations. Thus, even if public officials fail to meet what appear to be generous time limits within which to make a decision, neither the Commonwealth, the Secretary nor a delegate are liable for any loss which arises from the failure. Admittedly, in respect of one of the two time limits, the fee is reduced by 25 per cent if the limit is not met. However, this may not be adequate compensation. In the case of the other time limit there is no such provision. The Committee is concerned at this apparent limit on compensation for damage suffered because officials do not comply with the requirements of Commonwealth legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the 1990 amendments to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer: Australia will then be able to ratify the amendments to the Protocol. The legislation will also strengthen the existing provisions of the Ozone Protection Act 1989 so that the manufacture and import of substances that destroy the protective shield of ozone in the stratosphere can be phased out in accordance with Australia's National Strategy for Ozone Protection: a strategy which is three years ahead of the Protocol in its current form.

The latest scientific research from the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) and the World Meteorological Organisation has revealed for the first time ever, significant year round ozone losses in all areas of the world, other than the tropics.

There is now very strong scientific evidence that various chemicals such as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), halons, methyl chloroform and carbon tetrachloride are causing ozone destruction at a far greater rate than occurs through natural processes. Results of NASA experiments, announced recently, confirm the relationship between ozone depletion and these chemicals.

Senators will be aware that CFCs are used in refrigeration and air conditioning, as solvents to degrease metal parts, to clean electronic circuit boards and as blowing agents in the manufacture of plastic foams. Methyl chloroform and carbon tetrachloride are also used as cleaning solvents. Halons are used in fire fighting equipment.

Most Australians will be aware that we rely on a small layer of ozone in the stratosphere to filter out harmful ultraviolet radiation. Excessive ultraviolet radiation has the potential to cause major health problems to humans and animals and severely damage crops and natural ecosystems.

Consequently, if the ozone loss is sustained, our lifestyles and the environment around us will be severely affected. The incidence of non-melanoma skin cancer in Australia is already the highest recorded per capita for any cancer in any population in the world. A sustained 10% decrease in ozone is predicted to increase skin cancer by twenty six percent. The UNEP Scientific Assessment Panel predicts that worldwide, we could be looking at an increase in excess of 300,000 cases per year.

Not only suncream but sun-glasses will become a permanent way of life for the next thirty years for most Australians. A sustained 10% global decrease in ozone is predicted to result in between 1.6 and 1.75 million additional cases of eye cataracts per year worldwide.
It is also predicted that there will be an increase in the incidence or severity of infectious diseases, as ultraviolet radiation suppresses our immune system.

Apart from this potential human tragedy, the financial burden of additional health costs could amount to billions of dollars world-wide. The Department has recently commissioned a joint study by the University of Wollongong and the CSIRO to estimate the likely impacts of these health costs to the Australian economy.

Other effects of increased ultraviolet radiation include negative impacts on agriculture, forestry and natural ecosystems including the aquatic ecosystem. Pollution in the lower atmosphere is expected to increase and products made from wood and plastic will degrade more rapidly.

The world will not be able to avoid this scenario unless Governments make a strong commitment to ozone protection. However, the full impacts of increased ultraviolet radiation due to ozone depletion need not occur if the phase-out targets in the Protocol are met and if countries advance these targets wherever possible.

Australia is recognised as a world leader in ozone protection. Australia's action in implementing the Protocol has been coordinated by the Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) through the Strategy for Ozone Protection, which was released in 1989. The Strategy already provides a basis for phasing out the production and import of CFCs completely by the end of 1997 and is now being reviewed by ANZECC in the light of Australia's achievements to date and recent scientific assessments.

Initially, in 1989, there was resistance by some industry—sectors to the early phase out targets. With encouragement from ANZECC, Australia, which was a very high per capita user, has already reduced CFC consumption to less than 50% of 1986 quantities. Under our present strategies, by the end of 1995, CFC consumption is likely to have been reduced to about 10% of 1986 quantities, which would be mainly for certain essential uses and the servicing of existing equipment.

Some industries such as the aerosol industry, have taken a very responsible attitude and have almost completely eliminated the use of CFCs. Others have workable strategies in place or are in the process of developing their plans. Unfortunately one or two sectors remain relatively unmoved. It is imperative that all users of ozone depletion substances complete their planning for a change-over to transitional—substances or ozone benign technologies. One thing is certain, the phase-out of ozone depleting substances will proceed. It is inevitable that those who do not plan ahead will face higher costs as the phase-out dates become closer.

Australia's decision to phase out CFCs in advance of the 1990 Protocol requirements has been vindicated by the recent scientific assessments. International pressures is now mounting for the next review of the Protocol to bring forward the phase out dates. Such a development would bring international ozone protection policies closer to the target dates already established in our national Strategy.
The provisions of this Bill will enable Australia to meet its international obligations. The Bill provides for:
.controls on chemicals recently identified by the Parties to the Montreal Protocol as being ozone depleting, and
.a means by which the Government is able to implement policies which will maintain Australia's prominent position in ozone protection.

Eleven substances, comprising methyl chloroform and ten lesser known CFCs, will be incorporated into the licence and quota provisions of the Ozone Protection Act. Licences will only be granted to companies which manufactured, imported or exported the substances during the year 1989. Quotas will be granted to the same companies according to their market share in 1989. This will ensure that there are no new entrants into a diminishing market.

The quantity of carbon tetrachloride used in Australia, other than as a feedstock for the manufacture of other chemicals, is so small that a restricted licence system alone is sufficient to meet the policy objectives of controlling supply and providing for essential uses.

The Bill also includes a provision which enables quotas to be reduced in line with Government policy. In the past the Government has had some difficulty in implementing aspects of the national Strategy because the Ozone Protection Act was tied to the Protocol. The new provision will allow for achievement of the Strategy targets, set in close consultation with industry and community groups.

The Government will therefore have more flexibility in a rapidly changing situation. For instance, the supply of ozone depleting substances can be reduced as implementation of the national Strategy reduces demand. However, I should point out that the Government's commitment to replacing ozone depleting substances is contingent on the reasonable availability of suitable alternative substances and appropriate technology.

Industry has been and will continue to be consulted on the development of Government policies in this area. Although the Government's primary consideration will be to maintain Australia's commitment to ozone protection, we will also seek to minimise impacts on industry by promoting the development of orderly plans for phasing out ozone depleting substances.
Decisions made under this provision will be reviewable by application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

During the next few years there may be very rapid changes in ozone protection activity throughout the world. The flexibility provided for under this Bill will enable policies which flow from Australia's position during international negotiations, to be implemented.

An example could well be the us of HCFCs as interim CFC substitutes. The national Strategy, which is currently being updated, does not contain a detailed policy on the control of these substances. However, a decision on their control may well be taken at the next meeting of the Protocol Parties in November this year.

The Government is also aware that there are practical reasons for Australia's strategies to be linked to those of the international community. In a number of important areas we remain tied to international technologies. Members can envisage the chaos which would result if CFCs were prohibited in domestic refrigerators before suitable alternative technologies became commercially available world-wide.

Australia consumes less than two per cent of the world's CFCs. The direct impact on the healing of the ozone layer of Australia's phase-out policies is marginal. In particular there is little advantage in regulating to remove the last `drop' of CFCs from circulation at any cost. However, Australia can make a contribution to ozone protection far in excess of our reductions of ozone depleting substances.

It is in the world's interest for developed countries such as Australia to lead by example, and in so doing, encourage global compliance with international phase-out strategies. This is particularly significant when considering the escalating needs of developing countries for equipment which, at present, is often CFC based. Australia has an important role to play in demonstrating what can be achieved and in pioneering strategies and programs which will be directly relevant to the enormous task which must be faced by developing countries if they are to meet Protocol phase-out targets .

The Bill has no continuing financial implications, as licence fees automatically apply to substances placed on Schedule 1 of the Act and are levied on each kilogram manufactured or imported. A small fee will therefore be collected from companies involved in trading in methyl chloroform and carbon tetrachloride to offset costs of administering the legislation.

Mr President, this Bill, is designed to give effect to the 1990 Amendment to the Montreal Protocol. In addition, it will implement the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council's national Strategy for Ozone Protection. It is largely a response to initiatives already taken by both Governments and industry, and to the expectations of the community. I believe that the Bill will send a message to all Australians and to the international community that this Government considers protection of the ozone layer to be of the very highest priority.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1991-92APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1991-92APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1991-92SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1992-93SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1992-93SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1992-93

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now starting a debate on six Bills—Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1992-93, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1991-92, Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1992-93, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1992-93 and Supply Bill (No. 1) 1992-93.

PARA.TAB: The difference between the additional Appropriation Bills and the Supply Bills is that the Appropriation Bills, on the one hand, seek to appropriate money that the Government requires to meet its additional expenditures over and above what it had budgeted for last August until 30 June this year—that is, for the remainder of this financial year. The Supply Bills, on the other hand, seek to appropriate moneys for the period from 1 July 1992 to approximately the end of November 1992—namely, the first five months of the 1992-93 Budget year—pending the passing of the Budget Bills, which will not be introduced into the Parliament until mid-August and which take roughly until the end of November for their passage to be completed through both Houses of Parliament.

The additional Appropriation Bills create an extraordinary situation this year so far as the Senate is concerned. Indeed, we have an unprecedented situation in that Appropriation Bill (No. 3) that was introduced into the House of Representatives a month or so ago, has been amended by the House of Representatives before coming to the Senate. The reason for that was that after introducing Appropriation Bill (No. 3) into the House of Representatives, the Government found that it had grossly miscalculated its estimated requirements for funds and the timing of those requirements. As a result, it introduced an unprecedented Appropriation Bill (No. 5), which was rushed through this Parliament two or three weeks ago and about which we had very considerable debate both here and subsequently in the Estimates committee hearings.

The Government claimed that it had not allowed for contractual commitments for payments that were required in April and May—the next couple of months—when looking at the timetable for the passage of Appropriation Bill (No. 3), which is still to be passed because we are debating it at this very moment. It needed approximately an additional $200m of funds, so it amended Appropriation Bill (No. 3) in the House of Representatives, tucked that $200m into a new Appropriation Bill (No. 5), and rushed that Bill through both Houses of Parliament.

There will be debate about that matter in the Senate when the Estimates are debated in the committee stage over the next few days, because there is every indication at the moment that the Government misled the Parliament in terms of the need for Appropriation Bill (No. 5). The whole rationale for Appropriation Bill (No. 5) was that there were contractual obligations that the Government had to meet in terms of payments in April and May of this year and, therefore, it had to take the unprecedented action it did in amending Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and bringing in a new Bill.

The officials from the Department of Finance were unable to supply to Senate Estimates Committee B evidence of those contractual commitments. They are on notice to produce any documents that they may have to show this contractual obligation before we resume the Estimates hearings in the next day or so. If the Department of Finance is unable to produce evidence that there were contractual obligations requiring the passage of Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and the consequent amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 3), there can be no doubt that the Government grossly misled the Parliament in the whole process of seeking that appropriation. No graver indictment could be made of any government than that it misled, wantonly or for whatever other reason, the Parliament of this nation.

It will be an extremely serious matter if events turn out that way. I will not pursue this matter further because it will be the subject of ongoing debate over the next few days. Suffice it to say, I think for the first time in our history we are considering in the Senate an Appropriation Bill (No. 3) which is seeking a different amount of funds from those sought in the Bill that was introduced initially into the House of Representatives.

As I said earlier, the Supply Bills are designed to provide appropriations for the ongoing requirements of government operations during the period 1 July 1992 to 30 November 1992, by which date it is expected that the Appropriation Bills that will form part of the 1992-93 Budget will have been enacted. These are traditional routine machinery measures and, of course, the Opposition will be supporting the Bills.

The six Bills that we are debating are all money Bills. They have all been introduced at a time when, quite clearly, there is a deteriorating budgetary situation so far as the Government is concerned. When the Government introduced its Budget for 1991-92 last August the Budget deficit for 1991-92 was forecast to be $4.7 billion. That figure has progressively blown out since then.

After holding firm to the deficit, the Government was forced in January of this year to admit that it would blow out beyond the $4.7 billion. The figure put on it in January was $5.3 billion. That has gone out further since then. With the additional expenditure measures that are contained in the Government's economic statement—the so-called One Nation statement—of 26 February, the Budget deficit is now estimated by the Government to be $6.8 billion. But even that figure is going to be considerably exceeded because that was a forecast as of late February. Since then there has been evidence of a further deterioration in the budgetary situation.

Officers of the Australian Taxation Office revealed last week in Senate Estimates hearings that there is a shortfall in the revenue for up to the period to the end of February—the first eight months of this year—of $600m compared with their expectations. Those same officials admitted that there could be further slippage over the months ahead and that they were working urgently with officials of the Treasury to try to get a revised figure for revenue collections for 1991-92 as a whole.

One thing that is clear is that the deficit will considerably exceed the original $4.7 billion. It will almost certainly exceed $7 billion and is likely to be closer to $8 billion. That is only the Commonwealth's deficit. When we add to that the deteriorating budgetary situation of the States, we find a very worrying situation so far as public sector financing is concerned. The Premiers at their meeting in Melbourne only three days ago revealed that their expected accumulated deficit for 1992-93 will be something of the order of $7.5 billion and that that will be blowing out progressively to in excess of $12 billion by the mid-1990s.

When we add that to the deficit that we now have, both in actual terms and in prospect, for the Federal Budget, we have a situation where over the next two to three years the public sector in Australia is going to have to draw or borrow funds from the capital markets to the extent of well in excess of $30 billion. It will probably be closer to $40 billion. That is going to put enormous pressure on interest rates in Australia right at the time when the private sector, hopefully, will be in its recovery stages. Sooner or later there has to be a recovery in this country. The recession cannot go on indefinitely. We are going to rely on the private sector to get us out of recession.

What does the Government do? The Government imposes a major constraint on private sector recovery because of its own Budget laxity in not being able to get its own books in proper shape. Therefore, it has to go out and borrow and compete for funds in the market with the private sector. The inevitable result of that is an upward pressure on interest rates at the very time when, if we really want private sector recovery, the pressure on interest rates should be downwards, not upwards.

It may be—and we will know in the next hour or so when we find out the CPI figure for the March quarter—that in the short term we shall see some easing in the market pressure on interest rates. If one looks at the much more important situation—that is, the medium term situation—one will see that the pressure will be inexorably for upward interest rates because of the inability of this Government to manage its finances in a responsible way.

The economic recovery that we would all hope would be in prospect over the next year or so is going to be threatened by that fiscal irresponsibility on the part of government. That is going to be made worse, if I may interpose here, by the arrogant refusal by the Commonwealth Government to contemplate negotiating with the States to give the States a more stable revenue base. The Senate will recall that last October or November the then backbencher Paul Keating made a statement on Commonwealth-State financial relations, absolutely ruling out any prospect of the Commonwealth giving back to the States some of the taxing powers they have taken from the States over many years. It was, indeed, one of the major factors that put additional pressure on the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and led to his eventual overthrow and political assassination by Paul Keating.

Now as Prime Minister, Mr Keating is apparently reaffirming that view that he had last year. But at the same time, his Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, was saying on television over the weekend that the States need a better deal in terms of financial base and revenue sources. There is a great state of confusion at the moment.

It is incumbent on the Commonwealth Government to come clean with the States on just what they are prepared to do by way of reform of Commonwealth-State financial relations. Commonwealth-State financial relations are in a dreadful mess. They have been in a dreadful mess for many years and it is a matter of urgent priority that the mess be addressed so that there be a greater matching of the responsibility of the States to raise the revenue they spend.

At the moment, the States spend 50c in every dollar spent by the public sector but raise only about 20c of every dollar raised. That is a very major imbalance between their revenue raising and spending responsibilities that is distorting a large number of activities at the public sector level. Unless that imbalance is addressed, we will be failing to undertake what arguably would be the most significant micro-economic reform that could be undertaken in the 1990s.

It is certainly an issue that the coalition has addressed in a very up-front manner. The coalition has given the matter top priority in its Fightback proposals announced last November. In those proposals we said that we would be prepared to negotiate with the States on the basis of returning to the States some of the income taxing powers that they gave up to the Commonwealth as a so-called temporary wartime measure back in 1942. One way or another, Commonwealth-State financial relations have to be put on a better footing than they are now, and it is a matter of considerable regret that the Commonwealth appears to be intransigently and arrogantly refusing to address those really hard issues.

The present Prime Minister has been the architect of the economic mismanagement that we have witnessed from this Government throughout the last decade. Mr Keating has pulled the levers—to quote him—and has had the Reserve Bank of Australia and Treasury in his pocket for the last decade. He is the person who is single-handedly most responsible for the economic wasteland that has now been created in Australia. The Government's mismanagement has destroyed investment, growth and jobs.

In the last few days an OECD study has been released which shows that over the last five years Australia has continued to slip in the relative growth stakes. The last time an OECD study was conducted which looked at the ranking of Western world countries adjusted for purchasing power—that is, changing exchange rates, inflation rates and so on—was in 1985 when Australia ranked tenth out of the 24 OECD countries in its standard of living as measured in material terms. Now, just five years later, we have slipped to thirteenth place and moved to a position where, on average, we are six percentage points below the OECD average in our standard of living.

There are some very clear reasons for that, one being the failure by the Government to manage its own finances adequately. Another is the distortions that the Government has allowed to occur in our taxation system, distortions which have had a major impact on investment in Australia. Far too large a proportion of our potential investment capital has been put into the infamous shiny office blocks which now stand largely unlet in cities such as my own, Melbourne, and any capital city around Australia. At the same time over the last five years we have spent 9 per cent less than the OECD average on capital equipment and 29 per cent more on the construction of shiny office block buildings.

The OECD report also shows that we as a nation have spent 11 per cent more on government consumption than the OECD average. No wonder we have suffered a slippage in our living standards. We are not investing enough, saving enough and producing enough. We have let our productivity growth slide very badly indeed compared with the countries that we have to compete with around the world if we are to maintain or even increase our living standards.

Over the decade of the 1980s, average productivity growth in Australia was less than one per cent. It was 0.9 per cent. The average of the OECD and Western world countries was 1.5 per cent per annum. There may not be a great deal of difference between 0.9 and 1.5 per cent, but it is in fact a 60 per cent difference. When that is accumulated progressively through the course of the decade, the impact of it is quite enormous in terms of reducing our competitive position and our ability to sell overseas and compete with imports in our own home markets.

Business is still very much in the doldrums. In recent days surveys have been conducted by various business organisations. The latest one has come in the past two days from the Confederation of Australian Industry. It has shown that business confidence remains low and the climate for investment remains poor. Over 90 per cent of businesses surveyed thought that present conditions were poor or worse and over 80 per cent thought that the climate for investment was poor or worse than at the time of the previous survey.

Despite the fall in nominal interest rates, real interest rates in this country—that is, the nominal rate less the rate of inflation—remain amongst the very highest in the world. Investors who want to borrow money for plant, equipment, growth and development are still being massively disadvantaged by the fact that the real interest rate they face is among the highest in the world. Micro-economic reform in this country has come to a virtual standstill. The push for increased flexibility through labour market reform has stalled. What the Government is doing is mickey mouse stuff when compared with what is required. The union movement, according to the CAI survey, is more intractable than ever.

For all those sorts of reasons, most businesses are still reducing employment levels. Forty per cent of businesses surveyed by the CAI expect to reduce employment, and only about 5 per cent expect to put workers on over the next year or so. Approximately half of the businesses said that their production capacity was more than adequate to meet present levels of demand. In other words, the picture from business surveys of companies in Australia—companies that are going to make or break the recovery that we must at some stage have—is very pessimistic indeed as to future outlook.

The simple facts of the matter are that we face very grave problems in Australia of a fundamental nature. They are much more than the problems just associated with the fact that we have the most severe recession in 60 years, serious and grave though that is. It is the recession that has been responsible in large part for the massive growth in unemployment that we have had. We now have a million Australians unemployed, another million who are underemployed, and more than 40 per cent or thereabouts of our young people unable to find work. There could be no more telling or damning indictment of government than that cruel figure, not only for youth unemployment but for unemployment as a whole.

The reason Australia has these problems is not just because of the recession, although that has accentuated and brought them much more to our attention. The problems are more deep-seated than that. One of the basic problems in this country is that we do not save enough. Therefore, we have to draw on the rest of the world. We have put ourselves into hock to the rest of the world to an extent that will mortgage the future of our children and our grandchildren if we do not turn things around very quickly. Ten years ago we owed the rest of the world about $25 billion. Today we owe the rest of the world something like $180 billion, or $150 billion in net terms. The drain that puts on our ability to grow and to increase our living standards is enormous.

I mentioned earlier our low productivity growth. Low productivity growth and low savings add up to very bad news for this country's economic prospects. Those things have to be turned around. They are the fundamental reasons for the coalition's far-reaching, massive set of proposals contained in the so-called Fightback documents, which are designed specifically to address those problems of low savings and low productivity.

We need a major revamp of the taxation system in this country. We have to reduce the burden of taxation both on individuals and on businesses in their cost of producing goods and services. That is why the coalition's policies for reform include a $13 billion reduction in personal income tax. That is a reduction of between 25 per cent and 30 per cent in the current level of income tax.

The major beneficiaries of that tax cut and tax reform will be low and middle income earners. It is that category of our society, of our work force and of our income earners which has suffered so dramatically and so disastrously at the hands of the tax regime and other regimes of this Government over the last decade. That is why we have targeted families of low and medium income earners with massive increases in spending in family allowances. We are reshaping government spending, whilst reducing the overall level, by better targeting of it and through eliminating a great deal of the waste, duplications and inefficiencies that exist in the public sector and which cause more and more taxpayers' dollars to be inefficiently spent.

There will be a major reform of personal income tax to give back to taxpayers the incentive to work harder, smarter and better. They will do that if they know that they will be able to keep a higher proportion of the reward, rather than paying it back to the Government and the tax man every time they earn an extra dollar. There will be major reductions in the total level of income tax and the marginal tax rates applying to lower and, particularly, middle income earners. That is also why we have proposals to abolish $20 billion of taxes on the cost of doing business in Australia. We have saddled business in Australia with enormous burdens which make business less competitive than it should be. We slug business unmercifully in the course of its producing the very goods and services that we need for jobs, growth, employment and future investment.

We will abolish the wholesale sales tax; the payroll tax; the excise on fuel; and the training guarantee levy, which is another tax on jobs as is the payroll tax burden which is imposed on business in Australia. We will also abolish the Government's ongoing demand for compulsory levies from employers for superannuation purposes. We will encourage greater superannuation in this country through choice, not through coercion and compulsion, which seem to be the only words that this Government knows in terms of implementing its will.

Unless we do those sorts of things—unless we seriously tackle the need for tax reform in Australia; unless we seriously tackle the enormous problems that we have in industrial relations and our whole wage fixing system; unless we really get down to the situation where we allow and encourage employer and employee at the enterprise level to sit down and work out the terms and conditions of employment which best suit each enterprise—we will continue to shackle ourselves and our nation with respect to our growth prospects for the future, not just in terms of material living standards but also in terms of the creation of jobs. Through that, there will be the impact on society from the desperation of the inability to find work and all the things that go with that cause. We are talking about much more than an economic issue; it is a matter of great social importance. The sooner the Government realises that and the sooner it seriously gets down to doing the things that need to be done the better. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92, the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1992-93, the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1992-93, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1991-92, the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) 1992-93 and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1992-93.

PARA.TAB: One cannot help thinking back to what I had to say in this debate last year. I want to briefly summarise what I said then. I said that the challenge for the Government for the coming 12 months and for its Budget settings in August was to be a little more accurate with respect to what it brought down. It is absolutely essential in budgeting that what we budget for reflects very closely the outcomes with which we are faced.

Ask any business or household, or anybody who has to operate in the private sector, whether they get their budget as way off as the current Government has done when they are heading down a disaster route. As outlined by my colleague Senator Short, this year we find out once again that there are significant blow-outs in the estimates of the requirements to run the business called Australia.

In three of the Bills, and Senator Short referred to others—the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, Supply Bill (No. 1) and Supply Bill (No. 2)—the Government is seeking an increase of some $16.5 billion for government expenditure. In Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, we find an increase of 3 per cent; in Supply Bill (No. 1), we find an increase of 2.7 per cent; we then get to Supply Bill (No. 2) and we find a massive increase of 17.3 per cent. This is just not the way to run a business; it is a disaster route. Of course, that comes through when one starts examining what is occurring in Australia at present.

The simple facts are that governments, like businesses and households, have to cut their cloth according to their income; it is an essential, simple, economic fact. Against this background here in Australia now we find that we have, as is well known, unemployment of one million. The sad part about the one million unemployed is that, apart from the individuals themselves not having a job, they have no hope of getting a job—there are no prospects in the near future. In fact, the real prospect, unfortunately, is that that figure is more likely to increase than decrease. Looking at the Government's policies and its approach to constructive medium and long term policy making, it does not have any plan that is likely to address that particular problem.

On the other side of the coin—a matter that I have raised in this chamber on a number of occasions—there are bankruptcies. Bankruptcies highlight the likely prospect of business being able to address the unemployment situation. For example, last year there were some 13,091 bankruptcies. Already this year, in three quarters we have almost reached that figure—in fact, we are 174 short. The figure this year now stands at 12,917 and with the number of part X arrangements in the pipeline, which are significantly higher than normal, that figure, really, is significantly higher.On top of last year's record bankruptcy figures, we are looking at an annual increase this year of between 30 per cent and 40 per cent. That is on last year's record increases, which amounted to 50-odd per cent.

The comparative figures for the March quarter last year show that there was an increase of 44.1 per cent in the number of bankruptcies. So with those one million people who do not have jobs, and those who are on the edge of losing their jobs, with that level of bankruptcies occurring in Australia there is little hope of business picking up.

I want to go deeper into it. I have with me the recent Confederation of Australian Industry survey. The Confederation of Australian Industry is the employer organisation that the Government consistently quotes as being the peak employer organisation. I want to run through some of the research that the Confederation has done resulting from its survey. Looking at the Confederation's estimation of the current position, it must be remembered that this survey has been done since the One Nation program was brought down, so it reflects the most recent attitudes.

In April 1991, 0.6 per cent of businesses surveyed thought that current business conditions were good. Incidentally, no-one thought they were excellent or very good. The number of businesses which thought conditions were poor was 41.7 per cent. In July 1991, 1.7 per cent of businesses surveyed thought that business conditions were good while 42.1 per cent thought they were poor. In November 1991, 0.7 per cent of businesses thought conditions were good while 51.1 per cent thought they were poor. In April 1992, 0.6 per cent of businesses thought conditions were good while 44.2 per cent thought they were poor. So that is what business thinks of business conditions under the current Government.

The climate for investment is a very important aspect in terms of recovery. In April 1991, 4.2 per cent of businesses thought it was good while 43.1 per cent thought it was poor. In July 1991, 1.7 per cent thought it was good while 45 per cent thought it was poor. In November 1991, 4.3 per cent thought it was good while 48.9 per cent thought it was poor. In April 1992, 1.2 per cent of businesses thought the investment climate was good—that is a drop of 3 per cent over the November quarter, even though it is a very small figure—while 45.7 per cent of businesses thought it was poor.

I turn now to that part of the survey which deals with conditions within business. In July 1991, 5 per cent of businesses thought conditions were good while 34.2 per cent thought they were poor. In November 1991, 16.1 per cent thought they were good while 33.6 per cent thought they were poor. In April 1992, 12.8 per cent thought conditions were good while 31.1 per cent thought they were poor.

The levels of sales within businesses is contained a little further on in the survey. In July 1991, 9.2 per cent of businesses thought sales were good while 42 per cent thought they were poor. In November 1991, 12 per cent thought conditions were good while 33.8 per cent thought they were poor. In April 1992, 14.7 per cent of businesses thought sales were good while 36.8 per cent thought they were poor.

There are many more figures in this survey that are very instructive. The Government should take note of them. According to the survey done by the Confederation of Australian Industry, the indication of businesses is that they are pessimistic and very concerned about their future and their ability to invest, expand and increase sales at a time when we are in the worst recession—for many, a depression—for 60-odd years in this country.

However, there is some hope for Australia. I will use Treasury figures from an analysis made on the impact of the Fightback package in removing taxes on both business and a number of people in the community. Once again, these figures are very instructive. It is notable that the Government has little to say about them because they highlight the advantages and improvements that would occur in the Australian scenario if the policies in Fightback! were introduced. They signify very clearly that there would be significant drops in both the costs of doing business in this country and the cost of living. There would be an improvement for both business and households. Flowing from that is employment, our capacity to meet our current account deficits and improve them, an ability to begin to stabilise our national debt, which Senator Short mentioned, and an ability to then go about the process of reducing it.

If we look at the overall impact of the Fightback strategy—and I repeat that this analysis was done by Treasury—and we take into account the abolition of payroll tax, excise changes, the abolition of wholesale sales tax and the impact of GST, we find that there is a saving to agriculture of $1.025 billion. If we look at mining, we find a saving of $677m. If we look at manufacturing, we find a saving of $5.3 billion in operating costs.

We hear a lot from the Government benches, and particularly from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Simon Crean, about value-adding in this country. The Minister has emphasised this aspect on a number of occasions. The best thing that that Minister could do would be to put pressure on the Government to adopt this package. If one were able to introduce that sort of cost saving to businesses in this country, there would be a chance of getting value-adding off the ground.

Let me go through a number of other points in terms of industry analysis, because once again they are very instructive. We see that for food, beverage and tobacco, there is a cost saving to those industries of $1.336 billion. For textiles, there is a saving of $177m; clothing and footwear, a saving of $139m; paper and paper products, a saving of $440m; chemicals, a saving of $749m. If we look at electricity, gas and water, we find is a saving of $699m, which would impact very significantly not only on the costs of doing business, but also on the costs to households.

If we look down the list a little further at services to the wholesale and retail trades, we see a saving in the cost of doing business of $2.928 billion; transport and storage, a saving of $2.086 billion; road transport, a saving of $1.147 billion in the cost of doing business; communications, a saving of $538m; and in finance and business services a saving of $860m.

One works further through this list. It is a comprehensive list and, thanks to the shadow Treasurer, Mr Peter Reith, it is now a public document and available for all to see. One finds in almost every instance savings to the cost of doing business in this country and significant savings to the costs of being a householder.

What does this all mean? It means that if we get our costs down, Australian business and Australian householders will be in a much better position to start to see a rise in the standards of living. It will mean that we shall be in a much stronger position to be able to address some of our fundamental problems in terms of unemployment, and to arrest the bankruptcies that are increasing at an appalling rate. We do not hear a lot about bankruptcies in the public arena, but they are a real fact of life and cause a great deal of trauma for many people. Bankruptcy is an enormous social cost to the Australian community and more attention needs to be paid to it.

If we turn the page and look at some of the other examples of what is occurring and break them down, we find that in terms of investment the abolition of payroll tax will cut costs by $727m; the excise changes will cut costs by $604m. The abolition of the wholesale sales tax will cut costs by $3.166 billion. If we take away the cost of the implementation of the goods and services tax, we find that investment in this country will be $1.908 billion better off.

Exports are the key to our ability to address our current account situation. For too long, virtually for the past decade, we saw this Government act on the false premise that the way to balance our current account deficit was to try to screw people into the ground and stop imports coming into this country. That process and the high interest regime—a regime which hurt so many people so badly—failed. Those methods will not stop the blow-out in the current account deficit.

The only way to overcome our current account deficit is to make our exporters internationally competitive, allowing them to compete in the international marketplace by taking off their backs the costs of doing business. Australia has an enormous capacity to increase its production, whether it be in the area of agriculture, mining or any other form of exporting in which we may be involved.

If we look at the Treasury analysis of the cost of doing business under the Fightback package, we find that the abolition of the payroll tax will save exporters in this country some $603m. Abolition of fuel excise will produce a cost saving of $877m. The abolition of the wholesale sales tax will produce a cost saving of $803m. As a result of the changes made in the Fightback package, total net savings to exporters amount to some $1.976m—almost $2 billion.Under the Fightback program there is a cut of some $20 billion in direct input taxes.

I emphasise how important that is to the overall cash flow of businesses in Australia. When we think about the imposition of payroll taxes, excises and the wholesale sales tax, we realise that all those costs have to be paid before one cent is earned. In many cases business has to increase its overdraft to meet its commitments in respect of input taxes, which once again has a flow-on impact because of the interest rate costs that are involved in that area. Real interest rates in Australia are so much higher than they are in most other countries in the world. This is a major problem, and it is a reflection of this Government's mismanagement of its fiscal and monetary policies.

I will now turn to the current position in the Australian scene. Last August we were told that the Budget deficit would be less than $5 billion; that figure was later readjusted to $6.8 billion. I believe that we are now looking at a Budget deficit in the order of $8 billion. This Government has failed miserably in adjusting its programs and expenditure to make sure that the cost of doing business in this country and the cost of employment can be paid for and budgeted for accurately. Furthermore, the Government itself has also failed. In the past two years we have seen a massive turnaround in the Budget deficit blow-outs.

It is essential in any operation that at the end of the day we earn more than it costs us. To emphasise the consequences if we do not, I need only highlight the impact of bankruptcy statistics that I mentioned earlier. It looks as if this year we will end up with an increase of 40 per cent on the massive blow-out in bankruptcies which occurred last year.

I would like to turn briefly to a number of other aspects which are very important in addressing the fact that Australia is spending significantly more than it is earning. There are a number of things that need to be done, and they need to be done urgently. Probably the most important one of all is to reform our industrial relations system. The theme of the Government's industrial policy has been based on the centralised wage fixing system. It now tries to pretend that it is working towards workplace or enterprise agreements, but they are not really enterprise agreements. They have to go back to the Industrial Relations Commission. They involve unions, union bullying and union bludgeoning. They have to fit in between the sweetheart deals that have been done between the two Ks—Prime Minister Keating and the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty.

These enterprise agreements are not designed in the best interests of Australia. They do not take into account what really occurs in the workplaces in the Australian community. They have no consideration for the differing circumstances in Western Australia and New South Wales or in Queensland and South Australia or in Tasmania and the Northern Territory. They try to force the same set of rules and the same conditions right across the board in every workplace in Australia. Woe betide people who try to step out of that system. They will find themselves in the courts; they will face strike action; they will find themselves being bludgeoned by the ruthless actions of a small minority of the Australian community who by irresponsible industrial action cause costs to blow out.

One can liken much of what is occurring in many workplaces of Australia to guerilla action. Much of it is not about conditions in the workplace any more: it is about maintaining the hierarchy of the ACTU; it is about keeping the jobs of union officials; it is about bullying many people in the workplace who would much prefer to get on, do their job, earn their money, be productive and see improvements.

We need to lift our industrial relations performance in this country and allow employers and employees to sit down and make their own arrangements. It seems to me to be absolutely extraordinary in a country that is supposed to be built on freedom that under our current industrial relations system individuals are barred from making their own agreements in the workplace.

If we take that a little further—we will be dealing with this over the next week or two—we now find that this Parliament and the Australian community are threatened by a Bill which will endeavour to regulate contractors by bringing them under the auspices of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. All that has come out of the fact that some people with a bit of initiative, commonly known as Troubleshooters, worked out a plan which has been tested before Mr Justice Woodward in the Federal Court, before the Full Bench of the Federal Court and before the High Court and has been found to be legal. Yet we see this Government endeavouring to put barriers in the way of sensible industrial relations reform.

In the time remaining, I would like to comment on two or three other things that are essential ingredients of the Fightback package in terms of getting this country back into profitability again. I have mentioned the impact of the various up-front indirect taxes that we have. I have mentioned the industrial relations system. The next thing that is absolutely crucial is infrastructure reform, whether it be in the transport area, on the waterfront, in the communications area or in any of the myriad of things that we have before us.

We have heard much about the amount of money that has been spent on the waterfront. We have heard about the massive redundancy payouts. I have yet to see—and I have endeavoured to get this evidence—where the cost of doing business across the waterfront has gone down because of the enormous investment that has been made from the public purse to finance the so-called restructuring process that is being carried out on the waterfront. I do not believe that there is evidence that actually shows that the costs have fallen.

We still have the ridiculous situation where it is cheaper to take a shipload of wheat from Australia to London than it is to take the same ship with a similar cargo across from Tasmania to Melbourne. There are many more examples of this kind of thing. Shipping reform and waterfront reform in this country are still an abject failure.

We have seen decreases in the cost of doing business in the transport sector only in those areas where there is deregulation and competition has been increased. There are a number of examples of this, particularly in my State of Western Australia. We find that costs continue to go up in areas where regulation has been maintained, where road has been stopped from competing with rail or where road has been franchised and stopped from competing with itself. However, costs come down as soon as a little bit of competition is introduced into the system.

I come from an area that has been deregulated. When deregulation was introduced, I found that my transport costs dropped by about of 50 per cent. In fact, after the system in my area was deregulated and the monopoly franchise that one operator had was abolished, the cost of carting a tonne of superphosphate from the Esperance fertiliser works to my farm dropped from $11.80 a tonne to $5 a tonne. That is the sort of cost saving that is around if one is prepared to introduce competition into the marketplace.

The Government has been an abject failure in relation to all of the matters that I have raised today. The simple fact is that we cannot go on spending more than we earn. One only has to ask any householder or any businessman to find out that this is the case. Fightback is about reducing costs, returning profit to business and allowing Australia and Australians to balance their budgets. In the process of doing that we will be able to start reducing our debt and begin employing some of the one million people who do not have a job at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this cognate debate on the Appropriation Bills. I commend my colleague Senator Crane for the remarks that he made. I thought he made a valuable contribution to the debate in terms of explaining the workings of the industrial relations system. Senator Crane also drew attention of the problems that the Government, even by its own standards, is having with its policies.

PARA.TAB: Last night the debate, from the Government's perspective, on the so-called Treasury analysis of the Fightback package came unstuck. Treasurer Dawkins was required under the Freedom of Information Act to release a number of other papers which related to this analysis. These papers showed that rather than 70 per cent of households being worse off under the Fightback package, in fact 80 per cent of households were better off, even using some of the very strange assumptions that the Treasury unit had used in its modelling of the Fightback package.

The work of the Treasury, the work of the Government, and its attempt to attack the Fightback package is back in the news today. I wish to address my remarks in this cognate debate to some particular aspects of this debate. I think we are all aware of the role the Treasury had in the analysis of the Fightback package. What I thought I would do today is look at some aspects of that role—some of the issues which are raised by the Government's use of the Department of the Treasury, the use of Treasury officers and the use of taxpayers' funds in its efforts to attack the Fightback package.

I think there are important issues of principle here. We have a full time, fully taxpayer funded unit to analyse every word Opposition spokesmen and women say on radio and television so that it can be reported to the Government of the day, within the hour if possible. In relation to the use of the Treasury, I believe this is the first time that a major unit has been established, funded very extravagantly by the taxpayer, where senior officers have been appointed with the principal role, the principal purpose, of analysing policies. I am certainly aware, as is Senator Richardson, that in the past public servants and government departments have analysed policies which oppositions have presented. They have provided briefing notes to the government of the day on that particular issue.

It is a sensitive area but, nonetheless, it has been the practice and Senator Richardson and Senator Faulkner would be quite right to point out that this has happened in the past. What has never happened in the past is the setting up of a specialised unit in a major government department. This Department is perhaps arguably the most important Government Department. Its sole aim over a period of many months was to analyse and attempt to attack an Opposition policy. There is an issue of principle there.

I agree that just what government departments should do in this area is a matter for debate, but even after the Treasury was asked to set up this unit it was clear from at least one or two public comments that Tony Cole made, who was then the Secretary to the Treasury, that the Treasury was aware of the sensitivities of this particular matter. In a press release on 26 November last year, Tony Cole said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasury has always been aware of the sensitivities surrounding such analysis and is mindful of not involving any officers in activities that go beyond this traditional role.

Even at that stage, the Secretary to the Treasury was mindful of the sensitivities of what the Government had asked it to do on its behalf. It was important for the Government because, frankly, no-one will believe anything this Government says. We can mention a whole host of areas where Prime Minister Paul `There-will-be-no-recession' Keating has deliberately misled the Australian people on a number of important and vital occasions. Frankly, no-one would believe anything Mr Keating, Mr Dawkins and their colleagues say about Opposition policy.

PARA.TAB: The Government needed to see whether it could trade off the authority, independence and standing of the Treasury to cloak its attack on the Fightback package. The Government could not do it itself, because no-one would believe it. For eight years this Government has been guilty of misleading the Australian people on fundamental issues. What the Government had to do—to use Mr Keating's famous words when he said, `I've got the Reserve Bank in my pocket'—was to try to get the Treasury in its pocket.

As a first step, the Treasury was asked to set up a unit to model indirect and direct tax changes. It was pretty clear from day one what the purpose of this unit was. We should not beat about the bush; the purpose of the unit was to attempt to undermine the Opposition's Fightback package. Even in those early days it was pretty clear that Tony Cole was aware of the sensitivities of what the Government was asking the Treasury to do. Given the sensitivities involved, what would we have wanted the Public Service to do, knowing full well that the Government wanted to cloak its political attack on the Opposition by purporting to use the independence, the authority and the standing of that great Department, the Commonwealth Treasury?

A number of mistakes were made and I wish to run through these today. I want to make a contribution to this really important issue concerning the extent to which governments are able to use Treasury and other great departments of government to carry out their dirty political work. What is the role of public servants when asked to perform these functions?

In my view, the first mistake was to allow the unit to be established. I do not think it helps when people like Dr Preston, who was in charge of the operational and day to day activities of this modelling unit, pretend that it was established for any other purpose than to analyse the Opposition's policies. In statements before the Senate Estimates Committee B, Dr Preston persisted with the view that the purpose of the unit was to establish and develop the software and model indirect and direct tax changes. The reality is that the unit was essentially and principally established to attack the Fightback program.

We asked Dr Preston when he appeared before the Estimates Committee whether this unit and the model which was developed had been used to model the One Nation package. One would not have thought that was a complex question. The Government can find the resources to establish a unit to develop the software to model tax changes. The One Nation package had major tax changes and the question was: was the One Nation package modelled by the Treasury? If you had been before that Committee, Madam Acting Deputy President, you would have seen the ducking and weaving that went on. In my view it did Dr Preston no credit, and Senator McMullan kept on chipping in to try to divert the questioning.

Why be so coy? The Government has set up a major unit and spent a lot of money on it. It has diverted important officers to work in this unit, but we cannot even find out whether the `No Nation' package was modelled. I call it the `No Nation' policy, because the policies followed by Mr Keating in an attempt to cover up the disaster of his unemployment policies will cause massive division. Let us call it what it is; it is a `No Nation' policy. We asked whether that major statement by the Government had been modelled and the answer was, `We don't know'. That is a matter that Senator Short and I will be keen to pursue when the Estimates Committee B report comes before Parliament.

It was admitted before Estimates Committee B that some $300,000 had been spent on this exercise, and this did not include a lot of other expenses from what I could gather. Remember that the Government has modelled the superannuation policies of the Fightback package up to 1995-96. The same Dr Preston, when before the Senate Select Committee on superannuation, was asked whether the Government's policies on occupational superannuation had been modelled to the year 1995-96—this major new initiative by the Government, which people in business around Australia are complaining vigorously about, principally because it is going to create even more unemployment than we have at the moment—and he answered no. Why? He said it was a matter of cost; it was a matter of priorities.

In other words, the Treasury rightly pointed out that it does not have unlimited resources; it cannot do work on every particular aspect which comes before it. Apparently it can find the money to model the superannuation policies of the Opposition, but it cannot find the money to model its own superannuation policies. It is an extraordinary thing to find that the resources of the taxpayer, which are principally designed to fund government departments to help governments develop their policies, are being spent for political purposes on attacking the Opposition. But when we ask whether the Government has been prepared to subject its own policies to the same analysis by the same Department, the answer is no, the Department has not been able to give that a sufficient priority.I think, therefore, that establishes that this unit really should not have been established. Clearly, the Department did not have the money to divert to this particular area.

There was also, of course, the vital issue of principle: just how far government departments should go in the analysis of their political opponents' policies and whether, in fact, it is proper by any measure for a government to establish such a unit when one looks at the way this unit was established and the reason for its establishment. The fact is that the Treasury did not have sufficient resources, apparently, to do the work on the Government's own policies. From my conversations with Treasury officers, I gathered that a number of them were clearly unhappy with the establishment of this particular unit.

So, in my view, the first mistake made was to establish the unit. It is not clear that the Secretary, Mr Tony Cole, expressed any great concern to the Government at having been asked to establish it. I agree that there is an issue. If the Government demands that a unit be set up, it puts the particular officers in a difficult position when they know that the unit is going to be used for political purposes.Why should not the Government be up front and establish the unit in Senator Richardson's office? It seemed to be a political unit. Frankly, a number of the officers who were employed in this unit clearly have worked with the Government before and would have been quite happy to work out of Senator Richardson's office, then we would have seen exactly what this grubby exercise was all about. But no, the Government tried to cloak it with the authority and the independence of the Treasury.

The second mistake to be made was with the personnel appointed to the Committee. I would like to read a fairly lengthy quote to the Senate that was prepared by a former Secretary of the Treasury, Mr John Stone, on this very issue. He wrote in the Financial Review, on 12 March 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: The standards of behaviour of the Commonwealth Public Service, and particularly of key departments such as the Treasury, are much more important to the future of good governance of Australia than the standards of behaviour of our politicians—from either side—or of the ABC.

PARA.TAB: In another sense, however, the choice of Dr Henry was (in my view) unfortunate because he had also spent several of the intervening years working as Private Secretary (Taxation) in Mr Keating's Private Office. He could therefore not unreasonably be seen—and not only by the Opposition—as coming to this new task with his apolitical public service credentials inevitably impaired . . . This error of judgment by the Treasury Executive was, in my view, compounded by the fact that at least two other Treasury officers involved in the new modelling work had also served for periods of time within Mr Keating's Private Office during his time as Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, Mr Stone was referring to Mr Smith and Ms Furnell.

PARA.TAB: The make-up of the personnel of such a unit is important, especially in a highly charged political atmosphere. It was the second mistake for the Secretary of the Treasury not to use his judgment to ensure that, if he decided to follow the Government's instructions to establish such a unit, it was staffed in a way which would at least ensure that the public perception of the unit and its work could be less clouded than it is because of the fact that a number of key appointments to the unit clearly had very close associations with the former Treasurer and the now Prime Minister, Mr Keating.
The third mistake happened during the working of this unit. Clearly, records were not kept. Dr Preston stated on a number of occasions in evidence before the Estimates Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: They—
the Treasurer's office—
did not tell us how to do the analysis.

The Government stated that it had no direct input into having an influence on the analysis of the Fightback document. But, as Dr Preston's answer admits, many `instructions' were given. In evidence before the Committee, it was established that the Treasurer's office was in constant communication with the unit. Dr Preston said:
I do not know how many instructions we have had. We had a discussion about that earlier this morning. We have no way of keeping track of the number of instructions.
He concluded:
We had no instruction on how to do the analysis.

I have to make a number of comments on that. Knowing the political sensitivities of this issue and knowing the habit of the Public Service to keep notes of conversations with Ministers' offices—one day Senator Richardson may rue the fact that public servants keep notes of conversations with Ministers' offices—one would have thought that the experienced public servants involved would have kept a record of the conversations that they had had and the instructions that they had been given by the Treasurer's office. Indeed, I have checked again with public servants and I understand that many public servants adopt that practice, particularly in these highly charged political areas. Apparently, that was not the case in the work of the unit which had been established to attack the Fightback policies. In this sense, I believe that Dr Preston, having been in charge of the operational aspects of the unit, should have exercised more supervision and care.

PARA.TAB: We can all understand that the Treasury did the number crunching—no-one is arguing that. But the Government fed in the assumptions that made sure that the result of the analysis, to the extent that it could, would be unfavourable. Of course, the Government then wanted to pass off this biased result as a Treasury analysis.

This leads me to the next error that I believe Treasury made, and this was in the critical choice of the inflation assumption. My colleague Senator Short, in fairly extensive questioning before Estimates Committee B of Senator McMullan, Dr Preston and Mr Fraser, went very carefully through this particular exercise. Anyone who wants to pursue this at some length should take the trouble to read that particular evidence given to Estimates Committee B. Senator Short pointed to the critical fact that an inflation figure of 7 per cent was used. He asked Dr Preston why he used an inflation figure contained in a scenario which the document quite specifically said was not part of the Fightback modelling.

During the modelling carried out by the Treasury unit, there was an inflation assumption of 7 per cent and a wages growth of 3.5 per cent. As Senator Short pointed out, it was ludicrous for Treasury to have used an inflation figure of 7 per cent with a 3.5 per cent real wages growth figure when analysing the consequences of the Fightback package for the simple reason that this implies a very substantial fall in real wages.

It is interesting to note that when Senator Short asked the Deputy Secretary, John Fraser, about this particular assumption he agreed that the key assumption used by Treasury to analyse the Fightback package was unrealistic. Therefore, the second most senior Treasury officer disagrees—and this is important—with the assumptions developed by Dr Henry and his colleagues in the unit. That is a pretty important story but, let us face it, I doubt whether one will see that on the Four Corners program. Nonetheless, it shows that the claims by the Prime Minister and by the Treasurer that 70 per cent of wage and salary earners would be worse off under the Fightback package are wrong.

Again, as I mentioned at the commencement of my remarks, some documents that were released under freedom of information last night make it pretty clear that those wild, foolish and silly claims made by the Prime Minister are undermined by other work that Treasury had done which were released very late in the piece indeed. So that was the fourth mistake that was made. The unit failed in its efforts to produce assumptions to analyse the document which were soundly based, based at least on the document itself, and could also be sustained by their internal coherence with other assumptions that were made. Not only has this analysis been condemned more widely but also it is interesting to see that Treasury itself regards the assumptions which were made to analyse the Fightback package as very flawed indeed.

It does not require a PhD in econometrics or some $300,000 of taxpayers' money to work out that if one assumes a high inflation rate and, as a result, one creates bracket creep and then refuses to give the windfall gains back to the taxpayer everyone will be worse off. So Treasury, by following the instructions of the Treasurer's office, by ceaselessly feeding these in and doing the number crunching for the Government, was able to produce a piece of paper at least which clearly excited the interests of Four Corners and the press. But, as we saw last night in the papers released under the freedom of information and the comments made before Estimates B by Mr John Fraser, the key assumptions used in the analysis of the Fightback package were fatally flawed.

This brings me to the fifth mistake that I believe the Treasury made. Once the documents were in the public domain, it was clear from the Four Corners program—the program which got all the press coverage—that these papers were being represented as Treasury papers. The interesting thing is that I asked Dr Preston in Estimates Committee B:

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr, Preston, are you worried when leaks occur from the Treasury?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Preston correctly said:
Dr Preston—As any good manager would be, yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a leak of Treasury material to Four Corners on the ABC. Were you worried about that leak?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Preston—No, because it was not a leak of Treasury material.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document was described on Four Corners as Treasury material.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Preston—It may have been described as such but I knew that it was not.

So this great big beat-up that we had on Four Corners based on Treasury documents was repudiated in Estimates B by Treasury officers. They said that they were not Treasury documents. The documents were prepared in the Treasurer's office. Had that been known on the night, that would have substantially undermined the general thrust of that Four Corners program.

PARA.TAB: It thus raises the issue that Treasury's name is being used for political purposes. The Treasury should have put out a press release the following day, after it had seen the documents, indicating that they were not Treasury documents. As I said at the start of my remarks, it was important to clothe the Government attack in the independence and authority of the Treasury. It is a discussion I have had with Treasury officers. The views are a bit mixed. Some find that it certainly would be awkward for the Treasury to put out a press release saying, `Hey, your big story last night was all wrong; it wasn't a Treasury document'.

Senator MacGibbon has a far longer experience in this place than myself. I do not know about him, but it is certainly my memory that, from time to time when fraudulent documents are produced in the public arena which are claimed to be departmental documents, governments and departments in the past have made it very clear that they are fraudulent documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —A government of honour has.

—I thank Senator MacGibbon; we do not expect the Government to act in an honourable way. The point of my remarks is whether Treasury should have acted in an honourable way and declared the documents fraudulent. It is a difficult issue. Certainly, given the nature of the supposed leak and the public excitement that it occasioned, it would have been interesting to see whether it was ever considered in Treasury—a Treasury determined to maintain its independence and integrity—that it should have put out a statement saying that the Four Corners documents were not Treasury documents. That would have been a big story indeed. It certainly would have been a visible sign to the Government that it cannot misuse the authority and independence of the great state Department of the Treasury.

PARA.TAB: In my remarks I have listed five errors of judgment which I believe Treasury officers have made. Treasury officers tell me that Dr Preston is regarded as a decent and honest man. We have to say that, on the basis of what has been said—and Dr Preston has had the operational responsibilities for this unit—Dr Preston has clearly lacked judgment in the way that he allowed this whole exercise to be developed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the Appropriation Bills before the Senate this morning to talk about the Civil Aviation Authority. Aviation is very important to this country. One of our great difficulties is that the general public does not understand how the system is regulated by the regulatory authority—how it works, what it does and what place it has in the scheme of things. The average taxpayer gets onto a nice, clean, well presented airliner, flies with safety and, on most occasions, at the appointed time gets to where he or she wants to go; he or she thinks everything is going very well. The average taxpayer does not understand the process that brings all that about.

PARA.TAB: That process is different from the way other departments of state or statutory authorities operate. It is quite different to the way the welfare system works—the old age pension, for example—under the Department Social Security; the Australian Taxation Office, which Senator Kemp was talking about a few minutes ago; and the Treasury. It is different. It has its own legislative base. It has its own terminology. It has its own practices which have grown up over roughly the last 90 years.

One of the great difficulties in getting debate going in the Parliament and, therefore, hearing any informed comment on aviation in the Parliament, is that parliamentarians do not know very much about the aviation industry either, although they are very big users of it, spending a large part of their lives travelling in aeroplanes around this country. It is an important industry and it is important that we understand what is going on.

In Australia we had a dedicated department of state—the old Department of Civil Aviation—which existed for many years and regulated and controlled aviation in this country.
