It was a very good department. It had a lot of outstanding people. It had some outstanding men as its Director. It was staffed by people who understood the industry, who understood what they were meant to be doing and how to apply their knowledge for the benefit of the Australian community.

Then we had the reforming zeal of that great zealot Mr Whitlam, who came along nearly 20 years ago and got rid of the Department of Civil Aviation saying, `Aviation is just another form of transport. It is no different from running trains or ships. We will have a Department of Transport—a mega-department—and we will all be super-efficient and move into the modern age'. Since the advent of the Whitlam years there have been a number of major changes in the naming of the Department of Aviation. It has been called the Department of Transport, the Department of Aviation—a whole lot of things—and that has had a most significant effect on its efficiency and morale.

Finally, we arrived at the misfortune of having the Hawke Government. The Hawke Government decided that it would no longer persist with the Department of Civil Aviation in whatever guise it was operating and would, in the jargon of the times, get it off-budget. It set up two statutory authorities, namely the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation, to change it.

Whatever the ideals that might have motivated this change, the fact of the matter is that the move has been a disaster for the Australian community. I doubt very much whether the situation can be retrieved. I think a very good argument could be made—and I am personally persuaded to this view—for going back to having a department of state under the control of the Minister and seeing whether we can resurrect the regulatory system in an efficient and effective way for the benefit of the community.

Essentially, the Government has said, `We have to get this off-budget. We will make the authorities self-sufficient and it won't cost the taxpayers anything'. In doing that the Government sold all the assets which were owned by the Australian taxpayer—the airfields, the air traffic control facilities, all the infrastructure of aviation in Australia—to these two authorities, the CAA and the FAC, at grossly inflated contemporary prices. It then told the two authorities, `You pay us a dividend on the money—the thousands of millions of dollars—you have invested'. It was grossly dishonest to sell something that was owned by the Australian taxpayers to an authority, and to then tell that authority to make a profit on those inflated sales.

The exercise turns on two other fashionable beliefs—the belief of cost recovery and the belief that the user pays. To some degree those two beliefs are intertwined. The concepts are self supporting in a way because the Government is saying that under the cost recovery doctrine the aviation industry will pay for the regulatory system, while with the user-pays concept it is saying that those who use the aviation facilities will also pay.

Cost recovery is perhaps practical if we can define the use and if the cost can be recovered from those who are making use of the facility. But in the case of aviation it is not the person who is flying from Sydney to Melbourne this morning who is the exclusive user of the airways system. The whole community gets the benefit. Efficient transport is essential to Australia; it is as essential as a good public health system and a good educational system, and we have all the indirect benefits that flow from it.

We try to make a great deal of money out of tourism. Tourism in this country cannot exist without an aviation industry to bring people into Australia and to fly them around the country when they get in. The tourism industry provides a great boost for the building industry; look at all the five-star hotels that have been built in your State, Madam Acting Deputy President. We have seen hundreds, if not billions, of dollars invested in hardware to support the tourist industry. Think of the employment that the tourist industry brings to Australia—the tens of thousands of people who are now providing services, such as catering services. Those people owe part or all of their employment to the aviation industry.So there is definitely a public interest component in this area. I do not believe any thinking senator would deny that.

The difficulty comes in ascribing a proportion to the public interest component in the overall costs. I could come up with only a rough estimate that probably the public interest component is around 25 to 40 per cent. I am open to negotiation on that. But it cannot be denied that this public interest component exists. If we concede that there is a public interest component, the doctrine of cost recovery solely from the users of the aviation industry is untenable.

The user pays system sets out to recover from the citizen using the airways the hundreds of millions of dollars involved in the regulatory function. This taxing base is a very small base. If that is going to happen, the citizen who is travelling on the aircraft from Sydney to Melbourne this morning who is paying as a user for those air services is quite entitled to expect that the Government will reduce his personal income tax and the other indirect taxes to compensate for it. Unless that is done, the Government is double dipping; it is getting in twice. The Government is maintaining taxation at the same level—probably this Government is sneaking it up all the time—yet it is getting one of its expenses off budget, namely, the provision of aviation services.

The other great difficulty with the user pays concept is that the user simply has no right to say no; there is no power of veto. The consultative system set up under this Government for the clients of the CAA—the aircraft owners, the pilots, and the users of the aviation industry—are ineffectual.

At the end of the day, the CAA always gets what it wants; there is no right of veto. It is very similar to going into a restaurant for a hamburger and a cup of coffee and being billed at the end of that cup of coffee for a five-course meal with an extensive wine bill. We just have to pay, just as we do not have any say at all in what the Authority provides. The Authority always provides a gold-plated service, way beyond what people in the general aviation sector—at the private, recreational and charter level—require.

Since the Authority has been in operation, it has reduced the number of staff to about 65 per cent of the number of staff that existed beforehand. There have been huge redundancy payments for those members of staff who have been made to take premature retirement. It has also paid huge salary increases to the remaining staff, compared with what it was paying when it was a department of state.

The big difficulty that one encounters is the lack of accountability. We cannot get the Department before the Parliament very readily to explain what it is doing. It is an absolute fundamental of our democracy that we have the right to get statutory authorities and departments of State to explain what they are doing and how they are expending public funds. We should remember that the money raised by taxation or levies by the Civil Aviation Authority is public funds; it is not a private funding of the CAA, as the present Chief Executive Officer seems to think it is and that therefore he does not have to account for it. He certainly does have to account for what he is doing.

We have seen a number of cases of abuse of authority by the Civil Aviation Authority. In my experience, the number of abuses are significantly higher than they were when the process was operating through a department of state. We know about the shabby history of the CAA which has put liens on aircraft owned by people who did not pay their bills. On a number of occasions in taking this action the Authority has operated outside the law. It frankly admits that it breached the law. It then says to the poor client, `If you don't like it, see us in court'.

When the matter reaches the court, it is often the case that a lot of the clients who have been disadvantaged in this way and who have had liens placed on their aircraft simply cannot pay the legal bills. One person in such a position in my own State of Queensland told me that although his case would have been supported in court, he was required to deposit $40,000 as surety for the legal fees or court expenses before he could get into the court. He said, `Frankly, I haven't got anywhere near that sort of money'. Therefore, to a large extent the CAA operates with impunity.

The principal difficulty with the Authority flows from its rapacious desire to tax the industry under this cost recovery doctrine. One of the things that is coming up in the near future is a safety regulatory levy which will be applied to all certificate of registration holders on the Australian register. In essence, that is all those people who own aircraft in the country.

The interesting thing about this is that in 1984 an inquiry known as the Bosch inquiry was set up to look into the whole business of financing aviation in this country. Amongst other things, it recommended that the Government should clean up the inefficiencies over an 8-years to 10-years period in the regulation of the Australian aviation industry. When that was done, it was felt that those concerned should be close to attaining cost recovery. The inquiry indicated that cost recovery would be comparable with the old air navigation charge, which was a charge on the registration of each aircraft. It made specific reference to the regulatory function of the Authority. The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the setting of standards is more a policy function and that enforcement of the standards, as a policing function, has a large degree of public benefit in it.
Further:

. . . if the industry were required to pay those costs, there would be increased pressure to reduce the level of enforcement of standards. This could result in the level of compliance declining to an unacceptable degree.

In other words, it was saying that one cannot expect the industry to pay for its own policing. It is in the public interest that standards are maintained and therefore the public should bear the cost of it.

PARA.TAB: When the report was presented to Parliament, the Minister of the day, Minister Morris, gave an unequivocal assurance in the House of Representatives that the Government accepted all the recommendations. The cost recovery program went so well so rapidly that a short while ago the Government said, `We will get this money back from the safety regulatory function. We will charge the industry for it'. The 8,500 certificate of registration holders in this country will have to meet the bill. In the first instance the current cost is about $75m. It will impose a levy on aircraft owners in the next financial year which will start at a level of about $250 for the smallest and lightest aircraft and go up quite substantially. It will be doubled next year and trebled the year after that. This is in total defiance of its stated acceptance of the recommendations of the Bosch inquiry whose report was presented about six or seven years ago.

This has produced an enormous reaction in the industry. The industry is on its knees. It simply cannot afford a levy like that. We are not talking about $250 for all aircraft. We are talking about that as the lowest level. Commercial operators, people who are running charter airlines or flying training organisations, simply cannot afford it. The Government should not be under any illusion as to the reaction in the aviation community to this.

The principal body in Australia, the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association of Australia, has made an emphatic statement advising all of its members not to pay the levy. Yesterday the Sydney Morning Herald contained an article entitled `11,000 air operators may boycott tax'. This very strongly written article, which takes up four columns, goes through the business of how the industry `is furious about being blatantly ripped off by the Government'. The industry cannot afford to be subject to these sorts of irrational moves.

The basic point, of course, is that the general aviation sector, on which this levy will fall most heavily, simply does not need the CAA. We have reached the stage where that sector of the industry is well able to regulate its own activities. We simply do not need the huge impositions that are being placed on us by this bureaucracy.

The Civil Aviation Authority has the gall to claim that 45 per cent of the total amount that will be recovered by way of the safety regulatory levy will come from the airline industry. The airline industry is the reason why the Civil Aviation Authority exists. The industry is its principal customer. If there is any fairness at all, the airline industry should be paying about 98 per cent of the levy, not 45 per cent.

But it goes further than that. It goes to the certificate of approval holders—the people who are licensed to perform maintenance all around Australia. Proposals are around that they will pay somewhere between $10,000 and $20,000 a year just to have a workshop. Last week I rang up the financial section of the Civil Aviation Authority. I said, `Look, I am being besieged with calls about your charging practices. Where are we going on this? What is your basis for it?'. To my surprise, the senior officer told me, `Oh, well, we are going to put a levy on those maintenance people because they are not paying any tax at the moment'. I said, `That is astonishing. Do you mean to say that if someone in the industry is not paying tax, he has to be taxed?'. He said, `Oh yes, that is right'. This really is a bizarre way to handle the commercial world. Quite simply, the GA area cannot pay this levy. In my view, it is not going to pay the levy and I think we are in for an enormous fight.

In the 10 minutes left to me I would like to refer to a particular example of the performance of the Civil Aviation Authority. In evidence given before a committee of this Parliament, officers of the CAA have admitted to wasting hundreds of millions of dollars on programs in the last few years. One of the classic examples of that is its ventures into the acquisition of radars. Everything that this Authority has touched in the last few years has been an utter disaster.

The ATCARDS system, in respect of which the Authority gave a contract to Thomson radar to provide the radars for Perth, Adelaide and Melbourne, was a disaster. The Government and the CAA claim that the way in which the contract was awarded, with subcontractors nominated and Thomson not having total control, led to inefficiencies. In fact, there is some truth in that—it did lead to part of the problem. But the major part of the problem comes from the professional inadequacies of Thomson-CSF as a radar supplier.

Everyone in Australia would know of the difficulties that we have had with the Melbourne radar traffic control system. It was never fixed by Thomson; it was fixed by the Civil Aviation Authority itself at further expense, over the contract price, by $5.5m of taxpayers' funds.

We now have the RASPP program going—Cairns, Coolangatta, Gellibrand, Mount Macedon. On this occasion Thomson-CSF, the great favourite, the white-haired son of the CAA, again got the contract. It had total control of this contract from start to finish. Again, it is a disaster.

Many times in the Senate we have talked about the mechanical problems in Cairns and massive software problems when aircraft disappear. We have had the fatuous explanation from the Minister that it is because of a transponder fault in the aircraft. That is absolute nonsense. It is not only the secondary surveillance radar that is playing up; the software program will not recognise aircraft in certain circumstances. It is a software fault. It is not a transmitting fault in the aircraft itself. Of course, the Cairns program was something like 20 months over time on completion.

Now we come to the Australian air traffic control system which is a massive thing. My concern with that initially was the fact that the CAA arbitrarily decided that there would be no Australian participation. Having been with this program since it started—and it has been running for nearly 12 months now—I am appalled at the way the CAA has taken us back nearly 30 years in accountability with respect to tendering processes.

It might be very well for Mr Baldwin, who was a real estate salesman in New Zealand before he came to Australia, to operate on a one-on-one basis and work out contracts as he goes along, but Australia got away from that 30 years ago. The difficulty that he is in at the present time is that he is not prepared to account for what he has done, largely on his own, with respect to this new contract. He is not prepared at all to follow accepted procedures which provide the transparency in the decision process which enables taxpayers in Australia to know that their money has been properly spent. That is a very serious situation.

The way the CAA went about this was quite surprising. Instead of following the accepted tender procedures laid down by the Department of Administrative Services, it called for a request for information. It contacted six companies only and asked them to submit proposals for a radar system. It eliminated three quite rapidly. The three that were eliminated were Siemens Plessey, Selenia and Raytheon. That left IBM, Thomson and Hughes in the field.

The CAA eliminated Siemens Plessey, which was the cheapest and probably the most technologically advanced in the field, on the grounds that its air traffic control database system was based on an unproven system; namely, the McDonnell Detweiler software program which is being used in Canada by Hughes. It made no comment to Siemens, before eliminating it, that the program was too high a risk in its judgment. Had it made that comment, Siemens Plessey had off-the-shelf, cheaper software programs which would have fulfilled the requirement in that part of the contract.

Because Siemens Plessey was one of the formidable players in the tender, it was eliminated first. That left IBM. The Department told IBM that it was operationally unacceptable, yet begged it to stay in with Thomson and Hughes. To those of us who are interested in this matter, it was never any secret that Thomson from day 1 was the preferred candidate of the CAA. A most elaborate selection system was set up with 25 representatives from the air traffic controllers, 25 technical and engineering people, in five different committees looking at all aspects of the radar selection. I am glad Senator Button is in here because one of those aspects was Australian industry participation. All the recommendations from these committees favoured Hughes above Thomson on technological advancement, reliability, Australian industry content and cost—on every parameter possible.

But the operation of the CAA was very hard to follow. It allowed people to make other bids and recently in the papers—I have not yet read the Hansard of it but I think it was at the Public Works Committee hearing—the claims were made that some of the commercially sensitive information was passed to Thomson so that Thomson was in the position that apparently enabled it to revise its bids constantly through the selection program. Clearly, the CAA moved the goal posts as the selection process took place. People who did not agree with the direction that the CAA wanted to take were fired. Of course, it is a matter of public record that the air traffic controllers, the civil air operators, pulled out of the negotiations on the stated grounds of a lack of fairness. That is something to think about—what do those words `lack of fairness' actually mean in the selection process?

Of course, it is a matter of record that when the proposition was put forward by the CAA to the board of CAA that Thomson be the preferred tenderer, the board was very divided and it was not possible to come to a decision. Then, apparently, the Chief Executive Officer, Mr Baldwin, put on an emotional presentation on the virtues of Thomson and threatened to resign on the spot unless Thomson's bid was accepted by the board. So it came to pass that Thomson became the preferred tenderer.

It got to this position purely on a request for information. There was no formal tender proposal, there were no hard and fast specifications defined. The Australian public is faced with the position now that the CAA is sitting down with a preferred tenderer to write an extraordinarily complex tender document with a lot of money tied up in it, under pressure from Thomson saying, `If you do not agree to what we do, your air traffic control system in Sydney and in Brisbane is going to fall over and there are going to be enormous political consequences'.

We do not know what the final cost will be; we do not know what the specifications are going to be. It is a quite extraordinary procedure for a country with the standards of public accountability of Australia to be in. I have been involved in this Parliament for quite a number of years now. I have a great interest in defence and I have followed defence contracting very closely. We are talking about a civil aviation contract of somewhere around $150m to $200m. In defence contracts, things like the Collins class submarines, the Anzac ships, you are looking at a magnitude beyond that; you are looking at $2.5 billion, $3.5 billion or $4.5 billion—many times the size of this. In the tendering processes that I have been associated with or have observed, I have seen intense competition in defence. There are very big prizes of the order of billions of dollars to the successful tenderer. I have never in my life heard a word of criticism about the integrity of the selection process in defence.

In this contract of the Civil Aviation Authority, I have to say that the industry is rife with rumours questioning the integrity of the CAA in the selection process. I do not know whether they are true or false, but it is my intention to use this Parliament to bring the CAA to account for this. It has an obligation to the Australian community to prove those rumours either true or false, because there is expenditure there of some hundreds of millions of dollars.

If we look at the technical capabilities of the preferred tenderer, Thomson-CSF, we see a history of failure in performance, not only in Australia but all around the world. We see this doubt as to how the selection committee ever came to the decision it did in the face of contrary advice from all its technical committees. There are so many questions to this that have to be answered.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, in speaking to this Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, I formally move the amendment standing in my name, which has been duly circulated. I move:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate regrets the Government's failure to take advantage of the opportunity provided by this Bill to introduce more extensive changes to customs and excise legislation, including:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)abolishing the excise duty on fuel, including diesel fuel; and
(b)reducing other customs and excise and similar taxation burdens on business by adopting proposals such as those contained in the Coalition's `Fightback' program".

I refer to the nature of the Bill first. This is a Bill which has three parts to it: first, the electronic lodgment of information concerning imported goods; secondly, the system dealing with advance arrival reporting; and thirdly, the diesel fuel rebate scheme. To address the question of electronic lodgment, this Bill has, in fact, been referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology to be dealt with as a consideration of the Bill, and to report back. I would suggest that the electronic lodgment process, and the way it is arrived at, would be one of the things that would be looked at by that Committee.

PARA.TAB: The Bill proposes to amend the Customs Act by providing the legislative framework for the electronic transmission by the Australian Customs Service of information concerning imported goods; and secondly, the electronic lodgment of import entries with respect to those goods. The proposed amendments are similar to those supported by the coalition in 1990, which created the exit system. Indeed, the electronic import lodgment scheme to be introduced is designed to complement that existing system.

One of the problems is the way in which this has been done. I understand the Bill was available in draft form at the end of last year but, more particularly, the scheme was actually introduced prior to the legislation being introduced. It became effective in September last year, and it became effective by way of an agreement that was entered into between agents and the Australian Customs Service. In the Estimates hearings, we heard some evidence of coercion to the signing of those agreements. Mr Miller, an in-house lawyer with the Customs Service, admitted that it was a document—that is, the agreement document—that was biased in favour of the Customs Service because, to put it in his terms, he said, `The Customs Service was the client'.

The point is that this legislation provides the legislative base that will really authorise the Australian Customs Service to enter into a subsequent agreement, and it is to be hoped that there will be more consultation, and a better feeling of fairness about the entering into of the fresh agreement. It is quite important to put on the record that we still have not got an adequate answer, firstly as to why the legislation, being in draft form in December, was not made available more widely to the industry for consultation, and, secondly, why the scheme was implemented in September prior to the legislation being put in place, and why there was such a long delay between the implementation of the scheme and the introduction of the legislation.

It has been suggested that one of those reasons could be that the relevant Minister, the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, Mr Beddall, in fact made an undertaking to certain parts of the industry that the scheme would be up and running by September, and the Customs Service simply went out to find a way and a means of implementing the system without legislative authority. It is a dangerous precedent to set, and it is one that should be noted by the Senate, and something that we would hope would not recur.

The second part of the Bill deals with advance arrival reporting. Again, it is an amendment to the Customs Act 1901 and it relates to the advance reporting regime for ships and aircraft, their passengers, cargo and crew. The proposals are along the lines of amendments passed by the Parliament, again in 1990, and are designed to enhance the existing advance reporting provisions. At present aircraft and ships are required to provide the Customs Service with a report giving details of the cargo on board, the number and names of crew, and the number of passengers being carried. The screening and risk assessment of this information and subsequent action are among the key methods by which the Australian Customs Service meets its community protection obligations, particularly in regard to the importation of narcotics.

Amendments to the legislation in 1990 provided for the prescribed information to be reported via computer prior to the arrival of the aircraft or ship at the first port of call. Reports containing similar information continue to be conveyed by hand to Customs officers upon arrival at the vessel's subsequent ports. The Bill extends the current procedures to provide for the advance reporting of prescribed information at ports of call. The advance reporting system has been successful, in our opinion, in allowing risk management and other checks to be completed before the vessel arrives at the port. A more efficient system of processing crew, the early identification and better targeting of risk and the early availability of cargo have been key factors in the Australian Customs Service decision to extend the advance reporting mechanism to all ports of call for an aircraft or a ship.

The third part of the Bill relates to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. It is here that I think it is important to point out that this is again only a bandaid measure introduced by the Government. The detailed policies outlined in our Fightback package, which are going to give so much more benefit to Australian industry in the ability to create jobs, provide the better way to proceed. Certainly we will not be opposing the bandaid measures that the Government is introducing but we take the opportunity to point out that our Fightback package is so much better and indeed offers many more opportunities.

If one looks at this country as a whole, one could say it has been penalised by the tyranny of distance, to borrow Geoffrey Blainey's phrase, yet it is in this area that the Government has imposed a tax upon the means of transporting goods and services across Australia—namely, on fuel. Clearly, by abolishing the fuel excise on all petroleum products, including diesel, we will see a huge benefit to the Australian population. In our Fightback package we outlined the seven taxes which we will abolish. Those seven taxes include not only the fuel excise tax but tariff tax.

Long since have I abolished the word `protection' from my lexicon. It is a warm, fuzzy word that somehow says we are supposed to be doing something warm and nice. In fact, it is a tax like any other tax, which is simply designed to penalise one group of people by taxing them and to take that money and pay it to another group of people because the Government believes that they are somehow special. Then it has to explain to the rest of the people in Australia why they are not quite so special and they do not get those advantages.

The much better way is to have fair access to all the resources in Australia, both capital and human, being competed for fairly by all industry. That is the philosophy behind our policy to abolish tariff tax, in the sense that it will be reduced to negligible levels of 0 to 5 per cent. That will be done hand in hand with the abolition of the other costs that are imposed upon business. We will be abolishing $20 billion worth of taxes all-up. That will make business much more able to compete, particularly in the export line. At the moment we are held back because of the gross taxing on inputs that is currently the state of the Government's policy.

So although we do not oppose this Bill—indeed, it has been referred to the Friday committee for consideration—we will move the amendment that I outlined at the beginning of my presentation, which simply says to the Government, `Your policies are lacking; they are simply not good enough. The sooner we can have an election and see the implementation of the Fightback package, the better this country will be'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is debating the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. The Bill proposes amendments in three areas: first, to facilitate the electronic lodgment of import documentation; secondly, to broaden the advance reporting regime for imported cargo; and, thirdly, to alter the administration of the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

PARA.TAB: The first matter is to place in the principal Act the provisions which relate to the option of electronically lodging import entries with Customs. I think the term `option' is important, because Customs agents acting for importers have the option to use it or not. This COMPILE system is currently operating under regulation and is simply being put into primary legislation. A principal or agent wishing to import goods utilising the more efficient electronic lodgment system has to sign a user agreement governing the operation of the electronic system. The user simply fills in the requisite electronic documentation, then electronically lodges this with Customs.

A similar system which deals with exports, the so-called EXIT system, was supported by the Democrats in 1990. The new COMPILE system reduces the cost of lodging import entries and reduces normal clearance times from four hours to a few minutes and, on that point alone, is surely to be commended. The administration costs of Customs are also reduced. This measure is a minor improvement in the efficiency of the transport chain that is a small element of micro-reform and will help in marginally reducing the massive transport costs which are unavoidable in a country as large as ours. They may be unavoidable in substance, but certainly we can push for greater improvements.

I have had representations from a Melbourne customs broker who has some severe difficulties with this system, especially the manner in which Customs has instituted the current user agreements. He has opposed this system on the basis that it imposes unfair burdens on users and it creates potential legal liability in respect of seeking information which is not known to the broker.

The matter was discussed through my office with a Customs official who pointed out that the manual system which preceded the electronic COMPILE system also contained the questions which were objected to and that, if these were not satisfactorily answered, the goods would not be cleared by Customs under the former arrangements. It is clear that to run an effective system of enforcing the prohibition of certain imports, such as weapons, drugs and items subject to quarantine, somebody has to take the legal responsibility for declaring what the cargo is. As such, the Democrats understand that Customs is simply safeguarding the public interest. As I understand it, a new user agreement will be prepared when this Bill passes. I do hope that the dispute between the broker and Customs can then be amicably settled.

The second area concerns the advance reporting regime. Under this system, Customs is notified of goods which will arrive before they enter the country. This system has a dual purpose: it allows the fast clearance of goods which are routine and it allows better assessment of risk in respect of prohibited imports. Currently, the system does not require specification of the actual items to be unloaded at each particular port or airport, nor a report on the passengers and crew of aircraft. The Bill proposes that these now be mandatory, and the Democrats welcome that.

The Customs Brokers Council has made some representations to the Democrats about the optional port lodgment system. In particular, there appears to have been an agreed process under way with the industry, which may now have been circumvented or at least cut short. To examine this matter, the Democrats agree with the reference of the Bill to a legislative committee on Friday to take evidence on that matter.

Clause 12 imposes an obligation on pilots, shipmasters and/or owners of the aircraft or ships to answer questions relating to the craft's cargo, crew, passengers, stores and voyage. This has been highlighted by the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee as containing a reversal of the onus of proof. However, it is hard to see how Customs can operate effectively without the power to require this information. The enhanced information requirements can only assist Customs in its statutory function of the prevention of illegal imports and so, on balance, the Democrats support this provision also.

The final matter in the Bill is a proposal to reform the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The diesel fuel rebate scheme provides refunds of fuel excise or duty paid on diesel fuel purchased for specific off-road uses in mining operations, primary production, residential premises, hospitals, nursing homes and aged people's homes. All excise paid by primary producers is refunded; about 90 per cent is refunded for mining operations and about two-thirds for other uses.

The Bill proposes to introduce new administration arrangements for the scheme involving a self-assessment system—for example, minimal initial checking for rebate claims—and a much increased system of audits to verify subsequently the accuracy of the initial claim. These changes arose from a report by the Auditor-General suggesting them.

The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's second reading amendment. The Democrats believe that the benefits to be gained from abolishing the excise on fossil fuels is misguided because the benefits will be short term. In the long term, ways and means must be found for research on and development of alternative fuels. Simply to provide an incentive for people to use more of our dwindling fossil fuel supplies is a short term view on long term ecological sustainability.

The second part of the resolution proposed by the Opposition amongst other things seeks a further reduction in customs duties. That requires a lot more consideration. The Australian Democrats would like to see a careful assessment of the damage done to Australian industries and Australian jobs before we endorse an across-the-board reduction of customs duties. The Democrats will be supporting the Government's Bill without further amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to participate in the debate on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. I support the move in respect of the excise rebate on diesel fuel by which the Government intends to change the method of application for the rebate. Until now—I think since this Government came to power—excise on diesel fuel has been paid and users have to apply for a rebate with a standard form when they have used a certain quantity or after some time has elapsed. The previous system involved a fuel excise exemption certificate, which was used, I believe, from 1956 or 1957. Then one simply quoted the exemption certificate number and was not charged the diesel fuel excise.

PARA.TAB: This Government changed that system in 1983-84 because it believed that there were too many fuel excise exemptions being claimed that were not correct or legal to claim. When claiming under the present system, a claim form accompanied by invoices is sent to the Collector of Customs and then there is a wait of three or four or five weeks—the Government seems to be going for money in the coffers when it sends the rebate. I believe the old system was quite a sloppy system, if I can use that term, by which to apply because it meant a lot of unnecessary paperwork.

With modern accounting practices, fuel companies and others do not issue too much in the way of paperwork. They issue just a single invoice, which has to be sent with the application for a fuel rebate, collectively, with all the other invoices. It is up to the applicant to calculate what fuel was used on public roads and what was used off roads, whether on a farm or a mine or whatever.

Under the proposed new system, as I understand it, one simply fills in a claim form and then one is subject to an audit if the Customs department sees fit to do so. People keep their own invoices and supporting documents in a file. Of course, people were subject to audits previously. It seemed to be the custom that a representative of the fuel excise section would arrive on the place at least once every 12 months or so to go through invoices, purchases and what have you. The auditor also asked about any change of circumstances or any extra vehicles using diesel that may have been on public roads. To my knowledge, that practice has diminished or disappeared altogether in the last three or four years, unless the department thinks my company is doing the right thing. I do not know whether that is the fact or whether the inspectors were taken off the road on that.

I believe that the system of simply applying and keeping your own records will be far more efficient. Under the other system, one had to send the invoices away to support the claim but they were never sent back. If claims were lost one had to get a certified copy and that used to create problems. The best idea was to keep photocopies of the originals that were sent in, but those photocopies were not necessarily certified. I believe that the system proposed by the amendment in this Bill is a move in the right direction. It will cut down a lot of unnecessary paperwork. Whether we like it or not, substantiation is with us now for taxation as well as other areas.

As a practical user of diesel fuel in off-road situations, I welcome the measure because I believe it will be far more efficient. If an invoice is missing at the end of the month, there is no need to run around looking for it. One can apply for it in good time while waiting for an audit. The suppliers, as I have said before, have a tendency to give out only one invoice which gets left somewhere and cannot be found when the fuel is delivered. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. —I am very happy to explain the circumstances of that particular conversation. It was not a matter of Senator Richardson `clearing' anything with me. The language that he used in his press statement, just for the record, was `after checking with. . . ' me `to ensure that. . . ' he `was not acting improperly'. That was the context in which Senator Richardson raised the matter with me.

PARA.TAB: According to my recollection, he rang me on Friday, 3 April and explained the situation in which his relative by marriage found himself in the Marshall Islands. He told me that he had been asked by the lawyer for Mr Symons to ring the President of the Marshall Islands and ask that Mr Symons's passport not be withheld, not to ask for the charges against him to be dropped.

Against that background Senator Richardson asked me whether there was any Foreign Affairs protocol type reason why he should not do this and whether there was any precedent for this sort of situation. My reply was as follows: this was a very unusual situation which I had not previously encountered, and I was unaware of any precedent; but, bearing in mind the highly personalised character of politics and administration in small island countries, it was less odd than it would be elsewhere to contact the President directly. I interpolate at this point that the Marshall Islands is a very small island country of some 40,000 people.

I went on to say that, if all that Senator Richardson was proposing to ask was that Mr Symons's passport not be withheld so that he could prepare his defence, it seemed to me to be okay to make a representation seeking, in effect, the exercise of an executive or prosecutorial discretion on this kind of matter. I went on to say that it would be a much more sensitive matter to go in any way into the merits of the case: I understood that Senator Richardson himself had no intention of making any suggestion that the charges be dropped and I thought that was wise. I said finally that I did not see any objection in principle to his making the call, as long as he did not hold himself out in doing so to be acting on behalf of the Australian Government, which again I understood that he had no intention of doing.
Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston can ask a question later if he wishes.

—I have a supplementary question. Is there not an obvious risk in contacting the head of state of a small island state that he may well interpret that as an attempt by a senior Minister of the Australian Government to interfere in the judicial process of his island state?

—Senator Richardson made it perfectly clear, as he said in his statement, that he was making a call not in any capacity as a Minister representing or purporting to represent the Government, and he was quite explicit and articulate about that. Moreover, the question in issue was whether the executive, the prosecution, would ask for or continue to ask for the passport to be withheld, rather than any question going to the merits of the case as determined by the court itself. Under those circumstances, although the situation was an unusual one, in the context which I have described, I thought it was not improper for the approach to be made.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's assessment of the significance of the replacement of the Chairman of the Burmese State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC), Senior General Saw Maung, by General Than Shwe? In particular, what is the significance of the reported decisions by the Burmese Government to release some political prisoners and take other measures in the human rights area, including the possibility of allowing Daw Aung San Suu Kyi to meet again with her husband and children?

—As Senator Schacht has intimated and as honourable senators will know, late last week General Than Shwe was appointed Chairman of the SLORC and, in doing so, replaced General Saw Maung who was, according to the Burmese authorities, stepping down `temporarily' due to health reasons. Saw Maung is, in fact, known to have been ill for an extended period. General Than Shwe, the new head of SLORC, has been influential in the Burmese regime for some time. He was recently appointed Minister for Defence. As he is a protege of Ne Win, who is widely believed to be still the dominant force in Burmese politics, it does seem unlikely that there will be any major policy changes in Burma in the foreseeable future.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, since the appointment the Burmese authorities have made several announcements indicating some degree of political liberalisation. These are decisions, first of all, to release a total of 27 political prisoners, including the former Prime Minister, U Nu, with other releases to follow; secondly, a decision that the State Law and Order Restoration Council is to meet with representatives of the remaining political parties within two months and to convene the national convention within six months; and, thirdly, as Senator Schacht said, to permit Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's family to visit her in Rangoon where she is being detained.

The Australian Government certainly takes some encouragement from these announcements and we look to the speedy implementation of these decisions. The announcements are significant in that SLORC has now admitted for the first time that it holds political prisoners, and the proposed meeting between SLORC and the political parties represents another change of policy because, until now, SLORC had not identified any time frame at all for this further process.But there is still a long way to go to restore democratic process in Burma.

A measure of SLORC's commitment to these decisions would be the immediate and unconditional release of all political prisoners, of which we estimate there to be some 2,000 still in custody. These include Daw Aung San Suu Kyi herself, of course, and other leaders of the National League for Democracy, who could play a very significant role in the process of national reconciliation in the transition to a modern democratic state.

I take this opportunity again to call on behalf of the Australian Government for the earliest transfer of power to a democratically elected government and for respect for universally accepted principles of human rights. It is the case that Burma's regime remains one of the most repressive in the world. We did have a further encouraging development yesterday with Burma and Bangladesh signing an agreement for the repatriation of the Rohingya refugees. That situation has been, of course, a source of concern to us all.

There is a further report suggesting today that the Burma Army has suspended its attack against the Karen National Union forces near the Thai-Burma border. Again, we hope that that represents a change of policy and not just some cosmetic step designed to take some international heat off. In that respect, the approach of the monsoon season and the failure so far of the Burmese Army's efforts to capture the Karen capital of Manerplaw may have been factors in the reported suspension.

Summing all that up, the Government will continue to follow very closely developments in Burma. We do remain very concerned about the situation there. We had been over recent weeks increasing our diplomatic activity to explore the possibility of a full scale UN-endorsed arms embargo against Burma and had been looking again at the question of economic sanctions. I have been having quite extensive discussions on those subjects, particularly in China, which remains the most influential country in this respect.

It is certainly not time, in our judgment, to review the measures we have already taken to show Australia's disapproval of political repression but, in all the circumstances, we do think it appropriate to hold for the moment any further diplomatic action to endeavour to make a better judgment as to just how seriously these current developments do constitute a watershed or whether, rather, they are simply cosmetic.

—Is the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs aware of the difficulties confronted by members of many ethnic communities in securing their proper rights as consumers? Given that the language barrier may be a significant factor in those difficulties, especially for older migrants, what steps is the Government taking to remedy the situation?

—Yes, I am aware of the difficulties faced by some members of Australia's ethnic communities in asserting their rights as consumers—first of all, understanding what rights they may have and then, of course, having the confidence to assert those rights if they do not have English as a first language and are not very proficient at it. For that reason, I have been engaged for the last year or so in undertaking programs with various ethnic communities, mainly using the media which are read or listened to by those communities, in order to help them understand the rights that they have as consumers and to ensure that they are not intimidated or, out of simple ignorance of their rights, do not exercise the rights that they have.

PARA.TAB: Several instances have been brought to the attention of this chamber. For example, elderly immigrant couples not particularly proficient at English are asked by banks and other financial institutions to act as guarantors for their children's business ventures. They do not fully understand the situation. They are then called upon to make that guarantee have some substance if the business collapses. They do not know who to turn to in order to assert that they were led into an unconscionable situation by the financial institution. That is just one instance of many.

In relation to ordinary matters—such as defective or unsafe products which cause an injury, or services which are not provided or, if provided, turn out to be shoddy—they need to know who to turn to in order to assert their rights as consumers. For that reason, there has been a series of multicultural meetings with various ethnic groups and communities—Arabic, Greek, Italian, Spanish, Chinese, Vietnamese, Serbian, Macedonian, Turkish, Croatian. I have spoken to them all in Melbourne and Sydney at various launches. These meetings have had the full support of the ethnic press, SBS and public affairs radio. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer again to the Middle East peace process and to confidence building measures. Does this decision have any implications for the Middle East peace process overall?

—I am very pleased that reports now confirm that Syria has now lifted discriminatory restrictions on travel abroad by Syrian Jews and lifted restrictions also on the disposition of property by the Syrian Jewish community. I acknowledge the very strong interest which many members of this Parliament and members of the Australian community in general have taken with regard to the situation of the Jewish community in Syria.

PARA.TAB: It is undeniable that members of this community have been subject to quite severe discrimination, particularly regarding their ability to travel outside Syria. The Australian Government, along with other countries, has taken a very consistent and firm stance with respect to this issue. We have been making direct representations to the Syrian authorities through our Embassy in Damascus for several years, and these issues were raised directly by my predecessor, Mr Hayden, during his visits in 1984 and 1988. I have had occasion, of course, to raise the issue also with the Syrian Ambassador here.

The decision to lift restrictions on travel means that, at least in theory, whole Syrian Jewish families should now have the right to travel abroad, as do members of all other Syrian communities. We will have to monitor closely whether in practice whole Jewish families will now be able to leave Syria together. It is to be acknowledged that Syrian Jews, like all Syrians, are still prohibited from travelling to Israel.

Without overstating the kind of influence a country like Australia has, I believe that representations by us and others have been important contributors to the Syrian Government's decisions. If one looks at its larger significance, I believe that this represents a significant confidence building measure in the context of the Middle East peace process. It is exactly the kind of step which Australia has been urging on all parties to the process to follow in order to promote a spirit of moderation and flexibility in the current negotiations. TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to a notice put out by Mr John Howard's office to promote a rally to be held on Thursday in Melbourne to protest about proposed legislation concerning so-called independent contractors? Can the Minister advise honourable senators what the legislation proposes to cause this reaction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last question was: what legislation is proposed that would cause this reaction? The answer to that question is that there is nothing proposed that would cause this reaction. What we have here is the practice of the big lie technique—the practice of building a huge emotional circus and pretending that something is happening that is not happening. Unfortunately, a number of people have fallen victim to the lies that are being told.

PARA.TAB: The notice that has been circulated by Mr Howard is a notice for a rally which is apparently sponsored by him and the Small Business Association of Australia against the independent contractors Bill. The first defect is in the title of this notice. There is no such Bill in existence. I have announced an intention to bring a Bill before the Senate, but at this stage the consultations associated with the Bill have not been concluded.

This notice is based on the big lie technique. There are essentially four lies being propounded. The first lie is that housing costs will increase by between 15 and 25 per cent. The second lie is that this alleged Bill will regulate subcontractors by awards of the Industrial Relations Commission. The third lie is that it will force all subcontractors in the housing industry into trade unions. Those lies are all absolutely wrong. The most outrageous of those three lies is the housing industry lie. I have asked organisations associated with the housing industry that have made these allegations to produce some evidence. They have not been able to do so, and they simply cannot because their allegations are not based on any foundation.

The fourth big lie is the lie of omission—not telling the truth—when one knows something else to exist that is relevant to the circumstances and one omits to actually mention it. The fourth big lie is that the legislation that I am proposing to introduce into the Senate is quite similar to legislation that applies in New South Wales which was introduced in the last rework for the New South Wales industrial relations Bill by the Greiner Government. I would have thought that that is a relevant fact that Mr Howard might have mentioned in his circular. He did not do so. That goes to his credibility as `Honest John' in terms of telling the truth about these circumstances.

I have said that I propose to introduce legislation that enables the Industrial Relations Commission to have the power to determine what class of employee or worker should be engaged in particular work, whether it should be those covered by awards or those working on independent contract. This is an area of industrial dispute in industrial relations. The Commission does not have the power to prevent or settle those issues of industrial dispute as the Constitution of this country enjoins it to. It seems to me entirely appropriate to clothe the Commission with the power to settle those disputes and to do so with the guidelines that I have suggested of efficiency, custom and practice to guide its mind when it approaches those problems.

Also under the legislation that I propose to introduce, the Commission would have the power to set aside contracts which are harsh and unconscionable, upon application by a so-called contractor, and then direct the parties to renegotiate or impose new terms. I would like to know who will stand up here in the Senate and defend harsh and unconscionable contracts. If there are contracts of that character, should not those who are victims of them have recourse to some means by which they can be settled? If someone thinks that this is an academic question, I can show that person outworkers in the clothing industry—mostly migrant women working away in their own homes—who are victims of harsh and unconscionable contracts and who, in the present circumstances, have no recourse to deal with those employment situations they are cast into by force of circumstances.

The `anti' campaign depends on misrepresentation and distortion. It is a political attempt to whip up hysteria on this subject. Many people who have been duped by it confess to me when I talk to them that they do not know the terms of the Bill; that is because there is no Bill. When I discuss it with them, they are enlightened and they change their attitude to a considerable extent. Therefore, I caution industry and employer associations not to be gulled, not to be used by John Howard's political agenda, but to talk to the Government about exactly what is intended and ascertain for themselves the facts.

Many employer organisations and industries have done so. Many of them have spoken to me, they recognise the situation and are pleased with the outcome. The Housing Industry Association sent me a letter dated 15 April 1992, which I am prepared to table. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: We appreciated the manner in which you conducted the discussions and your courtesy in providing the briefing note on the legislation amendments.
The letter further states:

The Association will take comfort from your assurance that the amendments will not include the housing industry. However, the practical ways in which a fence can be placed around housing will require further thought.
The position of medium density housing and high rise residential projects presents thorny issues.
In this regard, your offer to continue consultations with the HIA is warmly welcomed.

That is hardly an organisation stampeding to demonstrate against the Government. Today I had further discussions with the Australian Road Transport Industry Organisation. This is a body of employers who are affiliated to the Confederation of Australian Industry. It said, categorically, that it will not take part in any campaign against this Government on this legislation. It has authorised me to say that to the Senate. It also said that it appreciated the talks and assistance that it had been given by me and my Department on this matter; that they had been constructive and useful and it wished to continue in that vein.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you threaten to put up their registration charges?

—That is an intolerable assertion and it ought to be withdrawn. It is a disgusting reflection on Senator Macdonald. There were no such threats; this was a constructive dialogue. Senator Macdonald's interjection characterises efforts to pretend that something sinister is afoot. Why would he be frightened of the Industrial Relations Commission having power, on the evidence before it, to make a determination about these matters? Why would he not want the umpire to have that power and why would he not want a contract which is discovered to be harsh and unconscionable dealt with?

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, what is clearly the agenda of the Opposition and Mr Howard in muddying the waters and whipping up this hysterical campaign is to promote the idea of voluntary employment contracts. This is language used by the Opposition which offends English usage. They should probably be called exploitative employment contracts, something which Mr Howard has knocked on many employers doors offering as a solution to industrial relations issues. All of those employers I know of on whose doors he has knocked have said, `Is that you, John? If it is, go away. QWN.TITLE: ADDITIONAL RESPONSE TO QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I gave an undertaking to Senator Crowley to provide her with additional information in relation to the lifting of bans on Mr Martin Vinnicombe, and I will provide that information now.

PARA.TAB: On 24 April 1992, the Federal Court ordered that Martin Vinnicombe's action be dismissed, with no order as to costs, because the parties agreed to abide by a decision of the court-appointed referee. The outcome of this decision is that the parties to the agreement would do all things necessary to cause Mr Vinnicombe to be issued a professional licence. The Government will abide by the referee's decision. This will require that Mr Vinnicombe be issued a valid clearance from the Australian Cycling Federation; return a negative drug test conducted by the Australian Sports Drug Agency; make a valid application for a professional licence and then have that licence endorsed by the Australian Professional Cycling Council for international competition.

The Government will not interfere in this process, a process which has commenced. However, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) understands that the process has been complicated by the fact that the New South Wales League of Wheelmen, the State professional cycling body which was not party to the mediation process, has indicated that it will not issue Mr Vinnicombe with a State licence. It is unclear whether the APCC can issue a valid international licence without the cooperation of the State league. The Minister has asked that this process be examined and I on her behalf will report this to the Senate further.

Again, I wish to make it clear that there is no doubt about Mr Vinnicombe's test result. As I said yesterday, it was positive. The Federal Court ruling relied on an opinion by the appointed mediator, the Hon. Bob Ellicott, QC, which stated that Mr Vinnicombe had taken the anabolic steroid called stanozolol. In fact, Mr Vinnicombe admitted this in a statement to Mr Ellicott.

The view of the Government is still that Martin Vinnicombe, by administering to himself a banned anabolic steroid, is in breach of the Australian Sports Commission's doping policy. Mr Vinnicombe is no longer a member of the Australian amateur cycling body known as the ACF. Nevertheless, the ACF's position continues to accord with the ASC's doping policy in that the ACF will not consider an application from Mr Vinnicombe for membership of the ACF until two years has elapsed from the date of Mr Vinnicombe's sample collection. As far as the ASC is concerned, Mr Vinnicombe will be ineligible for any form of financial assistance for two years from the date of the sample collection.

In conclusion, as I explained yesterday to the Senate, the Government will be moving quickly to ensure that in future individuals who cheat by taking performance enhancing drugs cannot escape sanctions on technicalities. This will require amendments to the ASDA legislation. As I advised the Senate yesterday, the Government is examining that matter now.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The coalition acknowledges the move by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to close this loophole—a closure that we called for at the weekend. I acknowledge Senator Collins's comments about the difficulties now faced by Mr Vinnicombe in getting a professional licence. I hope that those difficulties cannot be overcome.
—Hear, hear!

—I acknowledge the Minister's agreement. Like the Government, the Opposition believes that there is ample evidence, from Mr Vinnicombe's own mouth, that he breached the rules—rules which have required other Australian athletes to be suspended for two years. The Opposition certainly reminds all Australian athletes that the taking of drugs resulted in Australian swimmers, for example, being cheated out of gold medals for years by swimmers from Eastern European countries. We commend all actions—particularly those of the Government, the Sports Drug Agency and the Australian Sports Commission—in seeking to stamp out drug taking in Australian sport. There is no doubt from the Minister's comments that there is a bipartisan approach to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The necessity to retain the tariff on sugar imports at its current level of $76 a tonne and to postpone any further reduction until a successful conclusion is reached in the GATT Uruguay round.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion today because the future of Australia's sugar industry is indeed a matter of urgency. The industry requires our urgent action now, not in the year 2000, because Australia's sugar industry will become bankrupt without continued protection for the 23 per cent of its production which is consumed domestically.

PARA.TAB: We know why the industry is in this position. A combination of drought—which has reduced domestic sugar production—and low world prices has severely reduced the operating surplus of the average sugar farm. In asking for the retention of the current tariff rate, canegrowers are asking for a subsidy that accounts for about 40 per cent of the average cane farmer's cash flow and probably well over half of his or her profits.

We are talking survival. We are talking urgent survival—survival of an industry and survival of the towns and communities which depend on this industry. We are, in fact, asking Australia's seven million households to pay about $8.50 a year towards the survival of the sugar industry—$8.50 towards the maintenance of sugar growers' jobs, $8.50 towards the retention of thousands of jobs in the communities which depend on the sugar industry.

Ask the people of Mackay in Queensland, the people of Ayr or the people of Bundaberg whether they are willing to pay this small price. Of course they are, and so is the rest of Australia. Just ask the people who voted recently in Wills, and who told both the Government and the Opposition what they think about being treated as guinea pigs on the altar of world trade reform. How can it possibly be in the national interest to threaten the livelihood of Australia's 6,500 canegrowers and their families and their surrounding communities which rely on them? That is real job creation for you, and in a time of massive unemployment to boot.

A recent study by a Queensland university economist, Professor Rod Jensen, reveals that every $1m spent on locally made goods generates almost 30 full time jobs for a year. He estimates that Australia's $50,000m import bill could create more than a million jobs if spent on local products not imports. The same $1m order for local goods also creates a $500,000 bonus for State and Federal governments. We are moving in a contrary and contradictory direction.

Let us take a moment to look at the responses of both the coalition and the Government to the well publicised plight of canegrowers. From the Liberal Party we see absolute rigidity and from the Labor Party we see hypocritical selectivity. Dr Hewson says, `Well, I can explain all of this away. It is the Government's fault that the necessary micro-economic reform hasn't been carried out'. Maybe that is true.

How ridiculous then to go ahead and vote to destroy the sugar industry as a consequence. Surely, the sensible and reasonable thing for the Liberal Party to do would be to say, `We acknowledge that sugar is Australia's second most valuable crop after wheat. We acknowledge that it contributes about $1 billion a year to crop exports. We in the Liberal Party think it could do better with the sort of assistance we intend to put in place but, in the meantime, we want the sugar industry to survive so that when we win government and put these other reforms in place we will have this key industry in a position to move in the area of boosting exports'.

What do we see from Dr Hewson, from Mr Tim Fischer, from Senator Ian Macdonald and from others who represent sugar constituencies? We see absolute rigidity. We see absolutely blinkered, absolutely black and white—must have zero tariffs, must have no exemptions—blanket rules for all situations. I can tell Dr Hewson that life is not like that. Real life requires flexibility. It requires assessment of individual differences and individual needs.

In fact, far from creating the ideal free trade, zero tariff world it could be argued—as Mr Joe Farley of the Australian Canefarmers Association has argued—that Dr Hewson is in fact hindering world trade reform because of his constant stubborn reiteration of zero tariffs by the year 2000. What a perfect inducement that is for Europeans to sit back and do nothing to reduce their massive protective structure for the next eight years because they know that by the year 2000, under a coalition government, we will still be proceeding with scorched earth policies.

What of the position of Liberal members who represent sugar constituencies? Last year in a debate similar to this one Senator Ian Macdonald from Queensland said that he was the only one in this chamber whose livelihood has depended on the returns gained by the sugar industry. He said that he supports this industry and that he will be a credible voice in a coalition Cabinet to make sure that this important industry for north Queensland will be encouraged and enhanced. He talked about the innate ability of sugar producers to create wealth for Australia. Yet Senator Macdonald is not here; he has been totally silent on this issue. He has been promoted to the shadow Ministry, for which we congratulate him, but his success must not be at the cost of the Queensland and the Australian sugar industry—his constituency's major industry.

If Senator Macdonald and the Liberal Party vote in rigid uniformity against the urgent and special needs of the sugar industry, there will be half as many sugar growers left to benefit from the touted assistance of the structural reforms which the Liberal Party proposes. What great forward planning. Those in the Opposition are saying, `We will help to destroy you now, but when we come into government we will do wonderful things to assist you'.

That leads me to another component in the flawed arguments of the coalition with respect to how canegrowers will benefit from the Fightback package. Mr Tim Fischer bases his claim mainly on the fact that canegrowers will have lower fuel costs as a result of the replacement of the fuel excise with the 15 per cent goods and services tax, but lower fuel prices will go nowhere near covering the loss of the present subsidy.

Before I turn to the response of the Labor Party, I say to those listening to this debate that there are no National Party members on the speakers list or present here in the chamber. In fact, the Opposition has failed to provide a speaker for its second speaking position. I think we have to ask what this signifies. Will the National Party members avoid this vote or will they put their vote where their mouths have been recently? Unfortunately, that is what rigid party politics does to individuals. Where are those who, in their hearts and minds, support a halt in tariff phase-outs for the sugar industry? The bottom line in this debate is that the survival of the coalition is more important than the survival of the sugar industry.

The Labor Party, in an example of absolute selectivity, will introduce into the Senate this week amendments to the Customs Act to impose a $12,000 tariff on second-hand motor vehicles from Japan to correct a `distortion', a `distortion' in trade disadvantaging Australian industry. So it is okay to do something for cars, but it is not okay to do anything for sugar. Sugar growers are entitled to ask `Why not?' and `What criteria are being used?'.

Where does GATT feature in this? Both western Europe and the United States protect their motor industries via quotas. They do not call them quotas, but `voluntary restraints'. Why can we not call them that? Where does the Labor Party in Queensland stand? Mr Goss said that he would not tolerate reduced tariff protection, but what has he done? He has done nothing. It is all parochial talk.

Canegrowers do not want indefinite tariff support. They want urgent recognition of their special circumstances—their contribution to Australia's future. Let us not forget that this Government and Opposition changed the rules on canegrowers just last year. All the sugar industry wants is a fair go in order to survive and to contribute. We in the Australian Democrats believe that people should not pull their houses down before they have made arrangements to live elsewhere. We believe that canegrowers are entitled to that fair go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating an urgency motion moved by the Australian Democrats on tariff reform in the sugar industry. There ought to be a recognition in this debate that, while Australia is an island, it is part of the international world trading community. In that world we are faced with the formation of trading blocs and the locking out of markets of most efficient traders. Australia is an efficient grower of wheat, wool and sugarcane, and it is an efficient producer of iron ore, coal, alumina, gold and a whole range of agricultural and mineral commodities.

PARA.TAB: The issue here is: how do we penetrate markets that are closing off or are resistant to the most efficient producer and are heavily subsidised themselves? Can we as a small country in a large world, facing massive trading blocs, outsubsidise or outprotect particular commodities and therefore beat the United States and northern Europe? We do not have the capacity. We have to change the nature of the game by negotiating the removal of subsidies elsewhere and by opening up for our rural producers the closed markets in the European Community and elsewhere. That is the way in which we have to compete and change the nature of the game. We have done that by enlisting the support of other nations of medium and small size like our own in the Cairns Group to form an effective lobby against the giant superpowers in Europe and North America which lock us out of their markets. The Cairns Group has achieved a very important success in a difficult area.

In the context of those remarks, let us come to the issue of tariff protection. In the economic statement delivered on 12 March the Government declared what the regime will be for us in reducing tariff protection. The objective of that statement was to recognise the reality. As an exporter of raw materials in agriculture and raw bulk materials in minerals, we have not succeeded in transforming our economy from simply a mine and a farm to a manufacturing economy. That is because many of our industries languished behind tariff protection, grew fat, did not face world competition, were not competitive and lost markets overseas as a result of that lack of competition.

The evidence is that we are not making our industries more efficient, but rather that we are destroying our industries and replacing Australian products with imports.
I refer to an article, published in the Age newspaper on 21 April 1992, by Tim Colebatch, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australians are importing 36 per cent more clothing and footwear than three years ago. . .
He also states that in that industry the annual bill will reach $1.5 billion this financial year. Mr Colebatch also makes the point that:
The output of Australian clothing and footwear factories slumped by 34 per cent.
A similar picture emerges from Mr Tim Colebatch's reports about the car industry. He states:
