The causes appear to be the abolition of import quotas in 1988, and the drastic reduction of tariffs from 57.5 per cent to 35 per cent in four years.
The picture is emerging very clearly indeed that, in a very unthinking, non-strategic way, we are destroying our factories and increasing our unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The truth is that tariffs are not prohibited under GATT. This is one of the fairy tales that we have been fed—that to gain a quid pro quo with GATT, to be recognised by other trading nations, to become part of the international trading community, we must be good boys and girls; we must reduce our tariffs; we must cut out all other protective measures. The truth is that tariffs are not prohibited under GATT. It is, therefore, not surprising that the United States is using them to protect, for instance, its ball-bearing and computer industries.

Even quotas and import surcharges are justified if the country concerned has balance of payments difficulties. Certainly we can say, and the evidence is there, that Australia has had balance of payments difficulties. The only thing that GATT prohibits is subsidies. Here we come to the nub of the question: what about the United States; what about the European Community? Farmers in those countries are receiving subsidies of up to 44 per cent. No wonder those countries do not want to bring their particular agricultural industries under the GATT regime.

It is worthwhile to look at the United States' trade barriers which are currently in force. In 1990 primary producers in the United States were paid subsidies equal to 44 per cent of farm output. In 1988, 94 per cent of Illinois' and 72 per cent of Iowa's net farm income came in the form of government cheques. Since 1985—and this is probably the worst aspect of current United States policy—there have been over 110 export enhancement programs offered to 75 countries. These have been subsidised to the tune of $4 billion and have a total value of $11 billion in sales.

All this time, while these countries have been supported by their restrictive trade practices, we have been fed with the lie that we must reduce our protection to enable us to be accepted by the trading community. But there is no need for it. In fact, we should be using our tariff policy in a constructive manner so that we can, over time, develop industries which have much stronger market penetration and which are capable of increasing our import replacement and boosting our exports.

Our so-called tariff policy is nothing but a scorched earth policy, as has been reaffirmed again by Senator Durack in his new capacity as Opposition spokesperson for trade in the Senate. I congratulate him on his appointment, but I have great regret indeed that once again he has approached the matter in a very simplistic manner and is supporting a total abolition of tariffs. Let me quote to him from a recent study commissioned by the ISO in Victoria which says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . each $1 million saved on imports creates 30 person years of employment. . .
The study said that it also produces:
. . . $280,000 in taxes and charges for all levels of government. . . $250,000 in direct consumer spending and $231,000 in welfare expenditure savings.
These figures were published in an article in the Age on 11 April by Ken Davidson entitled, `Maximising local content: The key to industry policy'.

PARA.TAB: There is no suggestion that we should return to the days of indiscriminately high protection. However, the massive increase in the imports of cars, TCF products and the corresponding wave of job losses and factory closures confirms the failure of the Keating-Hewson scorched earth policy. In fact, tariffs and other protective devices are but one of the measures necessary to achieve the twin objectives of high international competitiveness and low unemployment. It is utterly simplistic to make a general judgment that tariffs are good or bad. Rather, the task is to use them as one of the tools available and to determine the level, timing and type of protection, if any, for each industry in accordance with clearly defined criteria.

At this stage, I remind honourable senators that this morning I gave notice of a motion to establish a tariffs inquiry to find out exactly how we can use our tariffs and the effects of the current policies, which are simply not acceptable and which are totally destructive. The matters that should be brought out in this inquiry are the import replacement and export boosting potential in the light of present and projected markets; the effect on employment, including the social effect of endangering the continuing existence of regional industries; the effect on the use of energy and natural resources; the potential for the development of alternative industries, including time scale, retraining and investment required; and, last but not least, the exploitation index—that is, unacceptably low wages, work safety and environmental safeguards which enable international competitors to undercut Australian products.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening, when we were discussing the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill, I began my speech by referring to those weighty but uncontentious matters—matters that have the support, I believe, of all senators in the chamber—which are the substantial matters in this legislation. They are the repealing of the National Service Act and its subsequent legislation, and the amendment to the Defence Act itself as it relates to the persons liable to conscription, and the deletion of inappropriate—I think I used the word `Aristotelian'—categories. They might have been appropriate in 1904 but they now ought to be more flexible and related to the particular emergency of the defence of Australia, which would prompt any action under this Act. Those categories will now be determined by regulation.

PARA.TAB: These matters, together with the references in this legislation to the Defence personnel Acts—those amendments that relate to the Defence Forces Retirement and Death Benefits Act, the Defence Housing Authority Act and the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act—are all supported by the Opposition and, as I have said, are uncontentious. However, one of the things I said in my introduction last night was that this is the first time in at least a decade that the Parliament is considering a philosophical matter—a very considerable matter of policy in the area of defence—and that is the particular provisions in our law for conscription for the defence of Australia and for conscientious objection to that conscription.

It is now understood that, as a result of the amendments contained in this legislation, if ever conscription is required—and I, for one, hope that it never will be—it will be a requirement falling upon men and women alike. That is, all citizens of Australia aged 18 to 60—not only citizens but also permanent residents with at least six months residency in Australia—male and female, will be contributing through conscription to the immediate defence of Australia, according to the particular strengths and abilities of the individual.

I turn now to three matters about which there are various views in this chamber. The first is one which I think will gain the full approval of senators, and that is that before any conscription proclamation is made, the government of the day will need to gain parliamentary approval for it. I believe that that will gain the support of all senators in this chamber. I note that this is a new element to conscription. It is a new element in terms of it being a restriction upon the full powers of the elected government of Australia.

In matters of defence, one of the first responsibilities of the elected government is to ensure the security of the people of Australia and the defence of Australia. I must say that I have reservations about this new provision requiring parliamentary approval. I support the legislation as it stands, and I conscientiously support parliamentary approval being required if ever there is to be a conscription proposal brought by the government of the day. My reservation is that I do not want this to be seen as the thin edge of the wedge and that the government of the day will require parliament's approval in matters of defence before it can act.

I am generally seeing the strengths of referenda in this country. Certainly, in any democracy, I see the importance of fairly conducted elections. But I do not believe that executive government is best conducted through referenda or through multiple elections. After an election has been held in this country, the elected government has a mandate and a responsibility to go about its task of governing. One of the few instances where there is a requirement for executive action to gain the approval of the Parliament is when the Government believes that conscription is necessary for the immediate defence of Australia.

One of the reasons for this is the whole century of debate in this country about conscription. There was enormous contention in this country about conscription at the time of the Vietnam war and, under the National Service Act, the conscription of young men to fight overseas in Indo-China. I acknowledge the other times in our history in which there has been contention about the government of the day deciding upon conscription.

A precedent was established during the Gulf war debate in January last year with the—not near unanimity—overwhelming majority of Government and Opposition members supporting the Government's decisions on Australia's role in the Gulf war. I believe that it was a great asset to our deployed troops, our contingent that was part of the allied effort in the Gulf, for this Parliament to have had that debate and for the overwhelming majority of members of parliament to have shown their support for what was then to be Australia's involvement in the Gulf.

In a similar way, were there ever to be any pending invasion of Australia or any direct and immediate threat to the invasion of Australia, it would be appropriate for the government of the day to formulate a series of defence decisions, including conscription, and to bring them in an opportune way to this Parliament, and to gain a similar endorsement of the actions proposed under the Defence Act—as so amended by the legislation in front of us—that would show that the government and opposition of the day were at least conscientiously able to put their views. If there were ever such a threat to the invasion of Australia, I believe there would be an agreement on the necessity of conscription.

In that debate the Parliament would be able to make its own representations; it would be able to reflect the views of the people of Australia in any modification, extension, variation or safeguards that would be involved in the parliamentary approvals that were given. My major reservation is this: I do not wish to see this Parliament regard this situation as the thin edge of the wedge so that the government of the day would be required to gain parliamentary approval in defence matters.

I turn now to the question of the 90-day limit. The Opposition does not agree with the words in this legislation that require parliamentary approval for conscription to be given within 90 days. I do not believe that we lose anything by removing entirely that reference to 90 days, because it would still be within the power of the Government to gain that approval at any point after the matter was proposed. If Australia were about to be invaded or if it were threatened with direct invasion, it would be most surprising if the Government did not act immediately by bringing before Parliament the proposal for the defence of Australia that it had formulated. This reference to 90 days then becomes unnecessary and redundant. It is with that in mind and with the expectation that parliamentary approval would flow within a much lesser period than 90 days that I join with my Opposition colleagues in opposing that reference in the Bill.

I come now to the definition of conscription that is set out in the legislation. As I said last night, this flows from the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs into conscientious objection to conscripted military service and the report that that Senate Committee brought down in 1985. The former ground on which conscientious objection to service in a war was given was rather narrowly confined to religious grounds—to the ground that someone was a lifelong pacifist on religious grounds. We had many instances of conscientious objection in the First World War, the Second World War, in the Vietnam war and in every case where the Australian public had been called upon to serve in a war.

We have recognised as one of the values in Australia that, on religious grounds, a person could argue, `I am a pacifist. It is against my conscience to take up arms and, although I am required by law to meet the call-up or the conscription as a loyal Australian, I am a pacifist and will not be able conscientiously to do so'. There has been historic provision to allow that as an excuse for not serving in a war.

The definition of conscientious objection that is now before us is much wider than that. But whilst it is wider than the profession of pacifism and it is wider than religious grounds, it is nevertheless very constrained and appropriately limited. The definition states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a person is taken to have a conscientious belief in relation to a matter if the person's belief in respect of that matter:
(a) involves a fundamental conviction of what is morally right and morally wrong, whether or not based on religious considerations; and
(b) is so compelling in character for that person that he or she is duty bound to espouse it; and
(c) is likely to be of a long standing nature.

It is not sufficient that it be the view of a particular minority political party—a political view or a temporary view. It must be a longstanding view based upon a conviction about what is morally right and wrong. It must be compelling. So when a person makes an appeal to the tribunal provided for in this legislation for conscientious objection, the tribunal tests his application according to that definition. I support the definition and I believe it is supported by every honourable senator in this chamber and, as I say, it flows from the Senate report.

PARA.TAB: Where there is contention, I refer to an additional ground for conscientious belief that is set out on the next page of the legislation which would allow persons to have conscientious objection to a particular war or a particular conflict. This involves a claim that they are conscientious objectors, not in general to all wars or not for all of their life, but that with regard to a particular war they have conscientious views, based on what is morally right and wrong, which they must espouse and which are longstanding.

It is a question of logic for me. It seems to me almost impossible to conceive why any Australian or Australian resident would wish to take the particular ground of conscientious objection when all that is at stake is the immediate defence of Australia from invasion. I acknowledge this ground of conscientious objection in the situation of Vietnam—not under the Defence Act but under the National Service Act involving an overseas expeditionary force. I refer to a force sent conscientiously by the Government of Australia to join allies indirectly for the defence of Australia. In the case of, say, Vietnam historically, I would have agreed with a set of words such as we see in clause 9(d)(i) of this Bill. That provision refers to:

SPEECH.PARA: persons whose conscientious beliefs do not allow them to participate in a particular war or particular warlike operations.

PARA.TAB: The point that should be stressed is that this package of legislation that is now before us repeals the National Service Act. It is no longer possible to have conscription for service in Vietnam. Conscription is confined to the immediate defence of Australia. In that respect I join with my Opposition colleagues in opposing the words of the clause that I read out that would allow conscientious objection to a particular war. I believe that it would lead mostly, if not entirely, to administrative difficulty and to a range of applications that would largely be difficult to uphold. It would delay the whole procedure with regard to any administrative conscription provision that the Australian Government and the Parliament had approved and put in place.

Senator MacGibbon referred to one possible case where persons of the Islam faith, if there were an invasion by persons who were also of the Islam faith, might wish to object to that particular conflict because they would be fighting against persons of their own faith. I do not believe that Australians can place that kind of allegiance ahead of the immediate defence of Australia from invasion. This is not to send an expeditionary force; it is to immediately defend Australia. If we were to allow such an example as I have referred to, it might be possible to contemplate almost any argument of conscientious objection to a particular war. I do not allow for that. I have said very clearly that my support for conscientious objection in a particular war would be confined to a situation such as Vietnam, which situation is no longer possible under the Defence Act.

With those remarks, I commend the great majority of the very welcome provisions that are now before the Senate in this defence legislation. I indicate that I am opposed to the reference to objection on the grounds of a particular war and to the reference to the 90-day period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill contains a number of measures concerning conscription, conscientious objection to military service, and housing and retirement provisions for Defence Force personnel. Several of these provisions are uncontroversial, but the conscription and conscientious objection amendments are more substantial and I will address them in more detail.

PARA.TAB: Overall, the Democrats support this Bill as a small, mostly symbolic step in the right direction towards a more sensible and democratic defence system for Australia. However, it totally and deliberately fails to address the reality of Australia's security environment, which dictates that our defence forces are far more likely to be deployed in overseas conflicts than in defence of the nation. My colleague Senator Spindler is finalising several amendments to address this concern and will circulate them shortly.

One of the two major provisions in this Bill is that women and Aboriginal people will be potentially eligible for conscription, although the actual classes of conscripts will no longer be defined in the Defence Act. Instead, they will be specified by regulation. It is important to note that the Defence Act, as it now stands, only permits conscription in time of war, which is defined in that Act as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any invasion or apprehended invasion of, or attack or apprehended attack on, Australia by an enemy or armed force.
Given that our policy envisages that conscription could be warranted in the event that Australia's survival as a nation state is at risk, we have no difficulty with that aspect of the Act.

PARA.TAB: The potential eligibility of women for conscription is in one sense a landmark change. However, the important word here is `potential'. Given that women are currently excluded from combat roles in the Defence Force, the Democrats do not anticipate that regulations to introduce conscription would change this situation, although we would ask the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to respond to this point. Subject to this qualification, and given the Bill's welcome provision that conscription is subject to parliamentary approval, the Democrats agree that women cannot reasonably be exempted from playing a role in the defence of this nation.

From the Democrats' viewpoint, the most significant provision of this Bill is to enshrine in the Defence Act the right of potential conscripts to conscientious objection to military service. Exemption may be claimed for all wars or for a particular war and from combatant duties only or from all military service.

In general, the Democrats support the right of conscientious objection as a fundamental civil liberty as well as being in the best interests of Australia's defence. For some people the taking of another life, which in normal times is seen as the most repugnant of crimes, is an intolerable affront to their conscience and their morality, no matter what the circumstances. To force these people into military service is not only unjust but it must also weaken the Defence Force by the inclusion of people whose capacity to perform their duties is highly questionable.

The Democrats support the establishment of conscientious objection tribunals to determine the claims of conscripts. Thorough examination of claims is essential to ensure that conscientious objection is not opportunistically employed as a means of avoiding military service for other reasons.

We have listened to the views of the Opposition, which appears to be concerned that conscientious objection by conscripts to service in the event of an attack on Australia—which is what this Bill provides for—should not be allowed on the ground that such service is paramount national duty. The Opposition appears to be particularly concerned by the proposal to allow exemption from a particular war, as Senator Teague has just said, which could presumably be sought on the ground of national descent.

The Democrats do not believe that our reasons for supporting conscientious objection are negated in the event of a direct threat to our national security. I have listened to what Senator Teague has been saying; he is very sensible on the matter. We have no doubt that the vast majority of Australians would be sufficiently motivated by self-interest and a sense of national duty to play their role in countering that threat. But we also regard as an inevitable consequence of our high immigration rates and our diverse sources of immigrants that, for some people, military service against a country with which they have had recent historical ties would provoke a crisis of conscience. Nothing would be gained by compelling such people to serve.

However, we believe that the conscientious objection provisions of this Bill look like an unjustifiably soft option in that an objector would be free to continue civilian life without interruption, while conscripts would be required to make huge sacrifices. It is our understanding that in some European countries conscientious objectors must perform community service in lieu of military service. We will be moving amendments to require conscientious objection tribunals to prescribe community service for Australian objectors.

While the Democrats welcome the improvements in the conscription and conscientious objection provisions of the Defence Act contained in this Bill, the fact remains that there is little prospect that they will be used for at least the next decade. It is generally accepted that we face no substantial military threats over at least that period. It is far more likely that any future combat operations will be conducted overseas.

Given the controversial nature of such deployments, a legacy of our historical tendency to follow great and powerful friends into foreign wars, the Democrats are particularly concerned that this Bill does not give volunteer service personnel the right of conscientious objection to service in overseas conflicts. Many Australians, including some in the Defence Force, have strong moral objections to such service.

While Defence Force volunteers should not be able to seek exemption from their fundamental duty to defend Australia, we believe that they should be able to claim exemption from overseas combat operations. As with conscripts, their claims should be heard by conscientious objection tribunals. We will be moving amendments to achieve this.

The Democrats are somewhat disappointed that this Bill demonstrates that the Government has not learned one of the major lessons of its Gulf war deployment. The controversy which was provoked by the unilateral commitment of Australian naval personnel and warships to combat operations in the Persian Gulf, which resulted in a hastily arranged parliamentary sitting some days later, was a salutary demonstration of the community's expectation that parliamentary approval should have been sort. Yet there is nothing in this Bill which enshrines such an obligation.

Parliament will be given the right to disallow conscription in the dire circumstances of a direct threat to Australia, yet we will have no control over a government which again decides to risk Australian lives in an unnecessary war aimed only at keeping oil prices as low as possible. We will therefore be moving amendments to make the deployment of Australian forces to overseas conflicts subject to parliamentary approval.

From a technical point of view, this Bill is a step forward. But in its relevance to the real world in which the Australian Defence Force operates, it represents very little change. It improves the regulatory framework governing uncontroversial deployments which are likely to occur, while leaving Cabinet free to deploy military forces to conflicts which have no relevance to our national security and are far more likely to divide the Australian community. While we support the Bill, we urge the Government and the Opposition to give serious consideration to our amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. I will keep my comments very brief. However, I wish to refer to certain aspects of the legislation. Of course, the Liberal and National parties do not object to the part of this legislation which clarifies the circumstances that would justify the imposition of conscription. The Bill removes reference to the fact that conscription applies to males between 18 and 60 years of age who are British subjects.

PARA.TAB: Last year the Australian Democrats mounted a quite childish and disgraceful scare campaign to the effect that conscription would be applied to the Gulf war. This has shown the need for this Parliament to consider carefully under what circumstances conscription should be justified. Senator Bourne, who has just fled the chamber like a gazelle, really does not seem to realise the significance of much of what the Democrats have stood for in the past and what they are obviously standing for in the future. I will come back to some of that in a moment.

The community at large is frequently told that short term national service would be of benefit to young Australians. I respect the concern that many people have that the concept of national service is a good one, especially when we look at the number of young Australians who lack employment and direction. However, I would have to say that that attitude does concern me in another respect. People who are suggesting this course of action and who do not wish any harm to the services probably have not considered the effect that this would have on the services.

People who wish to gain entry to the services are required to have very high qualifications. They have to be of a satisfactory standard. I do not think the services should in any way be a dumping ground for the criminals of Australia. I therefore always urge caution when people talk about reforming certain individuals by making them subject to national service. I think this would be undesirable not only for the services but also for the defence of our country.

It is no longer appropriate that compulsory conscription should be pursued in a military context. We have moved a long way from the arrangement that was put in place early this century when this Parliament gave bipartisan support for the military training of schoolboys. That, too, is a very sad reflection on the changes that have taken place. I think the training of schoolboy cadets was a very substantial part of the education system. Young boys were given an excellent grounding for future life. At that time Australia was defended by putting every man into uniform and giving him a rifle. In the 1960s blanket conscription of this type to ensure our security no longer made any military sense, let alone being relevant in other areas.

It is a fact that the Australian electorate did endorse conscription by ballot that existed between 1964 and 1972. However, it is no longer acceptable that compulsory overseas military service should apply only to a selection of young Australian men. Over the last two decades there has been a trend among Western democracies to abandon military conscription. This is based on the fact that defence needs are best met by small professional forces.

I believe that the Australian people will accept the need for compulsory military service when our nation is under direct threat. It is therefore proper that Parliament should give specific endorsement to conscription. There needs to be the explicit backing of the Australian people, just as our contribution to the Gulf war was vindicated by Parliament.

I have little doubt that in a scenario of direct military threat to Australia, such as we faced in 1942, the support of Parliament through the two major parties would be forthcoming. I would never go so far as to suggest that the Australian Democrats or the independent Greens, the peacemakers—call them what you like—would be supportive of that.

The performance that we saw last year from the Democrats and then Independent Senator Vallentine during the debate on the Gulf war was nothing short of appalling. The then Senator Vallentine sought to disrupt the Parliament, both in this chamber and in the House of Representatives. Her actions brought the whole of the Parliament into disrepute. I certainly hope that her successor does not carry on like a trained seal and act in the same way as she did on that occasion and, I might add, on many others.

It is appropriate that the Parliament should be able to exercise a veto in respect of actions of the Executive. A little while ago Senator Bourne said that people who come from certain countries should be exempt from conscription if they do not want to fight in a conflict in the country which they left. I find that absolutely and utterly staggering, coming from the Australian Democrats, who are great advocates of multiculturalism in other areas. Presumably, people who take out Australian citizenship or residency should be committed first to Australia and not the country from which they came. This is particularly the case if such people have taken out Australian citizenship. I would hope that the Australian Democrats would place more importance on Australian citizenship than that which Senator Bourne described today.

I think the Labor Government has failed to be consistent in making a political concession to minorities against the national interest in terms of new division 2 of part IV of the Defence Act, which deals with the termination of conscientious objection to military service. The right of a person not to bear arms should always be respected, although in time of peril—I stress in time of peril—the Australian nation has the right to demand of all its citizens that they assist the defence effort in some form. That is where, once again, I come into conflict with what the Australian Democrats have been saying that it should be easy to get out of it and use some other form of excuse. Indeed, when such a small proportion of a modern defence force is actually using weapons, there is massive scope for those with a conscientious objection to taking life to perform alternative roles.

In a sense, this Labor Government is fighting Vietnam all over again by introducing the avenue of conscientious objection to a particular war. There can indeed be proper debate as to whether Australians should have the right to object to participation to a particular overseas conflict. What we are talking about, however, in the context of this legislation, is a hypothetical war that threatens Australia with invasion or surrender, not a conflict pursued against aggression far from our shores.

It is only reasonable to suggest that no Australian has the right to decide that they will opt out of a particular war when our survival is at stake. I think that is particularly pertinent. Once again, instead of the Democrats calling on us to be reasonable, I think it is about time the Democrats looked at the reality of the situation of war, what the likelihood of a threat to Australia is and what we should do as a consequence.

These are not circumstances where individuals can make political decisions not to participate—when the fight is for survival. It would have been rather quaint 50 years ago to have allowed Australians to opt out of the war effort on the grounds that they thought it acceptable to be overrun by the Japanese. I just think that, in getting some reality into this, we need to look back in history and learn from it.

We cannot extend the grounds of conscientious objection so widely as to allow in effect disloyalty to Australia. It may be suggested that this unnecessary extra condition of opposition to a particular war has been introduced in order to conciliate ethnic minorities who protested at our participation in the Gulf war.

I come back to the point: are Australians Australians or are they Australians only when it suits them? I would hope that Australians are Australians through and through from beginning to end and all points in between. If that is so and we are to conciliate ethnic minorities, we are insulting those we should assume to be good Australians who would surely defend this country under direct threat, no matter where it came from. I think that is the point that we need to be focusing on today. Are we going to defend this country from all risk at whatever time?

As a Liberal, I am opposed to war but cannot deny the fact that war is sometimes inevitable to oppose greater evil and injustice. The Senate, I think, should reflect on the words of a former Governor-General of Australia, Sir William Slim, who nearly 50 years ago stood in resistance to Japanese military fascism at the head of a truly multicultural army of European and Indian soldiers. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If ever an army fought in a just cause, we did. We coveted no man's country; we wished to impose no form of government on any nation. We fought for the clean, the decent, the free things of life, for the right to live our lives in our own way, as others could live theirs, to worship God in what faith we chose, to be free in body and mind and for our children to be free. We fought only because the powers of evil had attacked these things.

I think those words are as true today as they were at that time. This is the kind of attitude that would animate any defence of Australia against external threat. We are a democracy that respects basic human rights and we must protect that. For that reason, there can be no selective loyalty when our whole society is in danger.

PARA.TAB: It would disturb me greatly if I believed that Australians were becoming selectively loyal. I do not believe that is so. I think Australians are loyal people and we should not be making it easy for others who may have various other motives to opt out at the sign of conflict. Liberal democracies are by their very nature worth fighting for. There can and should be respected conscientious objection to war, but not assent to a selective loyalty in time of direct threat to their independence and survival as free societies. For this reason, the Bill should be amended to remove this excessive and inappropriate circumstance of conscientious objection.

Conscription has moved from being an accepted form of defence to a last resort. We know that it is a last resort. People accept that it is a last resort. We should all hope that the circumstances in which this legislation would operate remain very much hypothetical. It should, however, reflect the patriotic necessity for the defence of Australia and without concessions that imply that commitment to our country for some would be an optional extra. I do not believe commitment to this country should ever be an optional extra, particularly in a time of war.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just listened to the usual lucid address from Senator Knowles, but there are some things about that address I would like to talk about. Senator Knowles referred to former Senator Vallentine. I was an admirer of former Senator Vallentine not so much for the causes she adopted but for the way she went about adopting them. She was often alone in supporting a cause. Something I always think is attractive and something to be admired in people is the fact that they can stand alone and nevertheless press on in support of the things they believe in. Indeed, she was often in a minority of one, but she put forward her many cases with great courage, great dignity and a readiness, which perhaps we all do not have, to put herself on the line.

Senator Knowles, as have other speakers, has put that in the context that that provision is there to suit particular ethnic groups. That is not correct. That provision arose from an excellent report from the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs entitled Conscientious Objection to Conscripted Military Service which was produced in 1985. The Chairman of that Committee was Senator Michael Tate, who has, of course, become an eminent Minister; Senator Robert Hill, who is now leader of the coalition in this place; Senator Nick Bolkus, who is now a Cabinet Minister; myself, who, I must confess, is the only one still on the Committee—

TALK.START.PARA: —A very distinguished senator, though.

—I thank Senator Cook. There was also Senator Alan Missen, who really was a towering figure in this chamber as a parliamentarian and, unfortunately, has since died; and Senator Christopher Puplick, as he then was, another eminent senator. PARA.TAB: I set that out because I wish to read from this report which that Committee sent to the Senate. On page 15 the recommendations read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Parliament should add to its present recognition of absolute conscientious belief, recognition of specific conscientious belief so as to grant exemption from participation in a particular military conflict where to be compelled by law to do so would violate the individual's sense of personal integrity.
The second recommendation states:

The Bill should not seek to limit the grounds upon which conscientious belief can be based and proved before an appropriate tribunal. That point went to the issue of whether people can have a conscientious objection on other than religious grounds and the Committee concluded that they can.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's for service in a situation like Vietnam, but that is no longer possible now.

—All I am saying is that that is the recommendation made by the Committee to this Senate. I do not want to add to or take away from that recommendation. It was not qualified in the way that Senator Teague is suggesting, certainly on my reading of the report.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague has asked where that came from. It was perhaps best expressed by a witness who came before the Committee, Professor Peter Singer, who is Professor of Philosophy at the Monash University. These passages are quoted in the report and these quotes found favour with the Committee. The passages state:

SPEECH.PARA: In my view the only possible definition of a conscientious belief is a belief based on a seriously held moral conviction. That is, of course, very broad and it is perhaps best understood if we see what it leaves out. What it leaves out most clearly are beliefs based on selfish desires of one sort or another, personal interest, belief based on emotions like fear or ambition perhaps. It also leaves out beliefs which are whimsical or based on impulse.

What is being made clear there is that the conscientious belief must be just that—a deeply held conviction from the heart and soul that informs the person who holds it with the greatest of conviction that he should not serve in a particular war. Professor Singer went on to say:

I believe that someone who opposed a particular war because they took the view that it could only add to suffering and the death of innocent civilians, without holding any religious basis for it, would be holding a conscientious objection to that particular war. A different war which it might be possible to fight by attacking only military targets they might not object to. So I would say that if we are to take seriously the notion of protecting conscience and giving way to people's conscientious beliefs then we must extend conscientious objection to those who hold a sincere moral conviction against taking part in a particular war. If we do not do that we are simply making an arbitrary distinction between two forms of conscientious belief which are equally conscientious.

He went on to say that, in fact, a person who has a conscientious objection to a specific war may—if you can talk in these terms—have more merit in his or her position, because that would have come from thinking out the issues involved, whereas a blanket objection is something that a person can hold without really analysing a particular situation. Many of the speeches made today have referred to specific situations and I think that is largely right.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make is that the provisions in the Bill that there ought be room for a person to make objection to a specific war on the grounds of conscientious objection, comes not from any multiculturalism or from any desire by anybody to cater for a particular group, but from the conviction that a person's conscience should not be violated, no matter what. I suppose that is the sort of thing that distinguishes us from the tyrannies that, fortunately, exist less often around the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except as far as trade unions are concerned.

—Senator Kemp has asked whether this applies to trade unions. Perhaps we are shifting to a different field, but there are specific provisions in the Industrial Relations Act which talk in terms of conscientious objections in the sense that this legislation does. I do not know of any union which would force a person who holds conscientious objections, in the sense they are talked about in the Bill now before us, to comply with a decision made by the majority, which is the way the unions operate.
—That is right.

—I remember that at one stage Senator Cook was a member of the Committee which drew up this report and, with his background in the union movement, he would be very used to the concept of conscientious objection as it played its part in the union movement. He would be able to confirm that what I have said about the union movement in terms of conscientious objection is correct.

PARA.TAB: There is one other point I wish to raise in this context. Clause 6 of the Bill reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 59 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by omitting `male';

That means that in the proper circumstances the women of this nation will be subject to conscription as are men. In my view that is a proper position. With the growth of technology in war and the sophistication with which war is conducted, there is no reason—if conscription is to be introduced during a crisis—why women, who are now as capable as men of running war machines, should not also be required to serve their country. I imagine that, were that tragic situation ever to arise, women would serve equally as well as men.

TALK.START.PARA: —The battlefield might be the safest place.

—Yes, given the ravages that the civilian populations are now put through. At times during the debate on this issue suggestions have been made that the Labor Party—the Party which is now in Government—through its history has not been perhaps as dedicated to the country's cause as others. I do not know whether that message was deliberately put forward, but at times it has come through in that way.

PARA.TAB: The answer that I as a member of the Labor Party would give is that there have been many great and heroic people, institutions and parties in the history of this country. During the great crisis in history of the Second World War people from all parties and of all beliefs fought mightily against the enemy. But it is to be remembered that, at the time this country was faced with its greatest threat from outside, the Party which led it through that crisis—of course with the cooperation of others—was the Party to which I belong, the ALP, and the great figure heading that Party at that time was John Curtin.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wanted and was a strong supporter of the Australian flag.

—Who, as Senator Kemp has properly said, was a strong supporter of the Australian flag at that time. At that point in time he saw that it represented what Australia was all about. However, the issue is whether 50 years later the flag still continues to do that. The flag is a symbol of what we stand for. Of course the flag is important, but more important is what we stand for—and the symbols will follow that. John Curtin was a great Australian, a great leader, who led a great nation to safety when it was facing its greatest crisis. So this side of the House certainly has nothing to apologise for in the part that it played in Australia's history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very daunting task to actually stand in the footsteps of Senator Vallentine and address a topic such as this. I believe it is very important to have a voice in relation to the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. I will be moving two amendments to this Bill when it comes to the committee stage. I wish to discuss the philosophical positions under the two principles which pertain to those amendments.

PARA.TAB: The first amendment I will be moving seeks to delete all reference to conscription in the Defence Act 1903. I will move this amendment because I believe there is no longer a place for conscription in the Australian defence forces, nor is there a place for conscripted military personnel anywhere in our world.

This option has not so far entered the debate. While it may not receive support, I would certainly plead that it receive urgent and considerate attention. Even though this voice might be a lone one, it may well be prophetic or a cutting edge that calls us to reconsider dramatically the direction that our security and defence thinking has taken over the last few years.

Nothing has brought home more powerfully the belief that there is no longer any place for conscripted military personnel than the Vietnam war and, more recently, the Gulf war. In both cases the side which was unable to win had enormous numbers of conscripted personnel. Indeed, before the start of the Gulf war much was made of the fact that Saddam Hussein's biggest problem was that he would have to all but hold guns at the head of his draftees in order to stop them from deserting.

In the Vietnam war, the American Army was all but torn apart, both at home and in Vietnam, by the enormous popular revolt and resistance against the draft. I do not think that even the most committed supporter of the American war effort in Vietnam would argue that there were not enormous problems with the fighting will of the many thousands of draftees. Even in the Gulf war, it was evident that the large numbers of reservists called into active duty by the US were not as well equipped in training or motivation to fulfil their duties; and that commanders had to take into account the composition of their forces when planning their strategies.

We also have to address the changing nature of war. An even more important lesson from the Gulf war should convince us that conscription is no longer necessary, let alone desirable. The Gulf war was not fought on the ground by large numbers of troops or naval personnel or by huge waves of air force planes in the air. The war was fought by relatively small groups of highly specialised, high technology weapons systems, operated by people who would best be described as technicians, not soldiers, sailors or pilots. If there are wars yet to come, they will be fought more and more that way.

With the nature of warfare changing so rapidly and with it becoming increasingly equipment oriented, there will be no place for conscripts in future wars. No defence force will be able to build its strategic planning on the basis that large numbers of untrained personnel will become part of the forces, when war has already begin, to be trained in the use of highly specialised equipment and be ready for active duty in the sort of timeframes in which war is already being fought now, much less in years to come, should it be necessary. The position I wish to present for consideration is that all reference to conscription be deleted from the Act and the amendment that I will move at the committee stage will allow that option to be chosen.

The second matter I wish to address relates to the conscientious objection amendment. I heartily support its inclusion as being a very enlightened, progressive step. However, I think that to make it available only to those who are conscripted and to be in a place where we are forcing defence forces to ignore their consciences is very questionable. The Government has proposed in this legislation new provisions for people to assert their conscientious objection to particular wars if they are being conscripted. I believe it is only logical that we extend these provisions to serving members of the armed forces. I believe that this is all the more important in light of the manner in which the Australian defence forces are promoting careers as a means of enticing young people to sign up.

More and more of the advertising of the defence forces is based on the idea that the Army, Royal Australian Navy or Royal Australian Air Force offers a glamorous career and an alternative to university which actually provides an income, accommodation and other opportunities while people are studying. I wonder if any honourable senator has ever seen a recruiting advertisement which actually says, `We will train you to be able to kill, and perhaps during your term with us you will actually get the chance, and you will not be able to exercise your conscience'. I believe that the permissibility of conscientious objection that has been raised in this amendment is very commendable but needs to be extended equally to those within our defence forces for all the excellent reasons that have been raised in the debate so far.

In the world as it is, not as it was, people have vastly different views of their government's foreign goals and styles of working. We cannot assume that a uniformity of opinion exists in the armed forces and we need to take this move towards selective conscientious objection even to assist those very armed forces when the possibility of war arises.

A few people have suggested as a way forward that such a move of selective conscientious objection being available to the defence forces as well as to conscripts would be unworkable. How could the armed forces ever plan anything if the possibility existed that some personnel would claim to hold a conscientious objection to a particular war? I believe that this has been overstated.

Conscientious objection is not an easy road to take, least of all when a country is actually at war. The process of facing the court and bringing forward a case which is convincing is not easy. The social pressures which are brought to bear on someone who chooses such a path are enormous, as anyone who has had contact with a war resister would know.

The time has long gone when the call to arms in Australia resulted in thousands queuing up to enrol in the armed forces. Likewise, fortunately, those who object to war on conscientious grounds are no longer vilified by all and sundry or presented with white feathers. Nevertheless, it is an extremely difficult road to travel. Furthermore, the numbers of conscientious objectors at any time—if history is some sort of guide—would be small. Indeed, if the numbers were high, it may well be an indication of a wrongful decision by government.

It may be instructive to consider the legislation presently before the US Congress. That legislation seeks to make similar provision for selective conscientious objection by members of the defence forces. Amongst other things, that legislation provides that those who claim conscientious objection to a war which is declared while they are on overseas duty will be sent back to the USA for their case to be heard. Likewise, those who are in the USA and in the armed forces when war is declared will have their case heard before there is any possibility of their being sent overseas. The provisions extend to members of the armed forces reserves, who were so much a part of the Gulf war.

The Gulf war demonstrated to me and many others that the possibility of a war being prosecuted on `just war' lines is very remote. This is largely a result of the ever increasing technology of weapons systems. It is now virtually impossible to satisfy that `just war' requirement that excessive force should not be used. The Gulf war demonstrated very clearly that the very nature of the weapons systems now being used can only result in excessive use of force.

In such a situation, it is more than possible that members of the defence forces will find themselves deeply disturbed by precisely such a war—one in which civilian casualties will inevitably be unacceptably high, and the devastation wreaked on the country under attack will be far in excess of the needs of the case. In some situations, people within the armed forces would be in a better position to follow their consciences in the light of the information they have in front of their eyes. The alternative to this amendment is that the armed forces will potentially face a situation of a revolt far greater than that carried out by one seaman during the Gulf war.

We need a new perspective. The emphasis of this Bill and the amendments—which I have already said I partially agree with—is not significant enough to change the perspective of the Bill. It is the wrong way around. The Cold War mentality is still being preserved. Now is the chance to re-examine what we mean by national security, and develop non-military forms of conflict resolution, rather than legislate for conscription and invasion scenarios.

In essence, we need to be putting money into training our diplomats in negotiation and language skills, rather than putting money aside for the ADF. As was pointed out in the ABC radio series on the new world order earlier this year, every dollar channelled from the Department of Defence to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is worth five times as much to the latter Department. What we spend on foreign language and negotiating skills for our diplomats does not even amount to the training of one FA18 pilot.

Talk of conscription and invasion ignores the fact that the whole nature of war has changed. A survey conducted in 1988 gave some idea of the scope of the current situation in the world. It reported that of a total of 111 states engaged in armed conflict, 63 of these conflicts were internal and a further 36 were categorised specifically as `wars of state formation' in which the conflict centred on issues concerning autonomy or secession, many of which involved ethnically related issues.

Since the publication of that report, the escalation of internal conflict in the former USSR, Eastern Europe, the Middle East, Asia and the Pacific projects an image of a world characterised increasingly by ethnically driven political fragmentation. Certainly it is true of this part of the world if we consider the situation in Bougainville, West Papua, East Timor, the South Moluccas, the Philippines, Cambodia, Burma, Sri Lanka, Kashmir and the Punjab. So why are we talking about military training and allowing the old warriors to harp on about the future of military training and the virtues of fighting old battles all over again?
I think we have to ask what we are teaching our children by continuing this line of thinking about defence and security. As the American anti-militarist Eugene Debs observed in 1916:

SPEECH.PARA: I would no more teach children military training than teach them arson, robbery or assassination.

Neither the State nor any other institution has the right to conscript young men and women for war. That, fundamentally, is why I oppose the amendment and support the deletion of conscription. Conscription is the mark of the slave.

PARA.TAB: For too long we have accepted that almost 10 per cent of our Budget should go on military spending, without even discussing the whole rationale for the military in today's world. It is perfectly true that we live in an unstable region, but virtually all of these conflicts are intrastate rather than interstate and certainly none pose a threat to Australia. Many old wars have been fought to a standstill and, at that point, we call in the United Nations to keep the peace.

I urge that we put the emphasis on war prevention, rather than clearing up the mess. For that, we need to develop skills other than training young men and women in the art of killing which, in the end, is what military training is all about. There is an enormous amount of hypocrisy and cant spoken about national defence. Frequently, politicians condemn groups or individuals who advocate the use of violence to achieve their ends, either at home or overseas. The dawn service on Anzac day dwells on the New Testament message of love and forgiving our enemies.

Another aspect of depriving people within the armed forces who are prepared to defend Australia is not allowing them the position where they can have conscientious objection to a particular war. We need to ask: what is the assumption underlying our refusal for that? If we cannot guarantee the positive motivation of all people in our defence force, we are the losers. We cannot deny them the fundamental civil liberty of applying their conscience to the position they are in.

I support the concept of defending Australia. I believe it is imperative to defend Australia; it is imperative to defend it in the best possible way. I want Australia defended in the best possible way, with an emphasis on peacemaking and on the prevention of war, not by a fall-back position of utilising numbers of people who are untrained and coercively drawn into outdated methods of warfare based on ancient history, where the winner is the one with the most cannon fodder. Nor do I want to be in a fall-back position in my country where the principle that people in the defence forces cannot exercise the fundamental civil liberty of following their conscience is part of the defence mentality of our nation.
