TALK.START.PARA: —It has been put to me that a senator's last speech in the chamber tends to be witty, amusing, apolitical and punctuated by a lifetime's anecdotes from the corridors of politics. But it seems that my early resignation and the reasons for it would make such a speech somewhat irrelevant both in purpose and in content. So I ask that you bear with a somewhat different tack as I simply tell you of my reasons for leaving and my enthusiasm for the future, albeit tempered with the knowledge of what I am leaving behind in Canberra and the size of the challenge ahead in South Australia.

PARA.TAB: I am, I admit with regret, leaving behind many people I have been proud to call my colleagues from both sides of the chamber. I refer to politicians who put people first, politicians who willingly put aside trenchant, philosophical backgrounds or positions to achieve in some instances—in many instances often not recognised by the public—a workable compromise for the good of Australia, and politicians with a capacity for long hours of hard, complex policy and committee work that the electorate just never knows of. For electors see only quick 30-second news service grabs from Question Time rather than the many hours of work put in by senators and members of Parliament—detailed hours, detailed office work—in the performances of their duties as representatives of the people. I refer to politicians who embrace change rather than hark to the past, to politicians who value the Senate process and who comprise people from all walks of life—I suppose one could say a snapshot of the Australian community. Looking around this chamber at the people in it, bearing in mind their backgrounds and qualifications, one must conclude that it is indeed a snapshot of the broader Australian community.

I am leaving behind a Senate staff which surely knows no equal in commitment to the Senate, in unswerving loyalty, professionalism and capacity for hard work, usually with quite unrealistic deadlines to meet. I should like to put on record my appreciation for the service of the Senate staff, their politeness and their courtesy at all times. It really does mean something when you turn up at those doors in the morning and you are greeted with, `Good morning'. The courtesies that are expressed by members of the staff in this place are really something that they should be proud of.
I have found cooperation from the other side of the chamber, both within committees—I suppose with one or two notable exceptions—

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder which one.

—Senator Kernot would well know the one notable exception that comes readily to mind. The cooperation during legislative research is particularly welcome, and in some instances perhaps unexpected. After all, I arrived here two years ago from a State scene in a lower house in which, under the Westminster system, adversarial politics took place. On most occasions it went well past the point of being cooperative; it was deliberately obstructionist in the processes of the Parliament. I have not seen that in the Senate, and that is something of which this chamber can be justly and rightly proud. So one might say, `Why are you going back? Why would you give up all of this?'
—Because you don't like Chinese food.

—Yes, I do like Chinese food, and I will not give the Chinese restaurant a plug. One of my New South Wales colleagues told me that when he heard on radio that I was going back, he considered it was one of Bob Carr's bad jokes. But it is not a joke, although I recognise it has created some astonishment in some quarters.

PARA.TAB: If anyone had said to me two years ago when I arrived that a return to South Australian State politics was on the cards, I would have laughed also. It was never my intention that my move to the Senate should be anything but committed, long term and successful. I hope those of you with whom I have worked during committee stages in this chamber have seen evidence of that commitment. I can assure you that it was no temporary exile in a foreign land.

I am not reticent about admitting that I had a goal of serving. I know that there will be a Hewson government after the next election. I had hoped and had a goal and objective of one day sitting on the front bench in a Hewson government. However, to use one of those dreadful and hackneyed political cliches, a week in politics is a long time. And so it was; just a week after I was given the No. 1 position on our State ticket by my Party in South Australia in early February, I was approached and asked whether I would consider returning to South Australia with a view to leading the Party in that State again in the mid year. Again, events gathered some momentum from those initial discussions. It was a difficult and, as some would say, a dangerous decision I had to make. I suppose that I made it as much with my heart as my head, and probably more. Call me parochial, if you like, but I feel passionately about the State of South Australia—the State in which I have grown up.

Longer ago than I care to remember, I attended Kadina Memorial High School, which had as its motto, `The dawn of opportunity'. I had been encouraged in my formative years never to put myself in a position where later I would have cause to say, `What if' or `If only'; in other words, as the school motto said, when the dawn of opportunity in life is there, one should grasp it. I suppose that, in the end, it was that kind of decision—no decision at all.

I guess I shall not hide the fact that my objective, goal and passion for South Australia extends to the determination to see a Liberal government there in due course. John Bannon's Labor Government no longer has a strange set of electoral boundaries. Mind you, they are not now absolutely fair; but they are fairer than they used to be. He no longer has any strange and suspect State Bank profits to hide behind in the future. In that respect, the level playing field is a little more level than it might have been in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —You won 52 per cent, didn't you, John?

—I am glad that Senator Teague reminded me of that. Yes, it was 52 per cent versus 48 per cent. However, with that figure next time around there will be no doubt that there will be a comprehensive Liberal win in the State of South Australia. If the polls are any indication of recent times, it will be a convincing win in South Australia.

PARA.TAB: I recognise the comradeship—I suppose that is how one would describe it—that I have enjoyed in Canberra of both those across the chamber and the Democrats. It definitely does not stretch to wishing me all the best as I seek to achieve a Liberal government in South Australia; that would be asking a little too much.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read this.

—Given some of the views of Senator West's colleagues as to the magnitude of the problems in South Australia, I think they wish that they were out of government rather than in government. I suppose that it would be almost like Senator Bolkus, who has always coveted the position of No. 1 ticket holder of the West Adelaide Football Club, a position which I am pleased to have held for a number of years and hopefully will continue to do so.
—They'll wake up some time.

—I hope that Senator Faulkner understands that it is my consuming passion to change government in South Australia. It is a great State. If ever there was a government in Australia that has forfeited its right to continue in government, it is in South Australia. The financial mismanagement in South Australia would leave Western Australia and Victoria behind.
—It must be bad, John.

—It is bad. The Government financial institution liabilities in South Australia as a percentage of gross State product happens to be this year, after the State Bank's $1.7 billion loss is factored into it, 99.8 per cent. Victoria's liability happens to be 24.5 per cent and everybody reckons it is bad in Victoria. Come into South Australia and have a look at the size of our debt. The net debt servicing requirement in South Australia as a percentage of gross State product is 3.3 per cent. It was 1.6 per cent in Victoria, after the State Bank of Victoria was sold, and it was 2.1 per cent prior to that sale.
—What about your bank?

—That is what I am saying. Our bank has significant liabilities, the extent of which, in terms of SGICs, really has not yet come to the surface. In November-December this year when the next round of statistics come out, the extent and size of the financial difficulties in South Australia will be clearly indicated. Someone recently offered me a background briefing on the extent of the problem in South Australia. After three and a half hours, this person said to me, `Now having seen a list, do you still want to go back there?'. I digress.

PARA.TAB: I suppose a decade of plastering over the cracks with high gloss has left a State infrastructure that really an earthquake could not have weakened more. The economic state of South Australia has been vandalised by the present Government. As clearly as it now appears, it cynically vandalised the State Bank for its own ends, as the Royal Commission is now clearly identifying. In fact, evidence before the Royal Commission points increasingly to the Government's using the bank to buy the 1989 State election. It bought votes at that election.

It seems that the Bannon Government viewed the bank as a money tap to be turned on at whatever volume was required to meet its political objectives. We know from evidence that it virtually raided all the bank's profits in the year 1988-89, the election year. It did so to the effect of $50m of tax cuts in its election Budget. To enable the Budget figures to be `juggled', in creative accounting terms, to achieve those cuts, it took an extra $30m from the bank in that election year. Previously, the Government had taken some 65 per cent of the bank profits—that is outrageous—which in 1988-89 would have amounted to $58m. In effect, that election year the Government took $88m from the State Bank.

I well remember moving an amendment to the State Bank Act when it was put up to preclude the Government from taking any greater than 50 per cent of the profits of the bank. John Bannon and the Labor Party refused to accept that amendment. Is it any wonder that we see in an election year that it puts that to one side and siphons everything off and says to the officers in the bank that they should in creative accounting terms make sure the profit matches the Budget requirements for that year? This is evidence before the royal commission now being exposed for Honest John in South Australia.

Talk about Honest John and credibility! It has now also been revealed that, during the election campaign, $2m of taxpayers' funds were used for the purpose of holding down State Bank home loan interest rates for the period of the election, provided that it did not appear in any balance sheets or reports to be tabled in Parliament. That is now on the State Bank royal commission evidence reports. There was a $2m transfer deal within the financial institutions of the Government to ensure that the interest rate movement on home loans did not occur during that State election campaign.

In other words, the Government took money from the pockets of people of its State and used their money in an attempt to buy their votes for the course of that last election. History will sadly record that, in the past decade, South Australia has achieved little but bread and circuses government housed in castles simply built on sand. That will be proved to be the case.

We made have a grand prix—which in itself is a good thing—but we now have the worst, most inefficient public transport system in the nation. We are aiming to have the multifunction polis become a centre of technology advancement and excellence, yet a national report has decried our education infrastructure as the worst in the nation. In an unforgivable move, we have stripped some $40m from the Better Cities program in one of the neediest electorates in South Australia to plant trees on the multifunction site at Gilman. When one considers that there are some $800m worth of earthworks to be done on that site, this $40m will be but a drop in the bucket. But, once again, it is about setting perceptions in the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the ones who put it there.
—I am clearly putting my point of view as it relates to the multifunction polis and the commitment of funds to it.
—Carry it through when you get back to South Australia.

—I look forward to Democrat preference flow in the by-election on 9 May to achieve that.While we are aiming for the Commonwealth Games, outside Adelaide less than five in 100 of our teenagers matriculate or manage to access further education. That is the worst record in the nation. Our castles, such as the State Bank and the State Government Insurance Commission, are having to be bailed out with taxpayers' money to the tune of $5,300 for every man, woman and child in South Australia. We have an interest bill of $600,000 a day every day of the year. We have added $186m extra to our debt servicing requirements simply because of the funds already injected into the State Bank bail-out.
—Look at the SGIC.
—Yes, as Senator Coulter says, the extent of the SGIC's difficulties is yet to be revealed.
—Twenty-four million for the building.

—The purchase and sale of some buildings deserve close analysis and scrutiny. If that amount of money had been spent on building up or refurbishing some of our State's infrastructure in the past decade, we would be a much better and more vibrant State. We would have schools that were not literally crumbling through neglect of maintenance; public hospitals with their wards open; safe rather than unsafe, pot-holed country roads; and, most importantly, we would have more people in work. In a State with an unemployment rate greater than 11.5 per cent, we have a massive problem with which to come to grips.

PARA.TAB: That $5,300 per person could have been a significant injection of energy rather than having to be applied to a debt from an insurance company and a bank—which supposedly had its heart in South Australia but was losing an arm and a leg interstate and overseas, and we, the taxpayers of South Australia, now have to pick up the bill. That energy would have created jobs and a future for South Australia, not the debilitating debt which we now have.

The period since the 1989 election whilst I have been in the Senate has seen not only Labor's duplicity exposed before the royal commission, but also a great deal of time and opportunity lost for the State. I have watched that with a great deal of frustration. However, during my time here I have gained a much greater appreciation of what South Australia must do to retain influence nationally. I am referring to such issues as the absolute necessity for transparency in government reporting and accounting.

In South Australia we have had the accounting standards and reporting mechanisms changed from year to year, because if you change them year to year it is very difficult to track what is happening with the accounting. It is well understood now why that has been the case. While the move is towards a far greater conformity and transparency in the presentation of government finances, the present South Australian Government has been strongly resisting—and this is recorded—such a move. In fact, South Australia has been described as the most negative of the States towards this development. Is it any wonder why? It certainly will not be so under any future Liberal government.

We also need to set about reforming Federal-State financial relations, and reforming government at the State level to ensure that the States maintain a relevant and real role in our federal system. Reducing our State debt is an absolute priority. In South Australia, in particular, we need to reform government trading enterprises to bring economic benefit, financial contribution and vitality to the State, setting in place a formalised financial monitoring system. Then the track record and performance of a government trading enterprise in South Australia could be measured against one in Victoria, one in New South Wales and one in Queensland. There would be a benchmark upon which we could judge these government trading enterprises, if it is inappropriate to privatise them—but I will not go back to 1985 and the need for privatisation and what the difference might have been had those policies been in place now.

My time in the Senate has also clearly shown me the present South Australian Government's abdication of its economic responsibility. Even more than its counterparts in Victoria and Western Australia, it has created a crisis in confidence in the ability of State governments to play an effective role in the revival of the regional and national economies. Because of such bad financial management we once again hear increasing rumblings about the lack of need for State governments in Australia.

Canberra has renewed my determination to regain for South Australia the reputation we once had for pride in our achievements, confidence in our future and prudence in economic management. I am going back there because I want to turn some of the negatives that I have been talking about into positives. It is a great challenge but I believe it can be done because we have in South Australia, per capita, the most skilled work force in the nation. We have a manufacturing and agricultural base which can and must be diversified to take account of being part of a more internationalised or global economy. We are a lucky State. We do not have to change our ways totally; the basis is there.

Diversification is the key to answering the question on everybody's lips: where will the jobs come from in the future? For example, in South Australia, where so many jobs rely on the automotive industry, we ought to look urgently at diversifying far more into car components for diverse world markets rather than concentrating on the assembly stage for just one or two manufacturers. There is another example, with which I am sure no-one in this Chamber would disagree, and that is the wisdom of value adding for our agricultural base in South Australia.Import replacement is as important as our export markets but it has not been happening. Either we have stood still in manufacturing and diversification or we have gone backwards.

While John Bannon has been chasing grand prix he was not thinking of jobs for the future in our crucial automotive manufacturing area. He should have been doing both. While he was chasing expansion for the State Bank outside South Australia—and, outside Australia, he has been chasing the Commonwealth Games—he was not thinking of encouraging niche markets, new crops or value adding in agriculture. He should have been; it was possible and it was necessary that he should have been doing both. The need for such policy work is not new. It has been looming on the horizon as being essential for many years. However, I desist from pursuing a whole range of what I consider should be policy initiatives for the future. Some of those should remain for the election campaign, whenever that might be.

I have enjoyed my time in Canberra—that mad mix of frustration and job satisfaction that the Senate provides. I have listened to many fascinating debates—skilful, intelligent and knowledgeable. Being here with you has broadened my horizons and given me an objectivity that has been of benefit in being able to step out of the State arena for that two years and look back upon it a little more objectively than I could when I was in it.

Being part of this chamber and the proceedings of this Parliament—in particular, to see the Parliament's requirements of the Executive in calling it accountable and responsible for its actions—has been a great insight. Some may well argue that the system here in this Federal Parliament is not sufficient, but I can assure them that if they do not think it is in check here, they should go to some of the State parliaments, particularly South Australia, because it ain't in check at all over there.

If we had had the checks and balances of this system of parliament applied to the South Australian Government and Executive the State of South Australia might not have been in the position in which it is now. We would not have had governments and premiers saying, `We cannot disclose this information to you because it is commercially confidential'. That is an excuse not to explain decisions and actions of government which have ultimately brought about the massive problems and difficulties that we have in South Australia.

I have been fortunate to be here among you to learn. It has been an invaluable experience. It has been a maturing process in some instances. I have been fortunate to be part of the canvas of the big picture, if only for a short time. I think I return to South Australia as a wiser and, hopefully, better politician for my involvement here with you and the processes of this Parliament. It has been an honour to work with so many people. I have appreciated the friendship and companionship of many of my colleagues in this place. As someone said to me once, `You will be moving to Canberra; appreciate your colleagues, their contribution, their capacity and the people with whom you will work'. That has been very true. I have appreciated the contribution, capacity, companionship and quality of the colleagues in this place.

I have a genuine concern for the future of Australia and I have a passionate concern for the future of my home State, South Australia. To that extent, my endeavours will be directed towards bringing about a more positive future. I wish all honourable senators and members of this chamber well in their pursuit. I think it is a genuine pursuit, although misguided in policy direction sometimes. I think all people come to this chamber with a genuine, sincere pursuit to make some contribution, to make Australia a better place. I wish you well in your endeavours in that regard. I will watch with great interest the proceedings of this chamber and this Parliament in the future with a tinge of sadness—

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have your work cut out.
—We'll send you the Hansard each day!
—However, I look forward to returning to Canberra on a regular basis—for the Premiers conferences each year!

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Olsen came to this chamber two years ago he was certainly no novice to parliamentary politics. I am quite sure that, as we have heard expressed this afternoon, in whatever sphere—the national or the State—he will always display that very real commitment to the democratic parliamentary system which we value so much in this great Commonwealth of Australia. I have no doubt that Senator Olsen will continue to make a contribution to our democracy.

PARA.TAB: As I say, Senator Olsen certainly did not need to undertake any apprenticeship, and it was quite clear from his earliest contributions here that he was able to master the Standing Orders and the procedures and the ethos of this place very quickly. In my observation, that enabled him to very quickly make articulate and forceful and, at times, emotional contributions to the major debates in this chamber.

I have had no experience of Senator Olsen's work on committees, but I imagine that in the Estimates committees and the standing committees of this place he also brought the same abilities—the forcefulness, the articulate manner in which he puts forward a case—to those deliberations, and I am sure that the committees benefited from his contributions.As Senator Olsen said, whilst this chamber is certainly adversarial, it has a different manner or mode of conducting that particular conflict. It does enable even backbenchers in Opposition, through the committee system, to make contributions, which is an opportunity certainly not available in many of the chambers in the State parliaments.

Senator Olsen said, `You may call me parochial if you like', but as a Tasmanian I think that is perhaps being quite unfair. I can understand the very strong emotional ties to his home State which have led him to make the decision which he announced, to our great astonishment, some time ago. I believe that all of us can understand the challenge of returning to do something in his home State, something which he feels very deeply, and he will go back and make that contribution.

The rehearsal of a speech from the stump which dominated the latter part of his remarks this afternoon is perhaps best passed over as not being the most considered of his contributions in this chamber. Senator Olsen, we will certainly remember you for more temperate contributions. I can understand the sense of challenge that you feel in returning to South Australia. I wish you all the success which you deserve, and I certainly look forward to your return.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I wish Senator Olsen all the best in his future endeavours. I recognise that there are many slips `twixt cup and lip and he still has some distance to go before he accepts and drinks from that chalice which I think he has set before himself. I genuinely hope that he does succeed in all those steps which still lie before him.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator Olsen entirely that the plight of South Australia is really desperate. That State has had a Premier and a government which have been more interested in the appearances of success than in real achievement. At each election we have seen the bread and circuses trotted out and we have seen the State fall from one which had considerable influence—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where have your preferences been going?

—We do not give out preferences at all, in any way. We always have double-sided `How to Vote' cards and we leave preferences with the voter where they should be. I believe Senator Olsen has made a very valuable contribution to this Senate. I have always found him an extremely gentlemanly and gentle person and a very considerate person. I know he will take those qualities back to South Australia where I believe they are desperately needed.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that have become very obvious, or should have become very obvious, to anybody who has observed this Parliament—this Senate and the House of Representatives—is that for the proper operation of the democratic process it is necessary to have an effective and varied expression of opinion. That is one of the things that we have in this Senate which is not present in the House of Representatives and which is not present in a lot of other parliamentary chambers around this country.

In the case of South Australia, I do not think Senator Olsen will mind me saying that in recent years the Opposition over there has been somewhat weak on many points. I think Senator Olsen will do a lot to stiffen and make more effective the existing Opposition. I really meant what I said, because it is a situation in which a change of government would not in any sense be a damaging occurrence in South Australia. My personal view is that very considerable corruption has gone on there, probably as significant as that which has occurred in Western Australia and Queensland. That fact is largely coming out in the commission which is still in progress and before which the Premier and a number of other prominent people still have to give evidence.

There are a number of other examples of this, some of which Senator Olsen did not mention. There is very considerable evidence of corruption and that really does need to be cleaned up before South Australia can be put back on the road to recovery. Senator Olsen will have a very useful role to play, not least, dare I mention, in stiffening the Opposition's resolve in South Australia in relation to that disastrous proposal on the MFP where, as he indicated, $40m has been swung out of the better cities program, something that South Australia could desperately need—and he identified public transport as something that has been atrociously run down in Adelaide—and which may well be followed by up to $800m if the present Government is allowed to get away with it.
I wish Senator Olsen all the best. We will certainly miss him here. I think he will make a very useful contribution to South Australia when he returns there.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join other honourable senators, particularly on behalf of my colleagues in the National Party within the coalition, in wishing Senator Olsen the very best in his change of political stature and political involvement. It has been a pleasure to work with Senator Olsen in so many areas of coalition activity, in this chamber, in the work of the Parliament and, of course, in the many areas of joint party endeavours between the National Party and the Liberal Party. I am sure that all of my colleagues, both in this chamber and in the House of Representatives, join me in posing the challenge to Senator Olsen that he will no doubt face and take on as he returns to the South Australian Parliament and, in particular, as he heads into government in South Australia.

PARA.TAB: On a personal level, I look forward to a change of government in this place, when, hopefully, I may be the Minister for Northern Australia working with the then Premier for South Australia on many endeavours across that common time zone that we share. For instance, projects such as ensuring that we have a land bridge with Asia, which may well involve a very comprehensive program that would hopefully lead to the commercial development of an Alice Springs to Darwin railway, would also serve in joining together the very strong interests of the Northern Territory and South Australia. I look forward to continuing that particular relationship in a common partnership between the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party and the South Australian Liberal Party.

Senator Olsen has given particular assistance to the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party and particular encouragement. That is a challenge that we look forward to developing with him in the future. My colleagues within the National Party in this Parliament join me in wishing Senator Olsen all the very best in his future endeavours.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is an occasion on which we traditionally thank retiring senators for their contributions to the chamber and wish them well for the future. I do so in both instances in this case with particular interest. Senator Olsen may not have been with us long but he quickly established a major contribution to the Opposition and to participation within the chamber. Senator Tate might not know it, but he was making an equal contribution within the processes of the Opposition outside the chamber. I am sure that he would have played a senior role within a Hewson government, which is shortly to be.

PARA.TAB: It is therefore with some disappointment that I have to say some final words on the parting of Senator Olsen from Federal politics. He does, however, go back to State politics. As has been said by Senator Tate, this is a States House. We all seek to advance the interests of our State in the way in which we think we are best able. Most of us are here to do it through the Federal process. Some feel that they can more effectively achieve a better outcome for their State through participation in the State parliament itself. Senator Olsen has made that choice.

As a South Australian, I am particularly interested in his doing well. He mentioned the South Australian health system, which is in a shambles, and the education system, which is in an enormous mess. I have one son doing this strange SACE system at the moment. I cannot make sense of it, let alone can the children who have to participate within it. Senator Olsen knows of the law and justice problems in South Australia. One can go on without getting to the appalling financial mess in which South Australia finds itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come and visit New South Wales and have your eyes opened.

—If I went to New South Wales, I would find more people going into jobs than we can in South Australia. Senator West should visit South Australia and travel down the major arterial roads and look at the shop after shop which is vacant. There are record bankruptcies, record unemployment rates and record youth unemployment in South Australia. It is an appalling mess. That is the legacy of the Bannon Labor Government in South Australia. The sooner it is got rid of, the better for all South Australians, including me. That is my vested interest in seeing Senator Olsen return to State politics to make a major contribution in getting rid of Bannon and getting rid of that Labor Government and giving South Australia some decent government again.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge the endorsement that Senator Olsen seems to have received from the Australian Democrats today. I want to think about whether I regard that as to his benefit or not. At first blush, it is an interesting endorsement. If that is to be carried through to the next State election, it might carry with it a few remaining votes, and they would, nevertheless, be appreciated.

I also acknowledge the presence of both Julie and Ben in the public gallery today. One reason for the success of the Olsens in politics has been the way in which they have approached this often very difficult business as a team. The strength of the Olsen family will continue to be a key in John's success and therefore to the benefit of the Liberal Party and the people of South Australia.

John, you depart after a short period here. We are disappointed to see you go but we thank you for the contribution that you have made. We particularly wish you well in the future in South Australia, not only personally but in the responsibilities that you will again take up in the State Parliament. We very much look forward to a victory and the end of the Labor Government in South Australia and a return to the chance of prosperity for South Australians again.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a close friend of John Olsen, I rise to wish him every success in his return to the State Parliament and to the service of my own State of South Australia, all the more ably and with all the more close attention. Like Senator Hill, I fully endorse all that Senator Olsen said in his valedictory speech. I acknowledge his positive contribution to the Senate. Some 20 years ago we served together on the State Executive of the Liberal Party in South Australia. At one stage, Senator Hill, Senator Olsen and I were all together in what was a heyday of policy development. That policy was eventually implemented with the re-election of the Liberal Government under Fraser and in the election of the Tonkin Government. John Olsen served as a Minister in the Tonkin Government. He then served as Leader of the Opposition most valiantly, and with every support from the rank and file of the Liberal Party, for eight years. In the last election he won 52 per cent of the vote of the people of my State. Because of the way that the boundaries were drawn—
—Gerrymandered.

—Because of the way they were gerrymandered, it unfortunately led to the injustice that John is not currently serving as Premier. He would have avoided the mess that we are currently in. It is desperate that a person of John's qualities make the contribution in our State Parliament as the chief contributor to a Liberal government that we need.

PARA.TAB: I genuinely wish Senator Olsen every success in the future. Like my colleague, I acknowledge that Julie Olsen, who is in the gallery, and the Olsens' three children, are very much a part of John's motivation and support. Julie is an exemplar, a standard for all spouses of members of parliament, State and Federal, like my own wife, Kathy, who is also in the gallery or watching in my room. I appreciate the enormous help that Julie Olsen has given to John while he has been here in the Senate, especially in some difficulties over the last couple of years of a family and personal nature and also in every sense politically. I support the remarks of colleagues in this chamber in wishing John Olsen every success in his return to South Australian politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I first heard the news that Senator John Olsen was moving back to South Australia, I also thought it was just a bad joke. I am very disappointed that he is leaving the Senate, but I admit that the gain that the people of South Australia have is only at the expense of the loss to the people in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I am not quite sure whether Senator Olsen will set up my favourite committee system—the Estimates committee system—when he returns to South Australia. But whether one is in government or opposition, I think Estimates committees are a very good way in which to keep the Executive accountable. I would advise Senator Olsen to set up such a committee system when he goes back to South Australia.

I hope that when Senator Olsen comes up to Canberra to Premiers Conferences he will have a cup of tea in the Whips' rooms. We will miss you very much, John, and we would certainly like you to do that.

Senator Olsen has painted a very clear picture of the problems in South Australia. I am sure that if Senator Knowles were on her feet she could paint an equally clear picture of the tragedies in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Things are looking better in Tasmania.

—I am sure that if Senator Rod Kemp were here, he would paint a very clear picture for us of what is happening in Victoria. I do not want to go into all of the problems that a Labor government foisted onto Tasmania. But the Liberals have had a very clear victory and Labor has been dumped by the Tasmanian people. As Senator Hill says, things are now looking very much better for the people of Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: I must admit that Senator Olsen has some wonderful quotes from Senator Coulter to use at the next election in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But is it to his benefit?

—I am not sure whether it is to his benefit. Perhaps they can be used to push the preferences towards the Liberals. Senator Olsen could say that, while the Democrats are sitting on the fence once again, they did in their more sober moments admit that the Liberals would be a far better choice than the present incumbent government.

PARA.TAB: John, I wish you all that you hope to attain in the next 12 months—I presume that there will be an election within that period. I trust that you will be back in Canberra to attend a Premiers Conference very soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator John Olsen will be missed in this place because he has brought to it an intellect and integrity that has enhanced our side of politics. I know that South Australia will gain from the commitment that he has made to return to his State as leader of his party again and to lead his party to success at the polls, despite the gerrymander that exists.

PARA.TAB: I listened very attentively to what Senator Coulter had to say. I must say that perhaps I listened more attentively than I might have done on another occasion. I found it gratifying that someone had the honesty to say that South Australia is in such an appalling mess. Across party lines, Senator Coulter recognised that John Olsen would bring an integrity and a strength of spirit and intellect that could right many of the wrongs in that State.

I have known John Olsen for a long time—before he and I became members of this place—through the party organisation. John Olsen was a member of the party organisation at a time when I was Vice-President of the Liberal Party. I suppose that strong bonds are built by supporting others who are in the parliamentary arena. Bonds grow through an understanding of the commitment that is necessary to be made. I acknowledge that in the chamber today.

I say to you John: every success not only to you but to your State under the statesmanlike leadership that you will undoubtedly bring when you become Premier. I hope that you will come and visit us when you attend Premiers Conferences.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the Whips, I would also like to be associated with the comments that have been made this afternoon. Senator Reid and I have enjoyed an association with Senator Olsen over what now seems to be such a short time. I have to say from the Whips' point of view that it has been a most enjoyable association.
—Me too.

—I am sorry—I also include Senator Brownhill, who is the National Party Whip. Senator Olsen has been a participator. He has been very much a team player. He is one of the people whom we have always been able to go to and say, `John, will you help us out?'. John has always been there to help us out. For that, Senator Olsen, we are very grateful.

PARA.TAB: Along with being a participator, Senator Olsen has always been a performer. We will remember for some time the work that Senator Olsen has carried out on many parliamentary committees in the short time that he has been here. I particularly refer to the committee which dealt with the gagging of free speech. Senator Olsen had a particularly good handle on that whole issue. He fought hard virtually all day and literally all night for what he believed.

On a personal note, I would also like to thank Senator Olsen for his friendship. It is a friendship that I will cherish. Like many others, I have known Senator Olsen for a considerable time. I knew him long before he came into this chamber. Thank you, John, for your friendship. I have talked about Senator Olsen being a participator and a performer. I look forward very much to the day when I can call him Premier Olsen instead of Senator Olsen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues in wishing Senator Olsen every success in his return to South Australian politics. As has been said, he has spent barely two years with us in this place. It is amazing how quickly that time has gone. It seems only yesterday that John joined us in the Senate to replace our South Australian colleague, Tony Messner.

PARA.TAB: As has been said by a number of my colleagues this afternoon, John very quickly made his mark in this chamber. His aggressive approach to debate was obviously well honed in the House of Assembly in South Australia, particularly in his days there as leader. This was of great benefit to the Opposition's approach to debate in this chamber on a number of important issues.

Of course, had the South Australian electoral boundaries been fair, John would not be going back to South Australia to become Premier—he would already be Premier of South Australia. A Liberal government in South Australia under his leadership will right the enormous problems which have already been mentioned in this discussion this afternoon.

Perhaps, John, it is just a little fortuitous that you did not quite get there last time. The blame for all of the problems which have become so public since the last election can be well and truly sheeted home to where it belongs—to Premier Bannon and his Govern-

SPEECH.PARA: ment. The problems that have arisen with regard to the State Bank, the SGRC, Workcover and the general state of the South Australian economy at the present time can be directly sheeted home to the Labor Government, which in fact set in place their causes well before the 1989 election. Of course, these problems have only become so much more evident since that election and since the Labor Government was returned to office.

PARA.TAB: So let us hope, John, that you will reap the reward which should have been yours at the last election. As I said, the cause of those problems—the Bannon Labor Government—is now so much more evident.

I wish you well in your return to South Australian politics. I look forward to working very closely with you in the State campaign that will develop over the next 12 to 18 months. I will support you in that regard. I trust that you will be back here to visit us when you attend Premiers Conferences.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think if we go for long enough tonight we will be able to just about talk out the time that is made available for the adjournment debate. I would just like to make a couple of comments.

PARA.TAB: Over the last two years I have enjoyed very much having John as a partner at the desk that we share in this chamber. It does not seem like two years. I first met John before I came to this place, when he was Leader of the Opposition in South Australia.

I always remember very well—and I have mentioned it more than once—a photo of John when he was dressed in a frogman's outfit trying to gain some publicity for an election campaign. I look forward to visiting John when he is Premier of South Australia. I endorse all those very generous remarks that have been made throughout this chamber. It seems that I am going to be sitting here on my own again for quite some time. All the very best, John.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues in saying that it has been a privilege for me to serve with John Olsen in the time I have been here. I had admired John from afar when he had been Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, but it was something of chance and fate that we both ended up here at much the same time. I say `fate' because in any other democracy in the whole of the world we would never have met. Wherever you get 52 per cent of the vote you usually win and John Olsen would have been Premier. I suppose South Australia's temporary loss—and I emphasise temporary—has been my personal gain. I very much appreciate the associations I have had with John, a man of integrity and very great ability, and a man whom I consider to be a very close friend.

PARA.TAB: Coming from Queensland, I have never had the opportunity of being on first name terms with anyone who was ever likely to be Premier of the State. I might say that John Olsen will be the first State Premier with whom I will be able to be on first name terms. I wish you, John, all the best in your future career as the South Australian Premier.

TALK.START.PARA: —During his period here, we have seen Senator Olsen get up on frequent occasions to address this chamber on a broad range of issues. Nobody can say that he is a one-issue person. He has a grasp of quite a diverse area of policy matters. He has presented these views and his policies with strength. I am sure we all agree that he has contributed a higher standard to debates in this place than have most people—certainly higher than I have.

PARA.TAB: Very often the forcefulness of his interventions have resulted in some criticism from the other side of the chamber. He has received some bagging, I suppose you could call it, from the other side of the chamber. I have looked over there from time to time and have seen how he cops it. I often look to see how people cop the baggings they get in this chamber. Invariably, he has worn that disarming smile—more of an engaging grin—which has been rather off-putting to some of the people doing the bagging. I think more of us should engage that particular kind of grin and cop it sweet as he has often done.

I have heard Senator Olsen in action in Estimates committees. I recall his pursuing questions through the Estimates Committee dealing with the estimates for AIDAB. He raised questions on the provision of ultrasound machines to the State Family Planning Commission of China, where the ratio of girls to boys under two years of age has fallen to 89 girls for every 100 boys. It is most distressing, and one wonders what our ultrasound machines are being used for in China. Are they detecting the sex of those unborn female children before they are aborted? That is the sort of perception Senator Olsen has about things that have drastic effects, not only here in this country but also in other countries.

Personally, I have got on very well with John. Unfortunately, the occasions to enjoy the conviviality of his company have not arisen as much as I would have liked. That is one of the problems with this place, of course. It was different in the old place. My office was the closest to the billiard room and the bar, and everybody had to go past my office to get to them. One does not get the opportunities here that we got in the other place to rub shoulders with colleagues and to have a general chat about things. Unfortunately, there have been only few occasions when that has been possible. On those occasions I found John's company to be very stimulating and convivial.
I would like to convey my personal best wishes to John and my appreciation of his contributions to this place. I know that these are shared by Senator Chamarette.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join my colleagues in their praise of John Olsen in the short career he has had in this Parliament. My major memory of John, apart from the friendship that he has shown to me, is the time we served together on the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. The sad thing about this is that he will not be in this chamber when Senator Bolkus comes in and moves major amendments to that Bill which will effectively end that particular disgraceful policy which the Government brought forward. I think it is very clear that the predictions Senator Olsen made before that particular committee have already eventuated as we have seen from the by-elections and the State elections which have been held.

PARA.TAB: My view, which I am sure is endorsed by all my colleagues here, John, is that you would have had a great career in Federal politics. You will now have a great career in State politics and we wish you well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Senate because I can see that Senator Collins is getting more and more agitated. But I do want to associate myself with the remarks of my colleagues from all sides of the chamber in relation to my friend and colleague Senator John Olsen. John has given me, as a relatively young and new member of the Senate, some inspiration. We entered the Senate at the same time and John has provided that inspiration. I know that John would have made a fantastic member of the first Hewson Government, and I feel sure that our neighbouring State in South Australia will be well led by an Olsen Liberal Government for many years to come.

PARA.TAB: One benefit of John's leaving the Senate is that we will no longer have confusion between the names `Olsen' and `Alston' on the paging system. The last point I want to make is that it is not so bad having to sit right out here in the upper reaches of the back bench when one is in such esteemed company as that of Senator John Olsen. I look forward to his buying me a drink in the Premier's suite of the South Australian Parliament. I will miss his company, both in the chamber and at a very famous little Chinese restaurant just down the road in Manuka.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not let an occasion like this pass me by without saying some nice words about Senator Olsen who has made such a wonderful contribution to this place in the two years that he has been here. The biggest contribution he made was the work he did in exposing the Government's ad ban and the curtailing of free speech. That will be with us for a long time. He really exposed the dangers of the legislation put forward by the Government on the advertising ban.

PARA.TAB: I wish Senator Olsen well in his new career—or his old career—

TALK.START.PARA: —Recycled.

—His old career recycled. That is correct, it is a recycled career but, as a result of the expertise and experience he has gained in this place, I am sure that in the future he will be one of the most outstanding Premiers of South Australia. I wish him and his family well. Obviously, he will be closer to his family when working from Adelaide rather than from this far-distant city of Canberra and that will be good for his family. In closing, I emphasise that obviously he will make a big contribution in the future. I thank him for the contribution he has made in this place and wish him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my colleagues opposite for allowing me to vacate the Chair in order to say a few words to Senator Olsen. I will miss the occasions of sitting beside Senator Olsen in aeroplanes to Adelaide when we argued everything. I do not know that we found too many points of agreement, but we were able to disagree with some mannerliness. I will miss that.

PARA.TAB: I simply say for the record, that if there are claims of winning an election in South Australia with less than 50 per cent of the vote, it is not without precedent in that State.
