DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Response by Governments to the Final Report

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 31 March 1992, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —By and large, the Opposition supports the Government's response, as it supported the findings of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. We do have some problems with the response and the findings, one of which is a major problem. There is no doubt that the two areas of health and employment in particular are the key areas on which Australia will be judged by its response.

PARA.TAB: But the issues are much wider than that. The Royal Commission will stand as the monumental work to date in examining the position of Aboriginal Australians within the broader Australian society. Hopefully, it will be looked on as the time when Australia took the opportunity to form a partnership for the advancement of Aboriginal people. We should ensure that it will be looked on not as a lost opportunity and show us to be a nation which is too immature to put aside petty differences in order to achieve something of real benefit to the whole nation.

The report to which the Government has responded is a frank and honest assessment of the attitudes of Aboriginal Australia, the position that Aboriginals occupy in our society and the attitudes of the broader Australian community. It is also a fairly frank examination of our past and why we are where we are today. It does not seek to instil guilt or apportion blame. The Opposition is pleased about that and believes that the breast beating and apportionment of blame are unnecessary and useless distractions from the main issues.

In many areas this report coldly and clinically dissects the facts and lays them on the table for proper discussion. Commissioner Johnston, having spent many years of his life in this investigation, states in the report:

SPEECH.PARA: I say very frankly that when I started upon my work in this commission, I had some knowledge of the way broad policy had evolved to the detriment of Aboriginal people and some idea of the consequences. But until I examined the files of the people who died and the other material which has come before the Commission and listened to Aboriginal people speaking, I had no conception of the degree of pin-pricking domination, abuse of personal power, utter paternalism, open contempt and total indifference with which so many Aboriginal people were visited on a day to day basis. It's hard to convey the understanding, because each particular story takes time and space to tell.
Nonetheless, he did in fact take some time and space to tell it. As my colleague and spokesman on Aboriginal Affairs in the House of Representatives, Dr Wooldridge, said:

Some years ago there was significant violence in the Kempsey area of New South Wales. The local council commissioned a report from a clinical psychologist into the basis of the violence and the racial tensions in the area. This report is illuminating reading. It states that the single most important factor in the poor race relations in the Kempsey area was the bitterness that the Aboriginal people felt. It was not bitterness for what happened 150 years ago or 100 years ago; it was bitterness for what happened in recent living memory.

This is one of the important issues that emerges from this report. It is all very well saying that the whole problem emerged from the way in which the early settlers dealt with and brutalised the Aboriginal people. This is a much more recent problem pointing to a whole number of needs to reverse recent attitudes.

PARA.TAB: These attitudes are manifest and it is clear that many of them are only in the process of change. In New South Wales until 1964 an Aboriginal child could be actively excluded from school on the basis of race. In the Northern Territory until 1965 Aboriginal people needed permission to marry. In Western Australia until 1968 Aboriginal children were still being forcibly removed from their parents against the will of the parents. In Queensland until the mid-1960s Aborigines had to carry what was in effect a passport if they wanted to leave a reserve. If they were caught without such a document exempting them from the Aborigines Protection Act, they were arrested and returned to the reservation.

The legacy of all this is a population marginalised, dispersed, dispossessed and very poorly educated. The first Aboriginal man in Australia to graduate from university, Charles Perkins, did so in 1966. That should be compared with the fact that the first New Zealand Maori to do the same was in 1901, two generations earlier. It is incumbent on us in this Parliament to see that this petty tyranny, the pin-pricking domination and utter paternalism, of which Commissioner Johnston speaks in his report, is finally put behind us. In fact, we do not have any other choice because today the debate on Aboriginal affairs is an international one.

This Royal Commission came into being partly in response to a campaign which had been waged since 1984 by the Committee to Defend Black Rights. This Committee had been founded after widespread dissatisfaction with the verdict in the John Pat case in Western Australia. John Pat died in police custody in Roebourne in 1983, and the ABC focused national attention on this case and other deaths in custody in a Four Corners program in September 1985. That program drew angry responses from the Western Australian Police Union with accusations of bias and inaccuracy.

Australia was also subject to growing international pressure in the middle of 1987. For example, the London-based anti-slavery movement concluded a two-month study of Australia's Aboriginal population and reported:

SPEECH.PARA: Widespread allegations of physical and psychological abuse of Aborigines in custody. . . including young women and children.
No matter what the accuracy of like reports, they created world wide concerns. This particular report was tabled at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Vancouver.

PARA.TAB: The Royal Commission was the last of a series of responses made by the Government to quell growing public anger. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs had been given a brief to inquire into Aboriginal involvement within the criminal justice system, but this lapsed on the calling of the 1987 election. Thus, with the growing number of deaths, in the end there was no choice and the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody was set up almost as a requirement in October 1987.

This Royal Commission, however, has not been without its critics and throughout its three-year history has attracted its fair share of publicity. There is no doubt it was expensive; in the end it cost over $30m. In many ways, however, it was really 99 individual royal commissions as the commissioners were required to report individually on every one of the 99 deaths in custody. The Commission allowed us as a country, fortunately, during this expensive investigation to have some breathing space, a sort of circuit-breaker, which allowed us to really look at why so many Aborigines were in custody and why they appeared to be dying so frequently.

The research in the report showed early on that Aborigines were 29 times more likely to be in gaol than non-Aborigines. But, for any given instance of imprisonment, the chance of an Aborigine dying in custody was actually slightly less than that of a European person. This is a key point that people must remember: Aborigines in custody are no more likely to die in custody than a non-Aboriginal person. So it was then that we had to look as a nation at other factors.

It was not so much then a problem of what happens after someone goes to gaol but rather the high numbers of Aboriginal people who are in gaol in the first place. The fact that Aborigines are 29 times more likely to be in prison than non-Aborigines, as was the case in 1987 and is still the case in many parts of Australia, makes Aboriginal people one of the most imprisoned races in the world. However, this figure is somewhat misleading because the age profile of Aboriginal people is significantly different from that of the general Australian population. The birth rate is higher and life expectancy is less. No doubt this skewed age profile would contribute towards this high imprisonment ratio.

But, unfortunately, in the Royal Commission report the whole of the difference is consistently ascribed to race. That simply is self-evidently wrong. In other words, it ascribes that because someone is an Aborigine, he has a 29-times higher likelihood of being put in gaol. That is clearly not the situation. The report which makes this claim, in fact, reveals what the answer really is. It shows us something of the poverty in Aboriginal society. No doubt a good proportion of that huge increase in the prospects of an Aborigine being in gaol is due to poverty rather than Aboriginality. How much so we do not know because that is an inadequate area of examination by the Royal Commission.

It would have been interesting to look at imprisonment rates in non-Aboriginal poverty areas to make a proper comparison. This was not done. Had it been done, I suspect we would have found that a good part of this larger proportion of Aborigines in custody could be explained by poverty. It is a pity that this study was not done because so much of the debate today is on technical methods to keep Aborigines out of gaol, whereas it might have been on ways of addressing Aboriginal poverty as a preventive measure.

What does the Royal Commission tell us of these 99 people who died in custody? This I believe is the major issue. It is, in fact, a rather chilling profile. Of the 99 people, 88 were males and 11 were females. The mean age at the time of death was 32. Of the 99, only two had completed secondary education and only one had completed vocational training at TAFE. Eighty three were unemployed at the time of their last detention—and I am interested to see the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) nod his head; that is, in my view, the essential matter. Forty three had been separated as children from their natural families by the action of government—and that certainly could be an element, but fortunately a disappearing one. In Western Australia and Queensland, over half had been separated from their natural families; in New South Wales just on half. Of the 99, 37 had died of natural causes while in gaol; the average age of those dying in this way was 30. So the health of this group of people ranged from poor to very poor—another factor as to why, other than race, there was this huge proportion of Aboriginal people dying in custody and being in gaol.

I now turn to the 339 recommendations themselves. These cover an enormous variety of areas. Many are purely custodial in nature and cover areas as diverse as relations with the police, youth and justice, diversion of arrest, bail issues, courts, custody and Aboriginal legal services. These generally receive unanimous support by the Commonwealth and Territory governments. Other recommendations relate to all areas of endeavour in Aboriginal affairs, housing and infrastructure through health, jobs and schooling. On issues relating to law and justice, the recommendations are unexceptionable and sensible.

Many of the recommendations relating to diversion from arrest, bail and representation before the court are ones which really should apply, however, to the whole community, not just the Aboriginal segment of it. This applies particularly to bail issues, breath testing of people taken into custody, and families of deceased being entitled to legal representation at coronial inquiries. That these recommendations should have wider application does not mean we do not support their introduction for Aboriginal people. It simply means that we hope that governments at all levels might look at their broader application.

In the area of health the recommendations made are generally sensible and desirable. In fact, some of the recommendations are long overdue. Recommendation 45 proposing a special national survey of the social, demographic, health and economic characteristics of Australia's Aboriginal population is welcomed. Such a survey should be carried out in conjunction with a census so that it would provide the most meaningful data.

In so much of Aboriginal affairs, our endeavour has been merely based on guesswork or anecdotal evidence. We have to be honest with ourselves as to whether or not our policies are achieving what we wish them to, and this special survey will give us a basis on which we can determine our benchmarks and look at our successes or otherwise in the programs for the future. Some of the recommendations have been overtaken by events. For example, recommendation 339 states that all governments support the process of reconciliation—and this has now happened.

The majority of other recommendations from the Royal Commission relate to ATSIC and those Aboriginal education programs within DEET. The majority of these appear relevant and sensible. The agreement by the Commonwealth and States on the majority of them reflects the fact that there is a growing agreement as to what is successful and what is not.

However, one part of the report has the potential to cause major conflict. This conflict may be more perceived than real and may not be insurmountable. It relates to recommendation 188, which talks about ensuring that the self-determination principle is applied in the design and implementation of any policy. The Opposition is not inclined to open up old wounds, but this matter is very serious so far as we are concerned. The report talks a great deal about self-determination; indeed, it comes through every single volume of the report. In the overview, Commissioner Johnston, when talking of the requirements to adhere to the principles of self-determination, states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a concept which—I think—does not have a precise definition.

The problem is that Commissioner Johnston is just plain wrong. The principle of self-determination has a specific and precise meaning in international law. It is contained in the first article of the United Nations Charter of 1945 and also in the first article of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The United Nations Charter states:
. . . to develop friendly relations among nations, based on respect for the principles of equal rights and self-determination of peoples . . .
The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights states:
All peoples have the right to self-determination. By virtue of that right, they freely determine their political status.

In both these texts, the word `peoples' was chosen over contending terms of minorities or nations. In international law, indigenous peoples are not a people for the meaning of these two texts. There are people of Kuwait who have a right to self-determination, but that applies to the nation as a whole, not a minority within it, for example—even an indigenous minority.

PARA.TAB: This is not just of historical interest. In the draft declaration of the Working Group on Indigenous Peoples, the usage of the word `peoples' is specifically precluded by the United Nations from conferring the rights associated with the word in international law. The demand for self-determination for the Aboriginal people in Australia is thus inextricably tied up with international law, with the idea of an independent sovereign state. It is not adapted to degrees of autonomy less than a full autonomous self-government. We can talk of degrees of autonomy and devolution, but there are no degrees of sovereign statehood. Thus, the idea of self-determination within the wider state or under a wider law is in itself contradictory.

It would be much easier to pretend that self-determination or the principle of self-determination meant whatever one wished it to mean and that there was room for argument. But in international law self-determination applies to sovereign states, and neither the Labor Party nor the coalition has ever suggested that we should be talking about dividing Australia's sovereignty. I suspect that the concept that we talk of in self-management and the concept the Government talks of in self-determination are similar concepts but using different words.

When the Royal Commission talks of policies of self-determination over the last 20 years, it fails to recognise that these have been policies of one political party. It has not been a continuous policy of successive governments, nor a continuing policy of successive State governments. However, it has been a policy of Labor State and Federal governments.

The coalition believes that it is desirable for Aboriginal people, in matters relating to their own internal and local affairs, to have the greatest possible degree of autonomy, consistent with obligations to the broader community. Our support for ATSIC and our long held policy position that Aboriginal people have the right, as a right, to choose to live a traditional lifestyle and to preserve their culture, support our view that when Aboriginal people have control over these matters that affect their day-to-day lives, they have by far the greatest chance of developing self-reliance, independence, dignity and choice. There is in international law an emerging concept of internal self-determination. Perhaps in the future this will offer us a way out.

There are other areas of concern about the Royal Commission report and the Government response to it. I raise these as concerns, not as criticisms, in the hope that they can provide a constructive point of view as to the limitations that the coalition sees with the approach being taken at the moment. These concerns relate to three areas: the first is the limitation of government; the second is the challenge of helping Aboriginal people move from a welfare dependant state; and the third is the administration of Aboriginal affairs and Aboriginal organisations.

The Government alone will never solve the challenge facing Aboriginal Australians. This is clearly recognised in the Royal Commission where, in the overview, Commissioner Johnston talks of three essential prerequisites to Aboriginal people having control over their lives and their communities. His first essential prerequisite, and the most crucial, is the desire and capacity of Aboriginal people to put an end to their disadvantaged situation and to take control of their lives. He says that there can be no other way. Only the Aboriginal people can in the final analysis ensure their own future.

The second prerequisite is assistance from the broad society, and this basically means assistance from government with the support of the electorate or at least without its opposition. According to the Commissioner, the third prerequisite is having in place an established method and procedure whereby the broader society can supply the assistance and the Aboriginal society can receive it without a welfare dependant position being established between the two groups. In effect, Commissioner Johnston is talking about a partnership between the Australian Government, the Aboriginal people and the broader community; and there is simply no other way.

By and large, the rest of the report relates to what government can or should do. This is a pity because no amount of governmental assistance in Aboriginal education, for example, will be successful if Aboriginal parents still do not want to send their children to school. No amount of money spent on programs to combat petrol sniffing or substance abuse will work unless the community wishes to take responsibility for what is going on in its midst.

I do not believe that we yet have a partnership in this country. It is what we desperately need and what we should work towards. If we have a belief, as I seem to read in the Royal Commission report or seem to read in the Government's response to this stage, that the Government alone has the capacity to turn this around, then we are wrong and we will fail, as we have failed previously. Money alone will not fix the problem. Money is important for what it can achieve in real, tangible, positive benefits on the ground for Aboriginal people. In all of the discussions of the report and the Government's response to it, accountability relates to the way we spend the money but not so much on what the money actually achieves. In the majority of instances where ATSIC and DEET have performance indicators, these performance indicators relate to the timely disbursement of money, not what the money achieves.

This is where we have to have a total turnaround in thinking in this nation. We will miss the point on real accountability if we are merely talking about spending the money. The question has to be: are we being effective in what we are doing? The only issue must be: does it work? I must say that we have a long way to go on this score.

Another concern is: how do we help Aboriginal people move from the position where they are dependent on government to a position where they are self-reliant? Until we face up to this, all other issues are secondary. We understand that the Minister is to make a speech in three months time, after discussions with the States, involving a further report when this issue will be addressed. The Opposition is pleased to note that the Royal Commission mentions this in its introduction. Unfortunately, the concept seems to get lost after that introduction.

As we say, it is not an issue of money. No-one in his right mind will say that another $50m a year will make the difference either way between welfare dependence and self-reliance. The problem here fundamentally is one of attitude, on both sides: the attitude in the broader Australian community to supply the support needed for Aboriginal people, not just financial support, but encouragement, patience and understanding for Aboriginal people to develop an economic base. It may also require a change in attitude in many Aboriginal people. As Commissioner Johnston said, there is the desire to put an end to their disadvantaged situation and take control of their own lives.

The Opposition looks forward to the Minister's response in three months time and seeing how the Government will help Aboriginal people develop an independent economic base. After the development of a partnership, development of an economic base is the greatest challenge we face. If we do not face it, self-management or self-determination—whatever we want to call it—is reduced to talking about how Aborigines control the government money given to them.

Another area of concern relates to the administration of programs and Aboriginal organisations. This is vital because these are the vehicles by which benefits pass to people in the community. Aboriginal programs in the Department of Employment, Education and Training appear to be a real shambles. In recent years, successive reports by the Auditor-General on DEET programs have shown insufficient verification checks for applications, insufficient information on clients' application forms, a lack of coordination with other departments and no procedures to avoid the duplication of payments.

The most recent Auditor-General's report stated that auditing was not undertaken in relation to $80m worth of expenditure under Aboriginal education supplementary assistance because auditing had revealed that departmental records were not adequate to determine whether payments were valid or accurate. DEET accepted this. In its own words:

SPEECH.PARA: Sufficient documentary evidence was unable to be located to support the expenditure relating to this program.

We are talking about $80m a year. Accountability has to start at home. Unless the Federal Government can be accountable for its own expenditure in these departments that it has control over, we cannot reasonably ask for the same sort of accountability within Aboriginal organisations.

PARA.TAB: The biggest initiatives in the Government's response to the report were in the areas of Aboriginal legal services. The extra funding to meet the main recommendations of the Royal Commission will be channelled through Aboriginal legal services. Yet Aboriginal legal services are structures that are not open and transparent. Many produce no annual reports, despite their being repeatedly requested to do so. ATSIC, itself, generally has no idea whether the money it is handing over is being used effectively and wisely. It hands it over, closes its eyes, crosses its fingers and hopes it will work. Not long ago, ATSIC had to take the New South Wales Aboriginal Legal Service to court to recover $94,000 that a couple of its directors had spent on a one-week jaunt around England.

I return to the report in general. The Government's response is a monumental work. Collating 339 responses from eight governments is no easy feat. The Opposition commends the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, for his work on this. On the Federal level, we often disagree with the Government. However, we have made an effort to look for common ground, and we have found much of it. Nevertheless, it is disappointing that the response of so many of the States has appeared to be self-serving and publicity seeking. They have not taken the same initiative that we have tried to take at a Federal level.

This report offers a great opportunity to take a step forward. We really must take advantage of it. The Opposition believes that we need a framework for a significantly new approach to the administration of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs under the next coalition government to address Aboriginal disadvantage, based on a partnership between the Australian Government and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We particularly need to address clear objectives such as an improvement in Aboriginal health, the provision of housing and infrastructure, Aboriginal education, Aboriginal economic development and cultural survival.

We must understand that if Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are to be given the opportunity to move from dependence on welfare and government to a position of self-reliance, it is essential that they be given the opportunity to develop a sound economic base. We must recognise the importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation in the decisions which affect their lives and the determination of local priorities. There must be an absolute requirement for a focus on outcomes rather than outputs; open and transparent decision making; organisations receiving government money to provide services in an efficient and equitable manner; and accountability at all levels of service delivery.

All this will need a decentralised administration with devolution of decision making powers at a local level, effective performance and accountability arrangements and the clarification of the role of the Minister and his or her relationship with ATSIC. We believe that such an approach will go a long way towards creating a fairer and more coherent program for Aboriginal Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 May 1991 the Melbourne Herald-Sun published an editorial which led to the Chief Commissioner of the Victorian Police, Mr Kel Glare, issuing proceedings against it in the Supreme Court claiming damages for libel. On 10 April 1992 a jury of six found that Mr Glare had been defamed, that there was no truth in the allegations made against him, and that a defence of fair comment had no validity. It awarded him $165,000, the highest amount ever recovered in a defamation action in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: On 18 April 1992 the Herald-Sun published the following editorial:

Last week, a jury of four women and two men found that the Herald-Sun had defamed police Chief Commissioner Kel Glare in an editorial on the Tennis Australia affair and ordered this newspaper to pay him $165,000 damages.

Mr Glare claimed that a May 17, 1991 editorial defamed him as `corrupt' and a `crook cop' by suggesting he had protected Labor `mates' by not prosecuting senior union officials who sought $10,000 from Tennis Australia to ensure the Ford Australian Open would be free from protests.

The Herald-Sun argued that the editorial only asked Mr Glare to make public the reasons why there were no prosecutions, that it suggested the Director of Public Prosecutions investigate, and that a full open public inquiry into the matter be conducted.
This newspaper did not back off from its views during the trial, and, because of the defamation hearing, the information it sought for its readers more than 12 months ago can at last be published.

The newspaper expressed no regret in that editorial for the wrong it had done the Chief Commissioner. It gave no hint of any remorse for its unlawful behaviour. To the contrary, it suggested that it had acted correctly because it caused confidential information to be made public. It justified illicit conduct on the basis that its readers thereby had made available to them material they would not otherwise have had.

There are times when breaching the law can achieve a worthy purpose—Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King showed that—but resort to such a strategy is in any circumstances a grave matter. Where it is undertaken by a rich and powerful company, especially one publishing a newspaper with enormous influence, there is reason for the utmost concern. On this occasion that was particularly well founded.

In its editorial of 18 April the Herald-Sun made it clear that the obtaining of the private information therein referred to made the besmirching of a man's name worthwhile. Having been told by a jury in the clearest of terms that it had grievously traduced the reputation of Victoria's highest ranked police officer, the newspaper answered by praising itself for achieving its illegitimate purpose. This is not a worthy breach of the law.

The Ten Commandments are at the foundation of our civilisation. They set out principles which most people throughout the world would hold to be fundamental to a proper society. One of them enjoins us all not to bear false witness against our neighbours. From time to time the media does harm to people's reputations by publishing false material about them. Given that it must rely on sources subject to all the frailties of human nature, that it must meet deadlines in making its material public, that it is serviced by men and women who like all others are capable of error, this is to be expected.

Often once an error is identified the media involved will correct it and that is the end of the matter. At other times the issues raised by the publication need to be resolved by a court. What rarely happens is for a perpetrator of a libel to maintain the propriety of its conduct after a verdict is delivered against it.

It is one thing to defame a person by mistake; it is another to bear false witness against an honourable man and then not resile from that action when shown to be wrong. The Herald-Sun shows a strange sense of values when it pays tribute to itself for causing private information to be made public through its own wrongful act. It was wrong according to both the common law and the Ten Commandments.

The stance taken by the Herald-Sun does not spring from some desire to do evil. It is not controlled by people contemptuous of the law, indifferent to morals, vicious in intent. Rather its false and damaging assault on Mr Glare's character resulted from those in charge of the publication seeing themselves as the real protectors of the public welfare—as the truly virtuous, as the all-knowing, as the all-wise. Nobody else, be he or she a judge, a minister, a commissioner of police, a senior administrator, a managing director, a sporting champion, a great artist, a professor, a union secretary, a leader in his or her profession, can match their omniscience, their righteousness, their sagacity.

The media for a long time now has seen itself as the moral guardian of society, as the repository of all knowledge, as the fount of all wisdom. Anthony Trollope anticipated much of what I now say in the middle of the last century. Chapter 14 of his novel The Warden is entitled `Mount Olympus', referring to the place where a fictional newspaper, the Jupiter, is published. The following is quoted from it:

SPEECH.PARA: From here issue the only known infallible bulls for the guidance of British souls and bodies. This little court is the Vatican of England. Here reigns a pope, self-nominated, self-consecrated—ay, and much stranger too—self-believing!—a pope whom, if you cannot obey him, I would advise you to disobey as silently as possible; a pope hitherto afraid of no Luther; a pope who manages his own inquisition, who punishes unbelievers as no most skilful inquisitor of Spain ever dreamt of doing—one who can excommunicate thoroughly, fearfully, radically; put you beyond the pale of men's charity; make you odious to your dearest friends, and turn you into a monster to be pointed at by the finger!

PARA.TAB: Oh heavens! and this is Mount Olympus!

It is a fact amazing to ordinary mortals that the Jupiter is never wrong. With what endless care, with what unsparing labour, do we not strive to get together for our great national council the men most fitting to compose it. And how we fail! Parliament is always wrong: look at the Jupiter, and see how futile are their meetings, how vain their council, how needless all their trouble! With what pride do we regard our chief ministers, the great servants of state, the oligarchs of the nation on whose wisdom we lean, to whom we look for guidance in our difficulties! But what are they to the writers of the Jupiter? They hold council together and with anxious thought painfully elaborate their country's good; but when all is done, the Jupiter declares that all is nought. Why should we look to Lord John Russell—why should we regard Palmerston and Gladstone, when Tom Towers—

SPEECH.PARA: Tom Towers was the editor of the Jupiter—

without a struggle can put us right? Look at our generals, what faults they make; at our admirals, how inactive they are. What money, honesty, and science can do, is done; and yet how badly are our troops brought together, fed, conveyed, clothed, armed, and managed. The most excellent of our good men do their best to man our ships, with the assistance of all possible external appliances; but in vain. All, all is wrong—alas! alas! Tom Towers, and he alone, knows all about it. Why, oh why, ye earthly ministers, why have ye not followed more closely this heaven-sent messenger that is among us?

PARA.TAB: There is ongoing pressure for reform of the law of defamation. Whatever changes are made should not abridge the rights of those who are libelled or slandered. People must have proper protection against a rich and powerful media capable of bringing their reputation to ruin, of destroying their careers, of leaving their lives in tatters. A free and democratic society calls for that safeguard as a minimum. It is often needed to save us from the righteous.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer:

PARA.TAB: (1) How is labour utilisation treated in the Treasury's econometric modelling.
(2) In relation to the employment and unemployment projections contained in One Nation, what assumptions were made concerning changes in labour utilisation.
(3) Of the 800 000 jobs the One Nation document claims will be created over the next five years, how many will be full-time.
(4) If the 800 000 figure is for equivalent full-time jobs, how many additional Australians will be in full and part-time jobs at the end of the five year period compared with the current number.
(5) In modelling the employment projections for One Nation, what immigration intakes were assumed for each of the next five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to Senator Alston's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1) In the medium term scenario employment and unemployment are determined by labour demand and supply.
The labour demand equation is based on aggregate hours worked by all employed persons, rather than the number of employed persons. The equation relates the demand for labour (expressed in hours) to:
non-dwelling output;
real labour costs (including payroll tax) adjusted for underlying productivity; and
trend underlying productivity.
Labour supply is related to the adult population and the participation rate. The participation rate is modelled as a function of:
the employment ratio (capturing an encouraged worker effect); and
a time trend (capturing the trend increase in the participation rate).
(2) The key assumptions adopted in the scenario in relation to the labour market are:
underlying productivity growth would increase by around 1 1/2 per cent per year, in line with the experience of the past two decades;
nominal wages growth of around 4 per cent per year; and
a continuation of the trend decline in the average hours worked per person employed.

(3) The 800 000 figure refers to total employment, which includes both full-time and part-time employed persons. As the labour demand equation underlying the medium term scenario is based on hours worked, it is not possible to allocate the employment growth between full-time and part-time jobs without making further assumptions regarding trends in average hours worked per full-time and part-time employed person.

The actual split between full and part time employment is likely to be influenced by a range of factors, including demographics and the preferences of employees and employers. The slight trend decline in average hours worked assumed implies, all other things being equal, some trend increase in the proportion of part-time workers.
(4) See answer to question (3).
(5) The technical assumption made for net immigration is consistent with the planned 1991-92 gross program intake of around 111,000.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the Treasury's estimate of the cost to revenue if all people aged 65 years and over were to receive the same tax rebate that aged pensioners currently do.

(2) What would be the cost to revenue if all people aged 65 years and over, whose income per annum is under $25,000 if they are single and under $40,000 (combined) if they are married, were given the same tax rebates that age pensioners currently receive.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: (1) Access to the pensioner rebate is restricted to persons receiving a full or part Australian age or service pension. The level of pensioner rebate received is determined by the level of taxable income of the pensioner. The pensioner rebate is calculated to enable pensioners to earn income up to the income test free area and pay no income tax. The rebate then reduces by 12.5 cents for each dollar of taxable income in excess of this level.

If the income test for the pensioner rebate were removed, so that access to the full pensioner rebate was extended to all persons aged 65 years and over, the estimated cost to revenue of the extension would be $275 million in 1991-92.

If access to the pensioner rebate were extended to all persons aged 65 years and over on the basis of the current income test, the estimated cost to revenue of the extension would be $60 million in 1991-92. The estimated cost would then relate to the extension of pension benefits to aged persons who meet the income test but are presently excluded from receiving an Australian social security pension on other grounds such as residency or the assets test.

(2) If access to the pensioner rebate were extended to all persons aged 65 years and over, but eligibility restricted to single taxpayers with incomes less than $25,000 and married taxpayers with combined incomes less than $40,000 the estimated cost to revenue of the extension would be $200 million in 1991-92.

This estimate does not include provision for tapering the rebate beyond the income test limits specified in the question and assumes that the current income test is not applied. (Application of the existing income test would reduce the estimated cost to revenue to $60 million in 1991-92 since the rebate would be phased-out before the income limits specified in the question are reached.)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What will be the total cost of the training component of the Formal Training Allowance (FTA) paid in 1991-92 and 1992-93.
(2) Was the training component of the FTA introduced to provide an incentive for the unemployed to undergo training.

(3) What is the rationale behind continuing to pay the $30 weekly training component of FTA given that long-term unemployed recipients must now sign Newstart agreements with the Commonwealth Employment Service, agreements which often require training to be undertaken as a precondition for receipt of the Newstart allowance.
(4) In respect of which Government training programs is the FTA paid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In 1991-92 the total cost of the training component of Formal Training Assistance (FTA) will be approximately $17.7 million. In 1992-93 it is expected that some $18 million will be spent on the FTA training component.

(2) FTA is paid to participants of formal training courses approved through Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) labour market programs. FTA consists of a living component (equivalent to a participant's entitlement to Job Search Allowance or Newstart Allowance (JSA/ NSA), a training component ($30 per week for full-time trainees over 21 years and sole parent pensioners) and ancillary allowances such as fares for remote clients, Living-Away-From-Home Allowance and compulsory course costs.

The FTA training component was not introduced to provide an incentive for the unemployed to undergo training; it was introduced to contribute towards the additional costs associated with undertaking formal training, for example daily transport costs and meals away from home.

(3) Those job seekers with Newstart agreements may be required to participate in formal training in order to improve their employment prospects. The $30 FTA training component is paid in recognition of the added costs of participating in training. The training component forms part of the Government's undertaking under Newstart agreements to assist jobseekers to obtain employment.

ANSWER.PARA: The training component is not paid to other participants under 21 years in order to more closely align FTA with AUSTUDY provisions. This reflects the Government's concern that there not be any financial incentive for young people to forgo longterm secondary and tertiary educational opportunities in favour of short-term training options. Young people are assisted with the additional costs of participating in training through the FTA ancillary allowances. However, processing of this assistance is administratively more costly than payment of the training component.

PARA.TAB: (4) FTA is payable to clients participating in formal training under the following DEET labour market programs:
Employment Access Program (JOBTRAIN and Special Intervention components);
SkillShare (structured skills training);
Training for Aboriginals Program (TAP);
Labour Adjustment Programs;
New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS);
Innovative Training Projects—National Skills; and
Special Assistance Program.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Report of the Suspect Illegal Entrant Vessel (SIEV) investigation released by the Customs Department recently:
(1) What part did the Department of Defence play in this investigation.

(2) What was the status of the relevant Defence assets in the Coastwatch operation, specifically, were they briefed on the likelihood of the landing and were they used or available for use in the operation; if not why not, if so, what was their role and what was the assessment of the value of their contribution.
(3) Were Defence elements on routine operations in the area briefed about the possible landing.
(4) Are there any difficulties in integrating Defence equipment, ships or aircraft with Coastwatch assets during operations or in planning for operations.
(5) Did Defence provide intelligence about the vessel at Sumba, its replacements, its crew and passengers; if so, what part did it play and why was the information inadequate, if not, why not.
(6) Does Defence have any contingency plans to cope with situations such as this; if so, are the plans integrated with those of the police, customs and other agencies in the region.
(7) Is Defence involved in `risk analysis techniques'; if so, in what way; if not, why not.
(8) Does Defence agree with the reports' judgment that there were little or no serious long-term considerations given to a deliberate landing and entry into the Kimberley region.

(9) The report admits that in regard to inter-agency communications `liaison and co-operation arrangements could be even better structured and streamlined', does Defence agree with this assessment, if so, why; if not, why not.

(10) In relation to the ground search (a) were any Defence elements involved in this operation; and (b) were any Defence elements requested to help in the search; if so, what part did they play and how effective was their contribution; if they were requested but not provided, why were they not provided, if they were not requested, were they offered.

(11) Does NORFORCE patrol the area where the ground search took place; if so, (a) how often; and (b) are their patrol reports and/or terrain assessments made available to other agencies, if so, what use were they in the ground operations; if not, why not.

(12) In relation to the persons who landed from the vessel: (a) have Defence personnel been involved in their debrief; (b) what is known of their prior knowledge of the country and conditions before they landed; (c) what navigation aids did they have; and (d) if they had navigation aids, what was the quality and effectiveness of such aids.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Defence supported the investigation by making available officers and information required by the investigating team.

(2) The operational authority of the patrol boat force in northern Australia was briefed to be aware of the possible arrival of a boatload of illegal entrants and that information was in turn passed on to the patrol boats. Patrol boats are available at all times to assist the civil authorities and the only impediments to gaining that assistance are usually weather, the urgency of the request, and the time and distance equation between the patrol boat and the location concerned. In this particular case, HMAS CESSNOCK, was directed to the vessel and members of the ship's company searched the vessel and the immediate area of the landing. Aside from evidence of the landing no entrants were found as they had moved inland by this stage. In assessing the value of this contribution, the use of a patrol boat was the most expeditious means available in the circumstances and the search was effective.

(3) As noted in 2 above, the operational authority of the patrol boat force in northern Australia was briefed to be aware of the possible arrival of a boatload of illegal entrants and that information was in turn passed on to the patrol boats.

(4) From the Defence perspective it is considered that the planning of the use of ADF units in the civil surveillance program has reached a high degree of efficiency. Officers from the major headquarters of the ADF and their civilian equivalents, meet on a formal basis each month in Canberra to match the bids for support from the civil agencies with the Defence and civil resources available. In reality, there is inevitably a gap between the resources available and the bids received but this is managed by making judgments on the priority of each request. With regard to the operational integration of Coastwatch and the ADF, major improvements in the processing of requests for assistance have been made in the past few years. The passage of operational information between Coastwatch aircraft and Navy patrol boats has also been improved with a special communications plan and it is intended to improve communications security with the purchase of data encryption devices for the patrol boat force.

(5) As is indicated in the Report, Defence provided relevant information to Coastwatch. It is the practice of this Government, and previous Governments, not to comment on intelligence matters, nor to confirm or deny such specific allegations.
(6) The ADF does not have any contingency plans for the landing of illegal immigrants. If the civil authorities require support for a contingency plan the ADF would assist as best it could.
(7) Defence uses risk analysis techniques in project planning and management. Risk assessments are made in such areas as contracting, finance, fraud exposure, technology and scheduling.
(8) As in Part 6, Defence is not the lead department for considering Coastwatch matters and in this case I defer to the judgment made in the Report.
(9) Yes, for the reasons outlined in the fourth paragraph on Page 11 of the subject Report.
(10) a. HMAS CESSNOCK searched the vicinity of the landing site at Montague Sound and a RAAF Caribou transport aircraft ferried aviation fuel to the helicopters based at King Edward River Station.
b. HMAS CESSNOCK searched the vicinity of the landing site on 16 January 1992. It was the only means available at the time and it is considered that the search was effective.

(11) a. NORFORCE infrequently patrols the area where the search took place. The last patrol was five years ago; there are no current plans to patrol because of doubts as to the effectiveness of ground patrols in that area.
b. Patrol reports and/or terrain assessments are available to other regional based agencies, on request. In this particular case no request was made for patrol reports or terrain assessments.
(12) a. Defence personnel were not involved in the debrief of the illegal immigrants; they were debriefed by civil authorities.
b, c. Since Defence was not involved in the debriefing process.
d. this question should be directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

(2) Does this mean that over the twelve month period July 1991 to June 1992 some people may be paying as much as $492 out of their own pocket, $246 of which they would not have had to pay had the financial year to calendar year change not been introduced; if so, what action will be taken to ensure that those disadvantaged are properly compensated?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A person who had no gap payments in the first half of 1991, and who reached the safety net limit of $246 in the second half of 1991 could be faced with further payments of up to $246 in the period 1 January to 31 December 1992 before the safety net again took effect. To the extent that a person who reached the safety net threshold did so because of costs incurred in the second half of the relevant accounting period this situation is no different from the arrangements which have applied since 1984.

(2) This means that over the twelve month period July 1991 to June 1992 some individuals may be paying as much as $492 in gap costs. This occurrence would be possible under any safety net arrangement which operated on an annual basis if a twelve month period is selected which does not coincide with the basis of the safety net. For this reason it is important to look at the out of pocket expenses incurred over a broader timeframe. In the case outlined by Senator Newman, no more than $492 would be paid over the entire period from 1 January 1991 to 31 December 1992, a total of 24 months.

The Government has made substantial improvements to the Medicare safety net by extending its provisions to cover registered families on the same basis that individuals were previously covered. The main reason for the shift from a financial year to a calendar year was to enable early introduction of this major improvement.

The change in the safety net to a calendar year basis was introduced retrospectively from 1 January 1991 to minimise the potential for individuals to feel disadvantaged. The retrospective introduction of the calendar year basis ensures that for services provided in the 1991 calendar year, no individual will have paid more than $246 in gap costs.

From 1 January 1992 the safety net was extended to include gap costs incurred by family members rather than just individuals. This change will mean that many people, including those who reached the safety net threshold in the latter half of 1991 are likely to reach the threshold earlier in the safety net accounting year than they would have under the previous individual safety net provisions. They and their families will be subsequently covered for the rest of the calendar year.

The Government is aware nevertheless that some people feel disadvantaged by the introduction of a calendar year basis safety net. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has asked his Department to examine the position and advise him on what action, if any, is appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 2 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to families which pay more than $296 in gap payments in any given calendar year:
(1) Do families need to register with Medicare for the rebate in the rebate scheme before they can apply to review the 100 per cent scheduled fee; if so, how many have done so.
(2) How many families have now applied for the full rebate because they have exceeded the $246 gap payment.
(3) How many families did the Government estimate would have applied to receive the 100 per cent scheduled fee at this point in the calendar year.
(4) Has the necessary documentation to be used by applicants been forwarded to all Medicare offices throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Families need to register with Medicare to be eligible for higher benefits under the Safety Net Scheme. Once families approach the $246 Safety Net threshold, they are also required to confirm that their family composition has not changed;
572,381 families were registered with Medicare for Safety Net purposes as at 10 April 1992.
(2) All families have substantiated gap payments of $246 or over (as at 10 April 1992).

(3) The Government did not prepare an estimate of the number of families who would have qualified for the 100 per cent scheduled fee at this point in the calendar year. The Government's estimates for the cost of extending the Safety Net to families and changing it to a calendar year were calculated on the basis of the full year effect of the changes and the part year effect of the transitional arrangements. The estimates were not calculated on a month by month basis.

(4) To facilitate family registration, Safety Net Family Registration Forms were included in the Medicare information brochures that were forwarded to 6.3 million households in Australia in November 1991. A further 1/2 million forms were printed and distributed to Medicare branch offices.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: ANZ Meko Frigates: Maintenance and Repair Contracts

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will AMECON be eligible to bid for maintenance and repair contracts for the ANZ Meko frigates after they enter service; if so: (a) what levels of maintenance and repair would AMECON be eligible to bid for; and (b) what proportion of the maintenance and repair work for the frigates would AMECON be eligible to perform: if not, why not.
(2) Has AMECON expressed interest, formally or informally, in bidding for maintenance and repair contracts for the ANZ Meko frigates.

(3) Is the claim made by an Australian Defence Industries spokesperson, as reported in the "Australian Financial Review" of 1 March 1992, that the Government has intended Garden Island to become the main east coast naval repair shipyard accurate; if so, why is the Government unwilling to expose ADI at Garden Island to full competition from the private sector at the end of its current five-year ship repair agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) and (b) In principle, AMECON will be able to tender for whatever work on ANZAC Ships which is put to tender. It should be recognised however, that maintenance and repair conducted in a ship's home port offers advantages in terms of transit and crew accommodation costs.
(2) To date AMECON has only informally expressed interest in bidding for maintenance contracts for the ANZAC frigates.

(3) It has always been the Government's intention that ADI's Naval Engineering Division, Garden Island Facility compete for work after the Five Year contracts with Defence expire on 30 June 1995. Its specialised capabilities would however give it a continuing advantage for some classes of ships.
